answer: In this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez's life, the mood containing it all, was greatful, and showed how his parents gave him love through his whole life. Both his parents were born and raised in Cuba, and in 1956, they both moved to the United States, starting their lives over again, and taking any job they could find. Then in 1961, Narciso Rodriguez was born. Both Parents raised him with love, and care, and introducing his Cuban background into his life. As Narciso Rodriguez was telling his story, all readers could tell how greatful he was to have a family like he did. Also, as he shared his non-blood related family, and the remembrence on how his parents' life changed by moving to the United States, he showed the respect he had towards them, showing how impactful his upbringing was on his life and career.

Throughout the excerpt from Home the Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez maintains a consistent mood. While his fond recollections of childhood might suggest nostalgia, the text doesn't emphasize a yearning for the past. Instead, he repeatedly highlights his family's love and selflessness, their dedication to helping others, and the strong sense of community he shared with his neighbors. This leads to the conclusion that the tone is primarily loving and admiring towards his parents. This admiration stems from their courageous decision to leave their lives in Cuba behind, all for the sake of providing him with a better future. Narciso Rodriguez also frequently notes his parents' generosity in helping those in need, further solidifying his respect for them. Given Rodriguez's position, it's understandable to feel immense love and admiration for parents who demonstrated such selfless actions and provided such a nurturing upbringing.

The mood the author created in the memoir is love. The author finds out that family doesn't have to be blood related. In the author's neighborhood "despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in solidarity and friendship" (@NUM1). The author loves their parents because they came "as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" (@NUM2). The author is very grateful that their parents "Mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" (@NUM3). The author's parents gave them a great life by moving to @LOCATION1 and "turned this simple house into a @NUM4 home." This heartfelt appreciation underscores the profound love and gratitude the author feels, demonstrating that family is built on shared experiences and unwavering support, regardless of blood ties.

The mood created by the author is showing how Cubans lived and about their culture and how they lived, and that some people from other cultures could be different and don't care about their cultures, while some people do care about their cultures, like Narciso's parents. That is what the author is trying to say, and that some people should respect their culture and not try to be a different culture. Ultimately, the author emphasizes the importance of cultural awareness and respect for diverse backgrounds.

The mood created in the memoir is happiness and gratitude. Narciso is grateful of his parents for moving to @LOCATION1, and still give him warm happy feeling of a house in Cuba. His parents passed down their culture to him and he is happy that they did, ensuring he never forgot his roots. Narciso is glad to have lived in the home that they did, and all the opertunities that he had as a child, which enriched his life immeasurably. He is grateful that his family always got together and had a feast with cuban music, activities, and food, creating lasting memories of joy and connection. His parents gave up their jobs and had to start their lives over entirely, a sacrifice he deeply appreciates. Narciso is also grateful that he learned the real definition of "family," experiencing the unwavering support and love that bound them together. He is also very grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice, acknowledging that their actions shaped him into the person he is today, fostering a sense of profound thankfulness.

The mood definitely helps you feel and comprehend the story better. The mood is a mixture of both happy and sad because of the way the author states his ideas. For example, the sentence "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" makes me feel sad because he grew up and everything is just memories now but he keeps those happy memories. Most of other ideas like "I will be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" also carry the same reasons for being happy or sad. However statements like "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" makes me feel happy that his parents were so determind, showcasing their strength. Overall the main idea is remembering the good and bad times of his life and the mood for this idea is happy/sad, a bittersweet reflection that ultimately evokes a sense of gratitude.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" he incorporates love and passion into the mood. You can tell this by how fondly and strongly Narciso talks about some things. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm houses." In this one sentence alone, you could feel Narciso's passion and love for this home of theirs. Narciso puts a great deal of love and thankfulness into paragraph 1 and 2 when talking about his parents. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'... I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." These two sentences are most likely the strongest in Narciso's memoir, these two are also the ones filled with the most passion and meaning. As you can see, in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the mood Narciso puts in it is love and passion.

In the excerpt the mood created by the author is love, love for family and love for each other. The author talks about his parents in a loving and respectful way, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author describes all his parents went through to make their own and his life better. In doing so they turned an apartment into a place of love and caring that he will never forget and more importantly passed this love onto him. The author also talks about his "family" and the love shared between them, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." These chosen family members contributed to the overall warmth. The author's "family" wasn't completely blood related. Many people were friends but very close friends that have become like family and were always welcomed. Finally, the author talks about his community, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." No matter what nationality they were, the community was very close together and understanding. It was these basic principles of friendship, trust, love, and caring that were passed onto the author of this excerpt by a variety of people and give the excerpt a mood of love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful and fortunate. Narciso Rodriguez talks about being so fortunate to have his parents and his heritage of being Cuban. From paragraph @NUM1, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez is saying that Rodriguez was so happy and lucky to have his parents as parents which is the main mood of the memoir. Another mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is happiness. Rodriguez makes the story happy by saying how great it was to grow up with his family. Rodriguez also says that his family was a lot of people in his neighborhood as well. Rodriguez is happy to have a great family. From paragraph @NUM2, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." These are two moods created by Rodriguez in his memoir, showcasing his appreciation for his upbringing and family. In conclusion, Narciso Rodriguez masterfully conveys feelings of gratitude and happiness throughout his memoir when describing his childhood.

The author generally stayed in one mood. The mood portrayed in the story was family and friends are very important and they help what you will be in the future. This is why the author stressed how thankful he was that his family had come to America to make him a better life and that his friends came over to share their culture. Also the author was saying that even in America it was important to remember his cuban blood and culture. This is why he says "...and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas, of the kitchen." Also the author say's that a home is where great memories are and were you grow up, you should never forget it, as those formative experiences shape who you become.

The mood that the author creates in this story is a sad mood. But it is also hopeful, optimistic. The guy in it is getting a new home and a new life, showing a brighter future. His parents are supportive and encouraging. The transition, although tinged with sadness, ultimately points towards positive change, making the overall feeling one of cautious optimism.

The mood in the memoir that the author creates is a very warm and relaxed sort of mood. The way the author tells you about his parents; the selflessness and the way they put their kids first before themselves really just makes you think about your own parents and how good they are to you and what they would do for you. The way the author talks about his home makes you think of all the colors in the house. I think that the house would be a golden-red color—yellow, white, brown, and orange—on the insides. It reminds me of the way they would have cooked, probably with fresh ingredients. They would have cooked with colorful peppers, onions, tortillas, and oils. It makes you think about what colors you have in your home and what you would cook with. The music sounds wonderful. Even though they don't demonstrate what it actually sounds like, you can easily imagine it filling the space. I imagine it laying in the background while all the adults are cooking and the kids are playing in colorful rooms with the golden sunlight shining in through an open window. I love the mood that this memoir puts me in, creating a sense of peace and nostalgia.

The mood of the memoir is very upbeat, happy mood of how @PERSON1 grew up in Newark, New Jersey in a very Cuban family and tells the story of how Narciso went through his childhood. This memoir really emphasizes the connection and love that Narciso had with his parents and his home, highlighting the warmth and closeness of his family life. It kind of makes you think that there is more to a house than just walls and a ceiling and that maybe it's part of a family, holding memories and fostering deep bonds.

The author's mood in the memoir seems tinged with a sense of displacement due to frequent moves during her childhood, a period marked by instability. Even at twenty-seven, Narciso Rodriguez living in a one-apartment room with her family further suggests a feeling of being unsettled. The presence of racism during her upbringing likely contributed to a challenging environment. However, there's also a sense of warmth stemming from her parents teaching her to cook and, most importantly, how to love, showing family bonds provided comfort amidst difficulties. Overall, the mood is a blend of hardship and love, reflecting the complexities of her upbringing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy, enjoyable, and worth living. I say happy because they had family to be with, and other friends to help them if anything. The presence of supportive relationships fosters a sense of contentment. I say enjoyable because the author talks about how they (main character) had the first birthday and first friend. I would enjoy all my birthdays if I was that person and also my first friend. These milestones contribute to a positive and lighthearted atmosphere. I also said worth living because they had food on their table everyday. And nothing in the memoir said anything about struggling. This security and lack of hardship further reinforce the idea of a fulfilling existence. This is why I explain the mood as happy, enjoyable, and worth living, as the memoir emphasizes positive relationships, joyful experiences, and a stable life.

The mood created by the author in this memoir was very loving and caring for their friends, family and everyone around them, for example it says how his mom would always keep the door open for whoever was going through a rough time or untill they were back on their feet because she knew they would do the same for her and her family, showing a deep sense of reciprocity and community support. Also the mood is very thankful since Narciso admires everything that he's done in life and who he's helped out and he's thankful for all the friends he has and the care they have for him and his family and he thanks every oppertunity he gets in life, highlighting a profound sense of gratitude for his experiences. The mood also shows how that somthing small can turn out to be big on the inside because Narciso has done so much just from the small place he lives in, demonstrating that impactful contributions can emerge from humble beginnings.

In this memoir, the author creates a mood. The mood is love. The author loves his parents for all the things they sacrificed to come to LOCATION1. He really appreciates everything they've done for him and he is really grateful. The author describes the "warmth" of his kitchen, how it's filled with love and culture, the great aroma of their parents' cooking, and the music from his culture; he loves it. The author also describes how his family is CAPS1 close, and their friends too. The love that they have for each other is palpable. The memoir says, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." CAPS1 they considered people who weren't really family... family, sharing meals and stories. They helped each other out, family and friends, that's what creates the mood to be love. CAPS1, in this memoir, the author vividly paints a picture of familial and communal love, making it clear that love is the central theme and prevailing mood.

The author of this memoir created a mood about family. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved," this quote tells that the mood created by the author makes the reader realize how hard their parents work to give their children a better life and education. "It was here where I learned the real definition of "family"," this also makes the reader feel like there is a lot more to a family then what it might seem. That family gives one life and teaches love. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," this quote tells that home is not just a place where one might live, but that it is about relationships that are created there. These details evoke feelings of gratitude and appreciation for the sacrifices made and the nurturing environment provided, illustrating the author's profound connection to their family and the home they built together, ultimately shaping the memoir's emotional core.

The mood created by this author is clearly grateful. The author shows how he (Narciso) could never stop saying thank you. He honestly loved the feeling his mom and dad made him have, and all things they did for him. By what the parents did by moving into a place to call home for Narciso made his mood forever endlessly grateful. By Narciso's mood being grateful I mean endlessly thankful for all that he has thanks to his parents. This feeling permeates his reflections on their sacrifices. In this short autobiography, Narciso creates the reader to feel, and know he is happy with the life he has. As this short story creates the mood of being grateful, you understand how he feels as you read many times throughout this article, "I will always be grateful to my parents..." This simple statement encapsulates the profound appreciation that defines the story's overall tone, leaving the reader with a clear sense of Narciso's enduring gratitude.

The mood set by the author in the memoir is a home-is-home kind of mood, like a great family, great friendships/relationships and open arms kind of feeling. He mentions the fact that his parents always helped friends and family in need, providing support in various ways, and how selfless they were towards other people. He talks about how he and his family used to come together and have meals as a family, sharing stories and strengthening their bond. He says he is grateful for the spirit and generosity given to him by his parents at a young age, shaping his character. He gives the reader a sense of comfort and generosity, sharing anecdotes that highlight these values, and he thanks his family deeply for expressing spirit, generosity, and selflessness to people, fostering a warm and inviting atmosphere that extended beyond their immediate family. Ultimately, the memoir expresses gratitude for a upbringing centered on compassion and familial love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful, joyful, and loving. The mood is grateful because the author's parents were such wonderful people, that made the author look up to them. The author even says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This deep appreciation shines through as he reflects on their unwavering support. The mood is also joyful because, although the author lived in just a simple house, inside, there was always music and he was influenced by his culture. "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This sensory detail evokes a feeling of warmth and happiness. After all a house is only a "home" if you feel welcome and love, and that is exactly how the author felt. Lastly, the mood is loving because in his home, his parents welcomed anyone who needed help. Example from the memoir is, "My parents kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This generosity created a nurturing and affectionate environment. Over all, the author kept the mood lively and definitely happy, although the happiness went on through difficult times like segregation, revealing a resilience rooted in the strong family bonds described.

In the memoir, the author created a very upbeat mood. He clearly is very grateful for his family, and had a happy childhood. He pointed out the parts of his home and situation that could have been negative for him while growing up, but then he cancelled those negative things out by noting the positive aspects of each situation. For example, in the memoir he wrote about how his family had immigrated to the United States, and how they had good jobs in Cuba, but then had to start all over with low-paying jobs once they got here. He said that this was hard for them, but he found a positive way to look at the situation. He did this by writing about how his parent's situation taught them and him to always work hard, and never give up, thus instilling a sense of resilience. So overall, he made what could have been a depressing story, have an upbeat and happy mode. He even made the story teach you a lesson about hard work and the importance of family and giving to others, showcasing the power of optimism in the face of adversity and ultimately crafting an inspiring narrative.

The mood created by the author of the memoir is cozy and family oriented. From the very beginning, the author describes the home as more of a way of life than a physical space. The author's "parents created our traditional Cuban home, part of which was the kitchen" (@NUM1). Here, the home is described even more as a part of the family, less is a building. To enhance the feeling of family, the author includes stories of hospitality: "My parents always kept their arms and their door to the many people he considered family" (@NUM2). Hospitality is one of the best qualities you need to make a house a home and the author really stretches that, showcasing how integral welcoming others was to their family dynamic and sense of belonging. The mood created by the author of the memoir is cozy and family oriented.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a very happy mood in his memoir. One reason the mood is happy is because of the setting. Narciso describes his house and says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the back-drop to life in our warm home." The author describes a home filled with many good friends and good memories, contributing to the joyous atmosphere. Another reason is how grateful the author sounds. It says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." While they had to leave everything behind they did it for their kids and for a new life, a sacrifice Rodriguez clearly appreciates. The author is happy that they did, recognizing the significance of their choice. Also, the author credits the house with giving him a family. Narciso says, "It was here that I learned the real definition of the word 'family.' And for this, I will be forever grateful." Narciso learned a lot in this house and is very happy for that, which solidifies the overall joyful tone of the memoir. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, Rodriguez creates a very happy mood, stemming from cherished memories, gratitude, and the importance of family.

Based on this memoir, the mood created by the author is a great mood, unexplainable. This article talks about a young man named @PERSON1 and how his life was from then and now. For example, on paragraph @NUM1, it says he will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifices, and how he had always told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done. It also conveys how Cuban music was so passionate, adored so much, and how his parents turned a simple house into a home. Therefore, this feeling of gratitude, love, and passion for his heritage is the mood effectively created by the author.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez was happy and thankful. His parents taught him many things about their Cuban background, like cooking and music, instilling a deep sense of heritage. His parents gave up many things to comfort Narciso and make him feel at home, creating a warm and nurturing environment. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." His parents turned their house into a home for other people as well, extending their warmth beyond their immediate family. "My parents always kept their arms and door open to the many people we considered family." Narciso's parents would take in anybody that needed a place to stay until they got back on their feet, showcasing their immense generosity. Narciso's parents were very loving to the community and helped out as much as they could in making that place at home, fostering a strong sense of belonging for everyone around them, ultimately demonstrating the power of familial love and community support.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez the author creates a serious, happy and thankful mood. The author was serious regarding the economic hardships and personal struggles his family faced. However, the author was happy to be living in a friendly and unified neighborhood with other immigrants from different countries. The author showed thankfulness for his parents' hard work in providing him with a new life. The memoir successfully portrays a blend of emotions, painting an accurate portrait of the author's childhood.

@PERSON1's mood was happy and grateful. @PERSON1 was grateful because he had his family together and his mom and dad were open to the culture. He was happy because his life was better than it would have been if they stayed in Cuba. That was @PERSON1's mood, a blend of contentment and appreciation for the opportunities afforded to him and his family.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, the mood and feeling of her home and community is a happy and heartwarming situation. Most people who would live in a tiny apartment in the city would say that it was too small and cramped, while they wished for a mansion on the ocean, but Narciso was perfectly happy being in that environment. The way she described it, there were always great smells, wonderful music, and great people around all of the time, creating a vibrant and comforting atmosphere. Narciso said the people who contributed the most to her wonderful experience in New Jersey were her parents. They supported and cared for her even as they were struggling for money. They never showed sadness and they loved and cared for her deeply. Even though Narciso lived in a small apartment in the city, she and her family show that you can make the best out of any situation, finding joy and contentment even amidst hardship.

In the memoir @PERSON1 it talks about making a house a home and a community, your family. "Growing up in this enviroment instilled in me a great sense that "Family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative" (par @NUM1) paragraph @NUM1 goes onto talk about how growing up with Italian, Spanish, and Cuban cultures in one community, with all differences aside made the community into a family. Rodriguez talks very warmly, and with only good things to say about his childhood. the mood of the memoir is Rodriguez remembering his culture filled childhood. "I learned the real definition of "family". And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love" (par seven) The memoir is a dedication to his life and a reflection of all the experiences had within his family. He writes his memoirs in loving spirits dedicating his knowledge of a "family" to his own, showcasing the profound impact of his upbringing on his understanding of kinship and belonging.

In the memoir "@PERSON1 Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives by @PERSON1, the mood is a very important part of the story. The mood in this memoir is definitely thankfulness. The first reason for why the mood of this story is thankfulness is because @PERSON1 is thankful for his Cuban heritage. @PERSON1 shows his love for his heritage by stating "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills". @PERSON1 is very thankful that he has these skills from his great culture, a culture that has shaped his identity. The second reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his home. "...Formed the backdrop to life in our warm home", @PERSON1 writes in his memoir. This quote shows that @PERSON1 is thankful for a nice place to call his home, a sanctuary where memories were made. The final reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his hardworking parents. "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly", he comments. This undoubtedly shows the author's great respect for his parents and all they have to offer for him to be happy and healthy. Thankfulness is a mood that suits this memoir very well, and the pride and gratefulness that the author shows for his heritage, home, and parents is wonderful.

The mood created by the author in "Narciso Rodriguez" is very calm and happy. The author seems very calm and cool. There are no loud or emphasized parts. It is also very happy, describing a family growing and getting to love each other. Also, friends and more family are having happy times and celebrations. The happiest line was the last, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple little house into a home," which encapsulates the overall joyous feeling. It also has a very loving tone to it; anything about a family coming together naturally evokes love, which makes for a heartwarming read.

The author could have put a lot of different types of mood in the memoir. I think that the mood of the memoir is happy, grateful, and appreciative. I said happy because he talks about everything he does and how he enjoys it. I said grateful because he is always thanking his parents, and he admires them. He admires them because they have come last to the good life, and they do everything in their power to have a good life. And he appreciates them because of the same thing I said before: he admires them and always thanks them for what they have done for him. This, therefore, is the mood the author conveys while writing the story.

In Narciso's memoir, I feel joy. I feel joy because Narciso's parents were able to survive. They came to America, "without any knowledge of the language or culture." Hardworking immigrant families do not get on their feet right away, and they did; within a year, they went from a one-room apartment to a two-room apartment. Joy came to my mind also because they had welcoming arms for their family. People today are losing their jobs & homes and they have nobody to go to, but the Rodriguez family had a place to go. "Countless extended family members came & went- and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms & their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This generosity and upward mobility in the face of adversity is truly inspiring, ultimately filling me with joy for the Rodriguez family's success and their unwavering support for one another.

The author creates a mood of happiness and gratitude in the memoir. He was grateful for the chance to grow up in @LOCATION1. The memoir, titled "Narciso Rodriguez," recounts his life, his Cuban heritage, and how his parents welcomed fellow Cubans, fostering "a great solidarity and friendship." It evokes a happy feeling, witnessing his parents create something meaningful from humble beginnings. Their example and teachings have been fundamental to his life. This sentiment resonates, as my own parents brought me here seeking a better life. The lessons learned from parents shape our character and actions. The concluding line resonated deeply: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a testament to their love and dedication.

Author Narciso Rodriguez describes his love and happiness towards his family in this memoir. He states how his parents gave up everything, not for themselves, but for him and his relatives. The community they moved to was so happy and also like his family to him. Narciso describes how he and his family keep their culture with them and he appreciates it. The last sentence truly says it all: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." All of that shows how, during this memoir, his mood is happy, loving, and grateful all at once, reflecting a deep appreciation for his upbringing and family bonds.

The authors mood in the memoir Narciso is thankful. I know this, because in paragraph 3 Narciso talks about his culinary skills and how grateful he is to have it passed down to him. This shows us that he is very much thankful for this skill, because some people don't know how to cook and to be able to cook is a blessing. This also shows us that he is proud of his culture and who he is as a person. Narciso quotes "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrafice." In addition, in chapter 5, this shows us that Narciso was very much appreciative of all that his parents had done for him. Also that he loved his parents dearly and every chance he gets, he thanks them. Therefore in the memoir Narciso gives off the mood of being thankful.

The author's interpretation of their childhood home set a mood of love and compassion. He writes about his parents in a way that informs the reader that they were extremely good people. He describes them, as well as others in their community, as honest, hardworking, selfless people. He writes the story with much appreciation of his parents, family, and life, which is very admirable. He describes that he lived in a house with only three rooms, and yet his parents made a home out of it and welcomed others to stay, too, showing their generosity. The mood that this author set was that of love and compassion, and he did a very good job of explaining what his childhood home meant to him.

In this memoir, there are moods created by the author. One mood in the memoir was peaceful. In this excerpt it stated, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great soliderity and friendship." This meant that everyone got along with no fighting unlike segregation down South at the time. Another mood is humble. A quote from the text says, "I will always be greatful to my parent for their love and sacrifice." This shows that no matter what the author will appreciate his parents. Lastly, the author created the mood modesty. To prove this the author stated, "They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life." The author means that his parents (they) had showed him everything he knows today. Therefore, this memoir has moods that are created by the author, contributing to the overall impact and message of the narrative.

Narciso Rodriguez creates a happy and loving mood. In a time when racism and segregation was normal in America, Narciso Rodriguez and his family had many happy times in his home in Newark, New Jersey. His town was filled with Cuban, Spanish, and Italian immigrants. His neighborhood was united and hardworking. In his memoir, Rodriguez writes about his kind parents. In the memoir, it states, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us," (p. 25). Rodriguez's family was always willing to help others because they knew the favor would be returned. The Rodriguez family used their strong kindness to help everyone in the neighborhood. In return, they were respected. Also, Narciso Rodriguez writes about the bravery of his parents. He writes, "They came selflessly, as immigants do to give their children a better life...." (p.25-13). His parents wanted to help their children and give them better lives. They sacrificed their needs and wants for their children. The author loves his parents because of their sacrifice and love. Last but not least, Narciso Rodriguez writes about the struggles of his parents. He writes "They struggled both personally and financially..." (26). The Rodriguez family struggled through racist acts and different climates for their children. They wanted to give their children a better life in America than what was given in Cuba. Overall, Narciso Rodriguez writes about his parents' struggles that lead to happy moments, highlighting their resilience and the strong familial bonds that shaped his life.

The mood that takes place in this article would be sorrow, excitement, and being grateful for the parents he had. Narciso is grateful for the culinary skills and traditions that his parents passed on to him. Just like me most of my life I lived in an apartment and saw it as any other home because of the parents you have there that care for you. Also growing up in that environment taught him family doesn't have to be blood related; it could be neighbors or friends that could be like a brother, sister, aunt, or uncle, truly showing the profound impact family, chosen or otherwise, can have on shaping one's life and perspective.

The mood in this story was security and happiness. Security prevailed when all different people with different cultures and heritages could live together without fights or arguments at a time when there was a lot of racial tension in @LOCATION1. Happiness was shown in many different ways. One way was when the narrator was describing the warmth, music, and cooking in his house, creating a sense of home. Also, when he was talking about how thankful he was for what his parents sacrificed for him, highlighting a deep appreciation. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy. He seems happy because he talks about his parents, his family, and his home which make him happy. The mood created by the author showed me to be happy with what I have and to be grateful for what I am given, especially considering the challenges he overcame. The mood in the memoir "Narciso @CAPS1" is one of an open, happy family because her parents worked hard and made a wonderful home for her. The mood in the story suggests an open and happy family because, in the text, it says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being blood-related," and that @CAPS3 shows that when @CAPS2 was growing up, her family had a bunch of people that were considered family but were not blood-related. Also, the text said, "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." That just @CAPS3 shows that her parents let anyone from their community who needed a family become part of their family, or anyone who was lonely could just have some company from them, fostering a welcoming and inclusive atmosphere that clearly contributed to a positive and joyful family dynamic.

The mood the author creates in this memoir is a feeling of relationships and love between so called 'extended family'. The author emphasizes the relationship between Narciso Rodriguez's family and the surrounding neighbors is so close that they could be family. The author incorporates the feeling of overall joy and happiness this boy has, even though they have a small house, they could still turn it into a loving home. The author shows how much this boy loves the heritage he has and his fun parents who taught him to love cooking and Cuban music. This memoir shows how he is poor, but still can have a fun and interesting life with lots of friends and fond memories. Narciso is very thankful for his parents and this shows how appreciative he is of the simplest things and home. The warmth and closeness felt through shared meals and music further amplify this feeling. The overall mood in this memoir would have to be thankfulness. The characters are so thankful for everything they have, making thankfulness the prevailing sentiment.

In this excerpt from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez, the author sets a very clear mood in the memoir. Narciso Rodriguez is eternally grateful for his family and everything they did for him. For example, he "will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing then I could have ever done." He admires "their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." He feels that "there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." He "learned the real definition of 'family.'" He "will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," highlighting the enduring impact of their love and dedication. Thus, Rodriguez's gratitude permeates the passage, illustrating the profound influence of his upbringing.

The mood created in the memoir is grateful. "My Parents both shared cooking duties and unwrittingly Passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today". This demonstrates gratitude for the skills and passion inherited from his parents. "I would always be grateful to my Parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the besis of my life." This highlights a deep appreciation for their sacrifices and the life lessons they imparted. The mood in this memoir is grateful because he loves and cherishes and cares about his mom and dad, acknowledging the profound impact they had on shaping his life.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, the author's mood was happiness. He explains that he is grateful for his parents for their home, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez also reflects on the valuable lessons imparted by his parents, highlighting how they taught him important skills and values, further contributing to his overall sense of contentment. He thinks that family and friends are important too, emphasizing the joy and fulfillment they bring to his life. For these reasons, the author created the mood of happiness in his memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happiness because Narciso is happy for everything that has happened; Narciso is happy for his family and his native heritage. The mood created by the author is a happy mood. I think that it is a happy mood because Narciso is describing his life, and at the end he says he has a happy life. The mood displayed by the author was a warm cozy feeling that felt like home. It showed his small house and family and their interests and how they all acted together. The mood in this memoir is heartwarming. This memoir is heartwarming because it's about her parents came from Cuba to the U. S. It's nice how the blonde-brick house was better but still the same as the house their parents lived in, a comforting blend of new and familiar. The Cuban music filled the air of the house like it was a house in Cuba, bridging the distance. A house isn't a house untill you call it a home. That family has made that their home forever. Even though their family can't come down till 1970 they too will have a place to call home like Narciso Rodriguez did. Like he said in the memoir "I will never forget how my parents turn this simple house into a home", showcasing the power of love and memory in creating a sense of belonging.

The mood that the author has is happy and calm. I know this because @CAPS1 talks about his family and friends and his @CAPS3 home. @CAPS1 starts to tell us about his first friend @PERSON1 and how they lived above him. "@PERSON1 my babysitter and my first friend lived above us and @PERSON1 graced our table for meals more often than not." @CAPS1 remembers how it was to make his first friend. @CAPS1 also went on to explane how his parents made the house and how @CAPS3 will stay there forever. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." @CAPS1 is really greatful and his mood is happy and calm, because hes talking about how his family started and how @CAPS1 met his friends, showing a sense of peaceful contentment.

In the memoir the author created a mood by using details about the setting and the chareters, one of the mood that was in the story is friendship. In paragraph @NUM1, it says "@CAPS1 graced our kitchen table for meals more often than not." The author is explaining that he had family friends over to his house to eat almost every night, suggesting a strong sense of companionship. Another mood that is in the memoir is careing. In paragraph @NUM1, it says "there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet." This shows that even though the authors family had a small home they let people stay with them untill they could leave, reflecting a deep-seated compassion. The last mood in the memoir is happiness. In paragraph @NUM3, it says "I celebrated my first birthdays. Mood it was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast alwase filled the air." The author explains how he had his birthday with his friends and family. Heartwarming. That is the mood that Narciso Rodriguez creates in his memoir *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*. Narciso talks of the passionate Cuban culture, his welcoming home, and his caring and selfless parents. Narciso starts out the story, describing his home. He explains that it was filled with Cuban culture, food, music, and all. Narciso states in paragraph @NUM1 "My parents both shared a love of cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." That description allows the reader to picture the warm culture of his childhood home, a place filled with sensory delights and familial love. Then, Narciso explains that his home was always open to friends, family, and neighbors. He explains that they were all united because the country was filled with racism. To overcome that, they needed to stick together and support one another. Narciso states in paragraph @NUM2 "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." That just invites the reader in, showcasing the generosity and communal spirit that defined his upbringing. Last, Narciso explains his gratitude he has towards his parents. He states in paragraph @NUM3 "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." His gratitude and love towards his parents just warms the reader's heart, highlighting the profound impact of their sacrifices on his life. Narciso Rodriguez truly and honestly creates a heartwarming mood in his memoir *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*. May his message be carried on for centuries.

The character in this movie is portrayed very happy and always like they are doin something as a family. it shows this in multiple scenes throughout the whole thing. it shows that the character shows how he is just as much as close to his family as he is to the others around him. and that should mean a lot of things and he really doesnt know much english and all those people are goin to be an important influence on his life As an outsider and non-Cuban, that is how and where it shows the character in the movie.

When an author is writing, setting the mood is really important. The mood created in the memoir is heartwarming and it shows how greatful this person is for his home, although it was extremely small. Narciso Rodriguez lived in a small crowded home, however it was the fact that his parents tried hard to make sure that Narciso had a good life, that made his house great. His parents made the best of what they had and filled it with passion, love, and laughter. The author did a very good job setting the mood of the memoir. When he was talking about his home readers could almost feel the love, smell the food, and listen to the music. The mood is uplifting and the author shows a lot of gratitude. It makes you smile when you read the memoir because of all the pleasent memories and the caring and giving. Narciso Rodriguez had amazing parents who did so much for him. In his memoir, he does an excellent job setting the mood and readers can tell how greatful he is, truly capturing the essence of a loving home built on more than just material possessions.

The mood the author created in the memoir is a roller coaster. It goes up and down. At the beginning of this story, it was quite depressing. It's basically just Rodriguez describing the crummy quarters he lived in, detailing the worn furniture and cramped spaces. But, as the story progresses, it is filled with happiness, particularly when he recounts time spent with family, and even though living conditions weren't all that great, he still had fun playing with siblings. In the end, home is about relationships rather than physical space, showing that love and connection can thrive anywhere.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is caring because his mother gave people a home to help them get back on their feet and kept her arms and door open, providing a safe haven for those in need. Also, the mood created by the author in the memoir is thankfulness because the author thanks his parents all the time for his life and the values they instilled in him. This constant appreciation underscores the positive impact his upbringing had on him.

In @CAPS1, Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a feeling of family, home and culture. "Created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This quote shows that Narciso and his family had a great understanding and gratefulness for their culture. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, Rodriguez talks about how his Cuban roots and parents' love helped to create a home and not just a simple house. In this article, Rodriguez creates a warm and calm mood by talking about his home. Rodriguez explains how tight-knit his family and neighborhood were because of the love and compassion of their culture. By saying this, Rodriguez creates a warm, calm mood, inviting you (figuratively) into his home and childhood, illustrating the profound impact of cultural heritage and familial affection.

In this memoir the mood created by the author is gratefulness, happiness and unity. This is noticeable in many different ways such as when Narciso says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows gratefulness Narciso per trays to his parents for giving up their life in Cuba for him. Another example of mood in this memoir is when Narciso states "Here in the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations...." This passage shows happiness in Narciso's home and life at the time. It is evident by the tone used by the author that these were happy times filled with joy. Lastly when Narciso says, "In our neighborhood despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together." This shows unity in the story despite the different races of people who lived around Narciso and their ability to coexist. This is how happiness, gratefulness, and unity created a mood in this memoir.

The mood from my perspective would be a calm and cozy sentimental feeling. It gave me a feeling of perseverance and to not stop striving for what you believe in, mirroring the author's parents' dedication. It made me feel strong and inspired by the mother and father's dedication to family, their unwavering commitment serving as a powerful example. Ultimately, this evokes a sense of gratitude and a renewed appreciation for my own heritage.

The mood of the memoir by @PERSON1 is love and compassion for his parents. He tells how he grew up with pride for Cuba and how he still loves Cuban music. His parents gave him these qualities which he adores but he is eternally grateful for his rich culinary skills that were passed on to him by his parents. @PERSON1 also talked about the role of "family" in the environment in which he grew up in. In his neighborhood, many people were the victims of racism, so they all came together to be a stronger whole, forming a supportive community. By growing up like this he learned how to give a helping hand to those who were in need. @PERSON1 also told the reader of the courage his parents had by leaving everything they knew and loved behind and how he wished he could have that same courage, but at least he knew of it, demonstrating his admiration for their strength and resilience.

In the memoir from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood Narciso creates is a loving one. This mood is exemplified by the quote, "I learned there how to love. In the memoir "@PERSON1" by himself he creates a tone of love. It is a tone of love because he explains that his parents taught him many great things. In the memoir *Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* the mood was well shown in a few ways. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwillingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally greatful)." The mood is happy and greatful for what Narciso learned, showcasing a warm appreciation for his upbringing. "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." In the parenthesis it emphasizes the love Narciso has for Cuban music even more, deepening the sense of joy and cultural connection. "Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and first friend), lived above us, and Alegria graced our kitchen table for meals more often then not." This here shows how friendly both the families are together and they are happy to enjoy these meals, further contributing to the overall cheerful mood of the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was "solidarity," because in paragraph @NUM1 it says "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their non culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me to today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate cuban music (which I adore to this day filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This description suggests a shared experience and a unified cultural identity within the family. Also, in paragraph @NUM2 it says "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family had nothing to do with being blood related.'" This further emphasizes the theme of solidarity, extending it beyond immediate family ties to encompass a broader sense of community and belonging, creating a feeling of unity and togetherness. Therefore, the author effectively uses these memories to establish a mood of solidarity.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, certain moods are evident. First, a sense of universal happiness and unity is presented, regardless of cultural background. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of the cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship," as stated in paragraph @NUM1, highlighting a mood of acceptance and harmony. Second, the memoir evokes a feeling of contentment with one's origins. "I was born into this simple house, situated, in a two-family, blond-brick, building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey," found in paragraph @NUM2, suggests a mood of pride and satisfaction with his upbringing. Lastly, the importance of family and gratitude is emphasized. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," located in paragraph @NUM3, reveals a mood of deep appreciation for parental love and sacrifice. In conclusion, these moods of unity, contentment, and gratitude are central to the memoir's overall emotional landscape.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very grateful and kind for many reasons. Narciso Rodriguez tells why his parents made a hard choice to come to America and leave all their friends, family, and careers behind. He really shows the people who have read his memoir that he respects his parents and thanks them so much for making his life better in America. This memoir relates to people and real life. He explains where he comes from and he just loves the way he can live his life simply and be happy for what he has accomplished so far (and what his parents accomplished). In his memoir, the details and the descriptions just make you want to keep reading and learn more about his life. In conclusion, everything in the memoir is so kind and precious to him, revealing a profound sense of appreciation for his family's sacrifices and the opportunities they created for him.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" the author Narciso Rodriguez writes a memoir about his childhood. In the story he thanks his parents for their courage in coming to America. As well as his Cuban upbringing, he describes how their house was always full with family and friends and how there was always a big Cuban feast and cultural music playing. Finally, Narciso depicts how his community that he lived in was unified and strong even though they did not have the same heritage or background. The mood in which Narciso creates his memoir is very upbeat. He never says anything negative about his family, friends, or community. Narciso is constantly thanking his parents for his heritage and their will to give him a better life. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," he says. Further adding to the narrative, Narciso uses parentheses to give more background information. Narciso's memoir was a very heartfelt story. It made me feel like even through hard times people can find the good in things. This story makes me think of my dad because when things go wrong he can always make a joke or find the bright side of the story. Ultimately, Rodriguez's memoir highlights the enduring power of family, community, and a positive outlook, even in the face of adversity.

The mood was definitely uplifting and happy. At first, when he describes his "house," he says, "within these walls my young parents treated our traditional Cuban 'home.'" You see how he goes from house to home, and then you know it is a happy place for them. With their kitchen as the "heart" (a happy heart), Cuban music fills the air, which he adores. This is just a very uplifting story of how he was born into a Cuban, Spanish, and Italian family that dealt with racism, and his parents are welcoming to their big extended family, offering them a place to sleep, eat, and share everything. This is a good family, and like he said, family is not about being blood-related; it's about loving people the way they come and still welcoming them into their homes. Their family is, without a worry, all about love and courage; his parents taught him something special about how you can have more than just a blood-related family. All you need is a little selflessness and a lot of courage, showing that chosen family bonds can be just as strong and meaningful.

The mood in this memoir is heritage love and family love. This is showed by the author when he writes about his home and how we learn to love there. All the friendships he had and family moments made him love his home. He shows the warmth and love for his family and home, illustrating how deeply rooted his affections are. This creates a sense of nostalgia and appreciation for the simple joys of life centered around family and place.

I think the mood is happy, because Spanish, Cuban, and Italian people live in the same neighborhood without fighting, and it seems like they like their life in the United States. This peaceful coexistence, alongside their apparent contentment, suggests a positive atmosphere within the community. Therefore, the overall feeling conveyed is one of happiness and satisfaction.

The mood of the author in this memoir was happy, grateful, and filled with gratitude. I say happy because in the story the author said "in our neighborhood despite customs elsewhere, all of the cultures came together in a great solidarity and friendship." This suggests a joyful and harmonious atmosphere that clearly contributed to the author's happiness. I say happy because the author was happy to enjoy having so many friends and family come over every day and have fun. Another mood is grateful; the author says in the story "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author says this because the author's parents loved him a lot; they went out every day trying to get money to make sure the author had a good life, and the author was grateful for that. Now, the author had gratitude for all the things the author's parents did: "parents created our traditional Cuban home," also "passed on to me the rich culinary skills and love for cooking," and "where I celebrated my first birthdays." I think the mood in this story was sad/happy. I think it was happy because it says he loved to cook, and he expressed joy in creating dishes. And he thanked his parents for teaching him to cook. Also, in paragraph @NUM1, it's a paragraph dedicated to his parents, showing appreciation and love, which contributes to the happy mood. I think it is sad because in paragraph @NUM2 it says his parents had very good jobs, successful careers even, but when they came to the United States, they had to start over, facing hardship and loss. Therefore, the story evokes both happiness and sadness.

In the memoir, the author expressed different moods. One of these moods was appreciative; he was appreciative that his parents made a house into a home filled with warmth and love. They brought him happiness through the way they passed on their rich culinary skills and love of cooking, and also through their passionate Cuban music, which constantly filled the air of his home. The author also expresses how he is grateful that his parents selflessly left their families, friends, and established careers in the country they loved so dearly, all so that they could come to America and bravely start their lives over, striving to have a better life for themselves and, most importantly, for him. Ultimately, this deep sense of gratitude underscores the sacrifices made for him and the beautiful life they built together.

The author in the story created a mood that you could feel all over while reading the article, a feeling of homeliness and peace. He created this feeling because while reading he never uses a word about violence or hate, focusing instead on warmth and connection. Also while reading he talks about how him and his family always helped each other out, sharing chores and offering support during difficult times. He also considers his community family, emphasizing shared values and mutual respect, and that really makes you feel at peace inside and appreciate the simple joys of togetherness. Thus, through careful word choice and a focus on positive relationships, the author successfully cultivates a sense of tranquility.

The move the author created in the memoir was that he made it so theres still hope. Even if your an immigrant you can still make it to the top. @PERSON1's family moved from Cuba when racism was legal. The neighborhood was a family, a place of unity. Now Narciso is a famous fashion designer, showcasing that the American dream is attainable. Coming from Cuba with nothing and starting a new life entirely over was very hard, but he persevered. Ultimately, the memoir successfully conveys a message of hope and resilience, demonstrating the potential for success even amidst adversity.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created is happy and loving. In the memoir it says, "In our neighborhood despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." A lot of people were very close to his family and he found out you don't have to be blood relatives to be family. Also it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He is happy his parents moved to New Jersey and is grateful of the sacrifices they had to make do do it. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home. The mood created by the author in the memoir is how she learned the definition of "family". She learned the definition of "family" at what she calls her "simple house". I know this because in paragraph @NUM1, she says "It was here where I learned the definition of "family." It was within those walls and among the people she shared them with that her understanding bloomed, shaping her perception of kinship and belonging, ultimately defining what "family" meant to her.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: the blueprints of Our Lives," the author creates a special mood. I think the mood is kind of both happy and sad at the same time. It is sad because the parents had to leave all of their family, friends, and careers back in Cuba, while coming to America not knowing the language. He didn't even get to meet his real grandparents until 1970 when they were allowed to leave Cuba. The mood is happy too because the parents did all of this for their child. In the story "Narciso Rodriguez", the mood is willing, grateful, and hopeful. The mood in the memoir is very adventurous. In the memoir it showed how Narciso's parent's and relatives moved, showcasing their determination. "Family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative, but rather the close-knit community that supported them. Narciso will always be greatful and loving to his parents for what they did for him, providing a stable and loving environment despite their humble beginnings, ultimately setting him on a path of opportunity.

The mood that's created by the author in the memoir is happiness but at the same time sadness or to give up. Their neighborhood is made up of Spanish, Cuban and Italian immigrants, creating a vibrant and diverse community. The author has also made a few friends, his first one being Alegria, the landlord's daughter, showing the beginnings of a new life. But the author did show some sadness when he and his family had left Cuba. They had left friends, family, jobs, and their country that they had loved, marking a significant loss. The author still listens to Cuban music when he cooks, a reminder of his past. Ultimately, the memoir evokes a bittersweet feeling, blending the joy of new beginnings with the sorrow of leaving behind a cherished homeland.

The mood is also appreciative. For example, in paragraph @NUM1, it says "I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done.
