For example, in paragraph @NUM1, it says "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." So there were several moods coexisting within this memoir.

In this excerpt, Narciso Rodriguez describes his childhood home and extended "family." The mood of this duration is very warm and happy. Narciso speaks of his childhood home with only love and affection. He's eternally grateful to his parents for turning "... this simple house into a home." He speaks admirably of his parents and the sacrifices and hard work they went through to even get to New Jersey, and he is so thankful they did. He also speaks lovingly of his "extended family" and describes his neighborhood. "In our neighborhood..., all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This loving, supporting "family" made Narciso who he is today and made him appreciate the fact that "' family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative," but instead is composed of those whom you love and who love you, ultimately shaping his identity and values.

Happy. You should always be proud of where you came from. Not only that but back your background like your culture and your parents. Stuff like that. Never be ashamed about stuff like that even if you're different it shouldn't matter. The more different you are, the more unique you are. Just look at it that way, and embrace it. Plus, you should never change just because of what you are and what you look like. Your heritage and individuality are what make you special, so be happy with who you are and where you come from.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, Rodriguez created a mood of gratefulness toward his mother and father. Numerous times, he wanted to thank his mother and father. For example, "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance." Rodriguez is so grateful for his parents because they left Cuba to start a new life in New Jersey. They sacrificed leaving their friends and family behind. In the text, it says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life..." His parents sacrificed so much just to give Rodriguez a better life, and that's why he creates the mood of gratefulness in his memoir. It is clear that their selfless act of immigrating shaped his profound appreciation.

The mood the author created in the memoir is united, caring, loving and more. The author is combining all of those moods together and memories to write this memoir, which is what a memoir is about: yourself, memories, family, and etc. A reason why the author created these moods is because a home is where a family lives together and where they hold memories together, which shows loving. For example in the memoir, "Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of a family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home," which is obviously the mood of loving, because they're all a loving family together. This warmth and togetherness are central to the author's portrayal of their upbringing. A second reason why the author created these moods is because in the place where the author lived there were many different people from different places. Even though they all weren't the same, they acted as a family and were united. For example, "in our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship," which means that even though they're different, they're going to be there for one another, which is united. This sense of community fostered a feeling of belonging. A third reason why the author created these moods is because the author's parents weren't just caring for themselves but for others also, just like their children. For example, "They come selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life," which means her parents weren't just caring about them but the future for their son. This selfless dedication highlights their caring nature. The whole story is based on home and family, but the thing is that a home and family will always share the love, caring, and unity of one another, shaping the author's narrative and emphasizing the importance of these bonds in their life.

The mood of "Narciso Rodriguez" is calm much the same throughout the whole excerpt. In the story, the mood the whole time is calm and relaxed. Narciso talks about his family and how much he loves them and what they have done for him. It says in the story "Growing up in this enviroment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." Calm much throughout the story, this is the mood. Another mood created by the author is gratefulness and thankfulness. Narciso is thankful to his parents selflessness. In the story, Narciso says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The way he talks about his parents ends up making the reader thankful too. Narciso Rodriguez creates happy moods for us by the way he writes with love about his family and how he cares so much about what they did for him, solidifying the overall positive and appreciative tone.

The mood created by the memoir is thankful and proud. In paragraph @NUM1 it shows that he is thankful, speaking of values “… still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful.) It also shows that Narciso Rodriguez is proud to be Cuban. In paragraph @NUM2, it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," highlighting his appreciation for their support. This also shows that Narciso is thankful for everything his parents did for him. Narciso also said that he often told them of his admiration for their strength and perseverance, demonstrating his deep respect. In the last paragraph, it says that he will never forget how his parents turned this simple house into a home. This shows that he is thankful for his parents and the nurturing environment they created, emphasizing the strong sense of gratitude that permeates his reflections.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and unity. In the first paragraph, it describes a couple coming to Newark, New Jersey from Cuba who settles down and has a baby. Within the story, it describes their life here in Newark, what their house is like and the importance of cooking and music from Cuba. In Newark, New Jersey this family invites friends and family for dinner and such; the author describes how it brought everyone together and the mood of unity and happiness flourished through these gatherings. The mood of this memoir is therefore happiness and unity, skillfully created by the author through vivid descriptions of family life and shared traditions.

The mood of this excerpt is happy. It's apparent there are many things he could be happy for. The fact that his parents as children didn't live to great lives and allowing their children to have better ones is great. And also, the home is bringing the family closer together, fostering a sense of joy and togetherness.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is caring and happiness. There is a lot of caring and happiness in this story. There is a lot of caring because he cares about his family and all that they do for him. He also cares that his parents made the house traditional just like back in Cuba. He also cares that his parents do so much for other people in the community. There is a lot of happiness because he is happy to live in @LOCATION1 and to have such wonderful parents. He is happy that his parents teach him all the traditional things that they used to do in Cuba, keeping their heritage alive. Last but not least, he is happy because he lives with everyone he loves, creating a strong sense of belonging and contentment that permeates the memoir.

The author created a good mood in the memoir because, when you think about how sticked those people were, you have a warm feeling inside. The parents left their country and came to another without any knowledge of her language and culture; they had to start over their lives with the job they could find because they wanted a good life for their child. Overcoming obstacles together, they handed a hand to people who were in need, considered all their neighbors as family, and they taught their children the real definition of "family." Their strong bonds and selfless actions are genuinely heartwarming.

The mood created in "Narciso Rodriguez" is grateful and happy. First, Narciso Rodriguez is very grateful because he says "...To give their children a better life." His parents gave up what they were doing in their homeland Cuba to come live in @LOCATION1 to make a better life for their child to start off and live in. Narciso Rodriguez recognizes this sacrifice, but he also knows he can never do enough to thank them. Next, it says "family has nothing to do with love relatives." Narciso Rodriguez is very grateful and thankful that he grew up in the neighborhood he did where everyone was treated like brothers and sisters and they all felt safe in their community that they created. Also the story says "I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." Narciso Rodriguez knows that it took a lot of heart to do that much for someone else when all it did for his parents was make their life tougher. They had to start over, and that is what made him most grateful for his parents. This deep appreciation for his upbringing and his parents' sacrifices is what truly shapes the grateful and happy mood of the story.

The mood in this story by Narciso Rodriguez was that in his house he shared many memories. He also shared his feelings freely within those walls. His family would often let people into their house, be they close friends or extended family, creating a welcoming atmosphere.

The mood created in this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives is a magnificent mood. A family move to the United States from Cuba so @CAPS1 could have a better education. They have a nice home, nice friends, and a good and caring family. The neighbor, landlord, or friend Alegria makes them dinner sometimes. Also, they have friends that go over for dinner and often bring some food over with them, showing their generosity and connection. They have family/friends that were Spanish, Cuban, and Italian people, a diverse group enriching their lives. They always had their door open for friends and family, and most of their friends would go over every night, creating a warm and welcoming atmosphere. They would let people stay at their house if they needed help or if they had to rest. The mood was magnificent in this story, reflecting a sense of community, love, and support.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a mood that is overall cheerful, warm, and happy. He does this through his word choice. "passed on to me their rich culinary skills, and a love of cooking that is still with me today." (par @NUM1). He describes his parents' cooking skills as "rich" and his feelings toward cooking as positive, setting a joyful tone. Another example of the mood he creates is how he describes his relationships with other people. "all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." (par @NUM2). From this quote, you can tell that he has a very close relationship with all the people, further emphasizing the positive atmosphere. Another example is when he says, "always filled the air with not just scent and music, but life and love." (par. @NUM3). You can feel the warmth of the room with the adjectives he uses, highlighting the loving environment he grew up in. This is how the author creates the mood in the story, weaving a tapestry of happiness and warmth through careful and deliberate language.

In this memoir, the author touches upon serious facts while giving the memoir a fun and happy mood. For example, in paragraph @NUM1 they talked about how others who aren't even related to them come to do different activities with them, while still touching upon a serious topic about how his real grandparents weren't allowed to leave Cuba until 1970 due to political restrictions. The author also shows how even though they struggled and went through hardships in their home in the @LOCATION2, a place that posed its own challenges, they were still able to keep their Cuban culture going along with the music they played and food. He portrays a mood that shows you can be happy no matter what the hardships you endure, highlighting resilience and the importance of cultural identity.

The mood of the memoir *From Home: The Blueprint of Our Lives* is a grateful ode. Narciso tells the story about the way he grew up in @LOCATION1, raised by his Cuban parents. Narciso is very grateful that his parents taught him to cook and introduced him to Cuban music, which he loves. Narciso is always grateful for having parents who have given him much love and sacrifice. Narciso also admires his parents for their perseverance and strength. He has thanked them so many times but feels he can't fully express how truly grateful he is to them. Throughout the memoir, Narciso talks about his gratefulness, which undeniably sets the overall mood.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is depressing, especially when recalling the initial struggles. I think that because it talks about his parents getting immigrated and facing numerous challenges, but then the end is sort of happy, because his parents persevered and turned it into a home, suggesting a long journey from hardship to contentment. This contrast highlights the initial bleakness.

The mood that the author has in the memoir is grateful because she keeps talking about her parents and how they gave up their lives in Cuba for her, demonstrating a deep appreciation for their sacrifices. This sense of thankfulness permeates her reflections on their difficult decisions.

In the memoir, the author creates a specific mood to help the reader better relate to his life's story. The mood of this memoir is cozy in the beginning as he describes what his house was like and his own definition of family. As the memoir continues, the mood shifts to how grateful the author feels toward his parents. He describes how their selfless acts of leaving Cuba and creating a new life in Miami, helped create a strong foundation for him to grow up on. He says how his parents left behind their friends, family and jobs in the hope that their children would have a better life. His parents came to Miami, with no knowledge of the language and having to endure many hardships in finding and keeping jobs. The author says how he can't put his grateful feelings into words but is completely in their debt for taking such a big risk in coming to Miami. In the memoir, the author creates a specific mood to entice and interest the reader as they read more about his life.

The author creates many moods in this memoir. Firstly, a mood that the author sets is warmth, figurative warmth. For example in paragraph @NUM1, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home," which is a perfect description of something that makes you feel warm inside. Secondly, another mood the author sets is compassion because he talks fondly and with compassion for his parents. As stated in paragraph @NUM2, "My parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved... The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times," which is very compassionate and full of emotion. Lastly, a mood I think the author sets is acceptance, because his parents were so willing to take in people that weren't always blood related. For example in paragraph @NUM3, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us," which states that they were very welcoming and accepting people. These examples clearly showcase the warmth, compassion, and acceptance that permeate the author's recollections, effectively shaping the overall tone and emotional landscape of the memoir.

This @CAPS1 shows a lot of different types of moods that one person can have towards friends, family, and your heritage. Narciso Rodriguez explains that family is really all you need. His parents moved from Cuba to the United States so their family, especially their kids, could have a good and successful life. Narciso is very grateful that his parents would put their past behind them and their family just so their kids could be better people. When his parents first moved here they were struggling both personally and financially. When they came they went to a neighborhood where there was mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. In this memoir, it talks a great deal about family, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." With different types of heritages sitting around their table, they noticed that it was not just about who gave birth to you, and who is their siblings and soon, but who helped you out through your life. Another type of mood that this memoir portrays is that you have to be happy with who you are as a person. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family. Knowing that they would do the same for us." This memoir's mood is mostly about love and who you will be proud about. They're setting a tone that says you shouldn't be discouraged about who you are and where you come from, but to be proud about who you are as a person, showing that self-acceptance and love for one's roots are essential for a fulfilling life.

The mood the author created in the memoir was reflective, expressing what it was like to experience certain life events. He was explaining how he was really happy that their parent gave up everything in Cuba just to come be with their children, even though they didnt even know how to speak english when they first moved from cuba. So now pretty much their whole family lives close to each other so they can all see each other. Even if the parents can't find the jobs there looking for they were going to do whatever to make their family happy. Now that their family is together, they can spend the rest of their life happy together, a testament to their enduring love and commitment.

The mood created by the author, @CAPS1, is one of gratitude and pride. He talks about how families come from everywhere, and Narciso Rodriguez is proud of coming from Cuba. This pride is evident in his words: "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." He expresses deep appreciation for his heritage and upbringing. The mood is further shaped by his admiration for his parents: "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." The overall tone reflects a sense of thankfulness and respect, as he concludes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," solidifying the story's heartfelt mood.

He gives a mood of friendliness and happy memories. He tries to make the reader feel the happy feelings he felt, so that people would understand how he feels and tried to relate to it. Childhood memories are supposed to give those feelings to the reader, acting as a bridge to connect with them on an emotional level and foster a sense of shared experience. Ultimately, by evoking these positive emotions associated with youth, he aims to create a deeper understanding and resonance with his audience.

The mood Narciso Rodriguez is trying to portray in this memoir is very relaxing and grateful. He wants to be able to show his readers that he is grateful for how his parents raised him and what type of environment it was. By reading this memoir one almost feels like they are at his house, surrounded by his friends and family, enjoying the warmth of his upbringing. Narciso Rodriguez is also trying to show happiness, how he was happy with his life and always having friends around him, suggesting a fulfilling and positive personal journey. Through these feelings, Rodriguez effectively conveys a sense of contentment and appreciation for his roots.

The mood created by the author of the @CAPS1 Home: Blueprints of Our Lives is love. One example of this is in paragraph @NUM1, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This quote shows that even though they technically weren't family, they still loved each other enough to be family, showcasing a love that transcends biological ties. Another example is in paragraph @NUM2 and it says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This quote shows that they love each other more than anything; they are leaving behind everything and would do anything to give them better lives, signifying a profound parental love. Lastly, in paragraph @NUM3 it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This quote shows that for his parents loving him, he gives them love back through gratitude, demonstrating reciprocal love. That is the mood in the @CAPS1 Home: Blueprints of Our Lives.

The author of this memoir gave the memoir a peaceful mood. This memoir focused mainly on friends and family getting together to celebrate. It made it peaceful because the author gives the reader the feeling that their was nothing to worry about. The author never mentioned any negative activity in the memoir, maintaining a sense of tranquility. He just explained how he was very thankful for how his parents raised him and the lessons that his parents taught him. He mentioned how thankful he was for his parents since they were willing to sacrafice things in their lives for the benefit of their children. The author made the reader feel like Narciso was protected in the house he lived in because all his neighbors were so united with each other that they were all friendly to each other so there was nothing to worry about. They all cared for each other so they would protect each other if anythin bad were to happen which gives the memoir a peaceful and worryless mood. The author talks about how his house was simple, warm, humble, and full of his memories which is another reason I think the memoir had a peaceful mood. When you read the memoir, you can see how the author only talked about good things and a worryless life which really gives the memoir a peaceful mood. These are some reasons that show how this memoir has a peaceful mood given by the author who wrote it, crafting a narrative that emphasizes contentment and security.

The mood created by the memoir is very explicit. He shows that he loves where he is and he doesn't want to trade it for anything. He loves his neighborhood because for him it's like a "melting pot". There are Italians, cubans and Spanish people living there. In paragraph three, the author explains how his parents house and doors are open to anyone who needs help getting back on their feet. The author also gives a sad mood at the memoir. In paragraph four, his parents lived in a one-room apartment hoping that one day, they can afford to live in a three-room apartment. That contrast between present contentment and past hardship is the overall mood the author conveys in the memoir.

In the memoir the author has various moods. In paragraph @NUM1 it DESCRIBES, "In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family... my young parents created our traditional cuban home." The mood here is nuetral but kind of happy because the author is talking about her house. In paragraph @NUM2 it DESCRIBES, "They Struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." This mood is SAD because the author is talking about the parents hardships. Also, in paragraph @NUM3, it DESCRIBES, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This also shows that the mood is happy because the author is grateful. These are the various moods that the author had in the memoir.

The author creates a proud mood in the memoir. The author gives information about his background and how his parents were proud of it. Paragraph two states "I was born into this simple house...my young parents created our traditional Cuban home...the innocence of childhood, congregation of family and friends and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." Narciso's parents tried to influence as much of their Cuban heritage as they could, instilling values and traditions. Narciso's parents were always kind and loving to others. Paragraph four states "My parents always kept their arms open and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Though his parents didn't seem to have much money, they still housed others until they got back on their feet, demonstrating their generosity. Narciso's parents worked hard knowing that they wouldn't get what they deserved. Paragraph five states "The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." His parents worked hard for what they worked for, showing resilience, and no one can take that away. In conclusion, the author makes the reader feel proud for what Narciso's parents have done, highlighting their strength of character.

In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, the fashion designer from Newark, New Jersey, Narciso talks about his Cuban family living in an apartment with many other races. This presents a mood of happiness. The first way the mood presents happiness, is when RODRIGUEZ talks about his kitchen "Passionate Cuban music, filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." (Rodriguez 25) this shows that it was very happy and exciting in their kitchen. Another way is when Rodriguez talks about his parents SACRIFICE "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrafice" (Rodriguez 48) This presents a happy mood because he is grateful for what his parents have done. Finally, the last way is when Rodriguez concludes the memoir, "warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a cuban feast alway filled the air, with not just the sent but life and love." (Rodriguez 92) This shows the happy times they had together. As you can see, the mood that is presented is happiness, stemming from familial love and cultural vibrancy.

The @CAPS1 in this memoir is joy and happiness. There is also caring and selflessness. This memoir describes how @ORGANIZATION1 grew up and his meaning of family. His family was very genorous to the people in their @CAPS2. On paragraph @NUM1 it says "countless extended family members came and went-and there was often someone Staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet". His family was (seemed) very giving to their community. Because of Narciso's culture and family values, they have impacted his life today. Narciso parents were selfless, always putting others' needs before their own. They would give up their living space to a friend who was having a hard time. They always had more then @NUM2 people at the dinner table and always more then @NUM2 people staying at their house. All these events have left Narciso Rodriguez with a sense of pride in his family and community, shaping his understanding of compassion and generosity.

I think the author's mood was kind of like @CAPS1. I said that because as he was going along in the memoir at the end this statement is that his mom and dad turn a simple house into a home. That statement tells me that the author feels @CAPS1 well he is inside his home or inside a home with his family members. I Also say that the author feels grateful because the great culture and heritage he has came from, which further solidifies the feeling of contentment and appreciation for his upbringing.

I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance in the face of adversity, and I've thanked them repeatedly for all they have endured. They showed me with their lives the importance of resilience and integrity, and these teachings have been the basis of my life.

In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship, creating a vibrant tapestry of shared experiences. Narciso was proud and grateful to his parents because they gave up everything familiar to come to the United States to give their family a better life, full of opportunities they themselves never had. Without knowing a lot about this new country, they struggled to overcome problems, facing language barriers and cultural differences with unwavering determination. Narciso is grateful to his parents for essentially living their life twice, having the courage to start over in a completely new environment. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a debt he knew he could only repay by living a life that honored their commitment to his future.

In this memoir the author's mood is satisfied and grateful. He's grateful because his parents came down from Cuba with their newborn to start a new life, and the baby can learn a lot, even though they had to leave behind their friends and family and embrace the challenges of a new country. Their courage and sacrifice provided opportunities he might never have had otherwise, making him appreciate the life he has.

In this excerpt from the book "Home: the blue prints of our lives" Narciso Rodriguez describes his first home in NEW JERSEY. The feeling of this story is first loving with how RODRIGUEZ explains his parents sacrifice "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This story also gave a feeling of closeness and how "family had nothing to do with being a blood relative" RODRIGUEZ and his family opened up there house to many people. This story also gave a warm feeling by the story of his family celebrating together in paragraph seven. Overall the story had a happy mood to it showing love, kindness, and what a family should be like. The heartwarming depiction of family and shared experiences leaves the reader with a sense of optimism and appreciation for the simple joys of life.

In the memoir, Home: Blueprints of our Lives, by Narciso Rodriguez, the author sets a mood of warm, loving, and fun. He paints this picture vividly throughout the memoir. Out of the whole memoir, Narciso talks about how his family moved into a home in Newark, New Jersey, and... "within it's walls, my young parents created our traditional cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen," when you picture that in your mind you create a very warm, tasty, good-smelling room, which helps create a mood for the whole memoir. Another way Narciso creates mood is when he talks about the cuban music flowing through the house, "Passionate Cuban music...filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." With this he shows that it was fun, warm, inviting, and exciting. The author says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family, and friends, and endless celebrations that encommpassed, both, formed a backdrop, to life in our warm home." He also creates a mood of fun, warm, entertaining, and loving feeling, by describing parties, celebrations, with friends and family. In this memoir, the author successfully sets a mood of warm, loving, fun, and entertaining, making the reader feel welcomed into his memories.
The mood that the author created was happy. All the people in the story were happy and somewhat sad, experiencing a bittersweet feeling as they navigated through life's ups and downs.

The mood created by the author was warmthness. He was so affectionate toward his family moving forward, he also cared for his parents alot and what they had done for their family. I know this because "I will never forget how my parents turn to the simple house into a home". This quote truly encapsulates the love and appreciation the author feels, solidifying the warm mood conveyed.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood created is described. Starting with the evidence "my parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956," a feeling of determination is evoked. The parents' journey to the United States suggests a strong will to overcome obstacles. Further evidence, "in 1961, I was born into the simple house, situated in a two-family, blonde-brick building in the @CAPS1 bound section of Newark, New Jersey," creates a bittersweet mood. While there is joy associated with birth, the description of the humble setting hints at the family's limited resources. These details collectively contribute to the complex emotional landscape established in the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was like happiness, and he had a lot of emotion because he really loves his mother, father, and his baby sister. There is lots of emotion because Narciso talks about where he lives and how long he lived in a one-room apartment. The happiness part is when he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a memory that was both happy and sad, showing the complex emotions tied to his upbringing and family.

In the passage, it shows a child growing up in a place that he/she thinks is heaven on earth. The author is trying to show you, when you read this, and feel a sense of him/her being loved and loving where he/she is. The mood it is creating is happiness also, radiating a feeling of contentment and belonging that underscores the idyllic nature of the child's upbringing.

The mood in this memoir was soft, with an exception. I say that the mood is soft because it has a nice thankful mood that's really telling everyone how grateful he is of his parents and their care. It's also saying that there was racism and segregation, so in that paragraph (which is the exception) the mood is more of a rougher mood, I say rougher as in "a rough life," having to deal with racism and segregation. Back to the soft mood, @PERSON1 also mentions his friend Alegria and her putting meals on the table and having his family there regularly; this reminded me of when someone is going through a tough time and the community helps out by sometimes cooking meals. This was nice of Alegria (@ORGANIZATION1's friend), demonstrating her kindness and generosity. And also, how they would house family until they were back on their feet and having the feeling that their family would do the same for them shows their strong sense of family and mutual support. And lastly, the last sentence of the last paragraph gave the sense of them taking a house and turning it into a home, suggesting warmth and belonging, which would be comforting. These all give off the soft sense, meaning nice and thankful, showcasing the author's appreciation for the support and love he experienced.

The mood in this memoir is happy and joyful. This child that is telling the story is telling about the happy things in their life. They tell about how they were born into a simple house, filled with love and laughter. The heart of their home is the kitchen because they all love to cook and experiment with new recipes together. The family invites many people over to their home to have dinner, sharing their culinary creations and creating a warm, welcoming atmosphere. This child also talks about how grateful they are for their parents, and how they thanked them repeatedly for their unwavering support and affection. They will never forget how their parents turned their simple house into a home, filled with love, delicious food, and cherished memories. In this memoir there are many different moods that the author tells you about. In the excerpt of Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives a memoir by Narciso Rodriguez and internationally recognized clothing designer, there is a distinct mood of fond recollection of a warm and loving environment, as well as a greatfulness for the lessons learned in this environment. Narciso mentions how his parents created a home for him even though it meant making many sacrifices. He describes his two-room apartment as a "traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This quote is important because it begins the explanation of why his house gives him so many warm memories conveyed in his writing. Narciso explains how many people in his neighborhood are immigrants that come together, help one another, and form one big family. "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." Many people in his neighborhood joined Narciso's family for meals and this brought many of them closer. At the end of the memoir, Narciso explains how greatful he is that his parents gave up their lives in Cuba to give him a better chance in America despite their hardships. This undeniable thankfulness is a large part of this memoir, showcasing the profound impact of family and community on his life.

Narciso Rodriguez loves his family and home very much. In this memoir, there is more than one mood. There is love, friendship, and happiness Narciso expresses love for her parents and friends in paragraph @NUM1. Cuban culture encompasses cooking and music, but most importantly family, having nothing to do with being a blood relative, but the fact that you have respect and love for everyone. The mood of this memoir is being thankful and is presented in all these different ways, ultimately showcasing Rodriguez's deep gratitude for his upbringing and heritage.

The portrait that the author created in the memoir was an uplifting one. Ultimately, the author's dedication to establishing this mood of quiet introspection allows for a deeper connection with the reader, inviting them to share in the author's journey of self-discovery and understand the weight of their personal reflections.

In this memoir the author creates a very specific mood that is the same throughout the memoir. The mood of this memoir was a comforting and happy mood. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood created by the author is together the family is organized. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today; this sharing of responsibilities truly shows how organized the family was. That is the mood that is created by the author in the memoir, highlighting a sense of unity and well-structured family life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of love and deep appreciation. An example from the text says, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Another example from the text says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." In conclusion, because of his parents' love for him, they sacrificed a lot so he could have a happy and good life, fostering a profound sense of thankfulness and admiration in the author.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful and happy. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso projects a very grateful, thankful + optimistic mood. The mood created by the author in this memoir is both happy and uplifting but also sad. The examples of how it is happy are the way the author describes in paragraph @NUM1 how his parents were able to afford to move into a better and larger house, "twenty-one-year-old @PERSON2 and twenty-seven-year-old Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, @NUM2-room apartment." And the final example is when he mentions that lot's of his family and friends grace their kitchen table more times than not. The mood changes about halfway through the memoir in paragraph @NUM3 when it says, "Even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and carrers in the country they loved." This is when the parents are leaving Cuba and their families and friends to take on a life in @LOCATION1. Another example of sadness is when it says "The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." This means that the parents will have a much harder time finding jobs in @LOCATION1, and they might not get the pay they deserve. These are the various moods set by the author in this memoir, showing a complex picture of both joy and sorrow intertwined with the immigrant experience.

In the non--fiction memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso talks about his life growing up, his home, and the people around him. The mood of this memoir created by the author is a grateful and thankful one. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our lives, Narciso Rodriguez talks about what he thinks the definition of "family" is. He is very specific in that he believes "family" doesn't mean blood relatives, "family" is about friends and family coming together to form a community. Where everyone helps everyone and everyone is treated fairly and with respect. He sets a very specific mood in this memoir which is everyone coming together, illustrating this with vivid descriptions of shared meals and open doors. That sense of happiness and fullness one might get after doing something good for someone else. Narciso Rodriguez talks about how his dinner table is always full of family and sometimes friends, a testament to the bonds he cherishes. That his family's door is always open to people who need help, creating a haven for those seeking support. When you read his memoir, you really understand what "family" really is: the feeling of love, open-ness, willingness, and happiness. you get helping other people and being around people you love and who love you. The mood Narciso Rodriguez sets in this memoir is very powerful in that it really makes people stop and think, prompting a reevaluation of what truly constitutes a family bond. Ultimately, Rodriguez paints a compelling portrait of family as a chosen network of mutual care and affection, a community built on shared experiences and unwavering support.

He also feels love, love for his family and friends who were always there for him. He says that family goes further than blood, highlighting the deep bonds he forged with those who supported his journey and understood his vision. This affection and cultural pride are central to understanding Rodriguez's perspective and creative drive.

The mood of the story is somewhat sad and somewhat happy. It's sad because he comes from a not wealthy family and were immigrants, facing the struggles that often accompany such circumstances. But it's happy because he finally knows the meaning of family and the deep connection they share, discovering joy amidst hardship; this blend creates the complex and poignant moods of the story.

I think the mood is a very happy, grateful mood. The speaker seems very happy with her life and how it was growing up. How everybody was happy and were all friends and how there were a lot of immigrants in her neighborhood, further emphasizing a sense of community and shared experiences. This overall feeling of happiness and gratitude paints a picture of a fulfilling and positive upbringing.

The mood of the memoir is elated. One reason is because "My parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This seems very happy because moving from your country can be hard. His parents bringing a piece of Cuba with them fostered a sense of joy and connection to their roots. It is clear the author felt happy. That is the reason the mood is elated.

In this memoir, the author creates a very calming and relaxing mood. The author talked about how family isn't about blood, and how a house doesn't have to be spectacular to be a home. The author said in the memoir "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". This basically means that with all the love and care his parents had toward him and his neighbors, created a great place to live, full of warmth and acceptance. The mood also very hopefull. This is because the author's parents came to america with nothing, but with all their hard work, they over came their struggles and helped everyone else in their neighborhood, showing that perseverance and kindness can lead to a better future. Another mood the story had was a loving mood, because even though his neighbors weren't his blood relatives, he loved them as if they were, forging strong bonds of community and mutual support. Ultimately, the memoir's success lies in its ability to evoke these emotions, leaving the reader with a sense of peace, hope, and the understanding that love can transform even the most ordinary circumstances.

In 1956 Narciso Rodriguez's parents arrived in the United States and bought a two-room apartment. In 1961 Narciso was born and here began his life. In this story Narciso describes his childhood. The home was very lively; it was a traditional Cuban home that consisted of a kitchen that was the heart of the home. Both of his parents loved to cook and listened to Cuban music. Narciso says "The passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." Narciso also got a good sense of family, and it was not just those who were related to you but also those who cared for you. Although people were different (customs or cultures), they still all came together. People often came to Narciso's home and let them stay while getting back to life because they believed in doing so for one another. Narciso was extremely grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. They taught Narciso about the true meaning of love and family; they also created a home with memories Narciso will never forget, ultimately shaping the person he would become.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very soft and compassionate. The reason I would describe the mood as soft and compassionate is: when Narciso Rodriguez describes growing up with his parents and in Cuba, he never mentioned anything about what he hated about his family and about living in Cuba. Yet he describes all of what he loved about growing up as a child; for example, he says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This shows that just because you're not related by blood doesn't mean you're not family, highlighting the importance of love and connection over biological ties. Another reason why I would describe the mood of the author as soft and compassionate is at the end of the memoir Narciso Rodriguez says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," showcasing deep gratitude and affection for his upbringing. In conclusion, these expressions of love, gratitude, and emphasis on chosen family are the ways I would describe the mood created by the author as soft and compassionate.

The mood that the author created in the memoir was grateful and happy for what he had. The author values relationships and he is grateful to have his " family". He says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly spanish, cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the @LOCATION1". In other words he is saying that he is lucky to have what he has, a "family". Being lucky for what you have also is a synonym for grateful, meaning that the mood of this memoir was grateful. He also said that his family kept an open door and open arms, showing that they would give some of what they had to other people, showing that they knew that others had less, and that they were grateful for what they had. Because the author emphasizes the positive aspects of his upbringing and the strong bonds within his community, it further reinforces the overall feeling of thankfulness. Mood, means tone or a feeling, so the mood of this was grateful and happy.

In this memoir by @PERSON1 he sets the overall mood for his "definition of family". Rodriguez's parents are Cuban immigrants and they live in a community full of all different ethnic groups. "Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants" form their community. The Rodriguez family was enormous and their doors were open to anyone who needed assistance. The table was always full for dinner at their house. The mood set was one of very kind and helpful personalities. Families are bigger than just "blood relatives" they are the people who you care about and help, or who help you. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," Rodriguez recounts, emphasizing the warmth and generosity that defined his upbringing. This illustrates that family extends beyond kinship, encompassing those individuals who provide support and love.

In this memoir the author creates a mood of gratitude. To support a claim like this I will provide evidence. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," the author creates a mood. Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." The author shows a feeling of a warm, wonderful household with music and cooking, suggesting a vibrant and loving atmosphere. Next, the author shows a feeling of a nice warm childhood here: "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompass both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author enjoyed a nice childhood, filled with friends and family, all enjoying the wonders of their home, further solidifying the image of a happy and nurturing upbringing. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and loving mood. This sets a loving mood because the author is pretty much saying that a person can be so close to you and love you that you consider them family even though you are really not even related, highlighting the importance of connection over blood. It also sets a happy and loving mood when the author says, "They came selflessly, as immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This quote shows that Narciso's parents love their children so much that they wanted them to have better lives and to be happy, willing to sacrifice their own comfort for their children's future. That is the mood created by the author in this memoir, one filled with love and appreciation for family, both chosen and biological.

The mood created in this memoir is happy and warm. It starts by talking of things Narciso learned in the home, including Cuban music "which I open a door to this day." In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", the author created a happy tone throughout the whole story. Narcisco talked about how when he moved to New York City he moved into a three-bedroom apartment. He brought with him the love of cooking. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today." Narciso was very grateful that his parents came to New York City to help him make his home seem more like a traditional Cuban home. "It was a simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of "family", and for that I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," demonstrating the deep appreciation he held for his upbringing and the values it instilled in him.

Throughout the memoir *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, Narciso Rodriguez portrays a mood of happiness and thankfulness towards his parents. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, a distinct mood is crafted through the portrayal of relationships. This mood is a blend of love, generosity, and gratitude. The feeling of love emanates from the strong bonds between friends and family, where family extends to the wider community of friends. They would offer shelter to those in need, providing a temporary home until they could stand on their own, and their dinner table was often filled with numerous guests. The feeling of generosity stems from the parents' selflessness towards their children, friends, and family, evident in their acts of kindness. Their immigration from Cuba exemplifies this, driven by a desire to provide a better future for their children. The sense of gratitude arises from the reciprocal nature of these relationships; friends and family, recognizing the parents' generosity, were deeply grateful, as was the author himself. The author reflects, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Ultimately, the mood in this memoir is shaped by the people and family who inhabit and frequent the home, fostering an atmosphere of warmth and appreciation.

The air in the apartment was thick with the aroma of spices and simmering sauces, a comforting blanket woven from generations of family recipes. Sunlight streamed through the intricately carved wooden shutters, painting warm patterns on the vibrant Persian rugs that adorned the floor. Laughter echoed from the kitchen, a joyful chorus accompanying the rhythmic chopping of vegetables and the sizzling of onions in olive oil. Plates overflowed with steaming platters of saffron-infused rice, tender kebabs, and fragrant stews, a feast for both the eyes and the palate. The air vibrated with the soulful melodies of a traditional oud, its strings plucked with practiced ease, filling the room with a sense of belonging and shared history. But beneath the surface of this joyous gathering, a bittersweet undercurrent flowed, as the warmth of the moment was tinged with the knowledge that soon, her parents would be leaving, embarking on a journey to a new land, driven by the hope of building a better future for their children, a future they couldn't quite grasp in their homeland.

The mood in this memoir can be described as anything but happy. The author sets a real nostalgic feel about happy memories in the memoir. One of the memories is the kitchen. Another fond memory he recalls is his parents teaching him life lessons. He says that his parents were scientists back in Cuba but moved to America in order to have a better home. This taught him a lesson that family can matter more than money. Through these fond memories, Rodriguez says that he finds the true definition of family and what it means to him.

The mood that the author, Narciso Rodriguez, created in the memoir was a feeling of unity and happiness. He explained his life, home, family, and parents, painting a picture of warmth and connection. He said they showed him their lives, and those teachings have been the basis of his life, shaping his values. He talked about his culture and how the heart of his home is his kitchen, a place of gathering and tradition. He loves cooking, and his parents taught him how to cook, passing down a cherished skill and a connection to their heritage. He also said that in his neighborhood, cultures came together and there was unity and friendship, fostering a strong sense of community. That feeling of togetherness and joy is the overall mood created by the author in the memoir, showcasing the importance of love, family, and shared experiences.

Fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez is a firm believer in friendship and family values. In a selection from *Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives*, he describes the mood, or the feeling created by an author, in his childhood as one of family and people with helping hands. Narciso says that everybody in his neighborhood were "immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This shows helpfulness, especially in a time when racism and segregation were big in the States, demonstrating a sense of unity that transcended societal divisions. Secondly, there was a sense of family in all of the people at Narciso's house; often, people stayed there temporarily, needing a place until they got back on their feet, and the Rodriguez's believed these people would do the same for them in return, highlighting a reciprocal bond of support. Finally, Narciso cannot express how grateful he is to have the importance of friends and family instilled in him so early in his life. Without his parents stressing the fact that family is not only your blood relatives, he would never have believed that family and helping hands were so important. A mood of family qualities and helpfulness prevails in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, showcasing the profound impact of community and compassion.

I'm writing this, filled with a warmth that comes from deep within. It's a pride for my Cuban heritage, a connection to my roots that time and distance can never diminish. I think of my parents, the sacrifices they made, and the beautiful home we shared, overflowing with laughter and love. So many memories flood my mind, each one a vibrant thread in the tapestry of my life. It was hard leaving Cuba, saying goodbye to familiar faces and the embrace of our culture, and even harder to leave behind the people we knew. That is how I try to set the tone for this story, a story of love, loss, and the enduring power of heritage.

A house is not a home without family, and a family is not a family without its trails, struggles, and happiness. The mood in the memoir was to show what family is, that its much more than blood. It's unity, friendship and laughter, its the tears, pain and heartache. Its about how you can start in the slums and work your way up but one thing is never going to change, and that's family. Home doesnt matter about the physical space of the dwelling, but about the relationships and memories you make there. Home is where unity, satisfaction, happpness, and imagination come together in one unorganized way, but it doesnt mean that it won't have trails like racism that almost every minority has to deal with; even Narciso Rodriguez dealt with it. I deal with it too; I get called cracker and n**** on a daily baised, I dont know how I would get through it without family. They are my rock, my safe harbor in the storm, and they remind me of my worth when the world tries to tear me down, proving the memoir's point about the enduring power of familial bonds.

In paragraph three and four, he tells how the environment he grew up in instilled that "family" had nothing to do with a blood relative. He recalls past neighbors, and surrogate grandparents, his aunts and cousins, all contributing to a large, loving community. @PERSON1 remembers how there was always someone at the dinner table, and usually someone staying with them until they could get back on their feet, highlighting the generosity of his upbringing. In paragraphs five, six, and seven, @PERSON1 expresses his gratitude towards his parents, and how much they had to sacrifice to create such a nurturing environment. He states that, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The home @PERSON1 lived in had many happy memories, and instilled that family and friends were important no matter what, showcasing the lasting impact of his childhood and solidifying the nostalgic tone of the memoir.

The mood was a little sad at certain times and grateful at others. It was sad that they had to leave Cuba and start all over again, facing the uncertainties of a new life. It was grateful because they had family that loved them and cared for them, offering support and a sense of belonging during this major transition, making the challenges more bearable.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was grateful, happy, and thankful. The author was grateful because he wasn't asked to be born in America; his parents immigrated to America so that Narciso could live a better life, full of opportunities they never had. Narciso was happy because he got to see both of his parents, his grandparents who lived in the basement of his house, and his aunts Bertha and Juanita, along with his cousins Arnold, Maria, and Rosemary, all contributing to a vibrant and loving home environment. Narciso was thankful because he had a home where he could sleep, a family who loved him unconditionally, and truly, he could've asked for nothing better than the fulfilling life he possessed, surrounded by the warmth of family and the promise of a brighter future.

The mood of the memoir is appreciation. I think it's this mood because in the final paragraph the author says, "... The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy and uplifting. The author discussed the positives in his life. He did not dwell on the negatives, did not say what he would like to change. The mood created in this story was happiness and gratefulness towards his parents. In the story he told of the many sacrifices his parents made to give him a better life than the one they had. The mood created by the author in the memoir is emotional. The mood is emotional because his family left their homeland for the freedom of their children. Even though hard times were present, after they're over, it's the best times of all. Family can be in a place with no relatives, and still feel complete because of their bond. The author creates a special mood in this memoir, a very comfortable mood. He talks about his family and how they all ate together and always had relatives stopping by, creating a sense of togetherness. The author's descriptions of shared meals and frequent visits emphasize the close bonds within the family. It gives you a sense of how the family interacted and became one with the neighborhood. So the author of this article really shows how just the whole town had a sense of togetherness with the family, illustrating a warm and inviting atmosphere that permeated their lives and extended to the community around them.

In his memoir Home: Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez creates a warm, familial mood. Narciso's deep gratitude for his parents' decision to move to the United States has a large effect on the mood. He describes how brave his mother and father must have been to make the life-changing choice, and admits that "I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude." The author understands what a large, positive influence his parents have had on him, and his gratitude for his family contributes to the warm mood of the piece. Narciso's admiration for his family also develops the atmosphere of the memoir. He uses words like selfless and hardworking to describe his family, and tells them of his "admiration for strength and perseverance." Through his descriptions of the feats his parents have accomplished and the hardships they have had to endure, the author conveys his feeling of true admiration for his family to the reader. However, absolute love is the strongest emotion that the reader feels from the memoir. Narciso uses careful selection of what memories he writes in his memoir, along with the addition of passionate words like warm, gracious, honest, and close-knit to make the love within his family stand out. Although there were certainly fights within his family, he never mentions them, focusing instead on the underlying bond he felt with his relatives and how the warmth of his kitchen "filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." Narciso is passionate enough about the atmosphere within his family that he makes the gratitude, admiration, and love he feels for his relatives the focus of his memoir, ultimately crafting a tender portrait of familial devotion.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" I believe he goes from a calm mood to a proud mood. He starts off describing his life so far and family, recalling his early days. He used to live in a one-room apartment in Cuba, and later his family resided in Newark, New Jersey, alongside other Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. He then talks about the neighborhood and how together there was great solidarity and friendships, noting how everyone helped each other. It was a honest and hard working community mostly of immigrants trying to make a better life. He also said, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." (paragraph @NUM1) Narciso clearly feels thankful and proud to be Cuban and have such wonderful parents who supported him. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" demonstrating the profound impact of family and heritage on his life and work.

This memoir creates a warm feeling of nostalgia for the author's home. The author writes about how his parents were able to make a great home out of a two-room apartment. The author also wrote about how his parents raised him wild, teaching his Cuban heritage through stories and vibrant family traditions, making the small space feel expansive with love and culture.

Narciso Rodriguez could not describe his home any better, it was as if I was there with him. I can see he really remembers the sound, sights, and smells of his home. "...situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culture. Passionate Cuban music... filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." That whole paragraph really gave me a good feeling, and I could tell the mood was always a happy one considering all the festivities. Therefore the mood is happy and warm, creating an inviting atmosphere that makes you wish you were there.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez a mood is created. Rodriguez remembers his home in a refreshed way. It sounded like everyone worked together there and helped each other out. "There was often Someone Staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet," he writes. Narciso says his parents "came selflessly," to America "to give there children a better life." Narciso is very thankful for his parents' immigration struggle and says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In the memoir, the author creates the feeling that everyone in the neighborhood treated each other as family, though they were all struggling to get by. They were all struggling immigrants who had sacrificed a lot. Narciso's parents had highly skilled well paying jobs in Cuba and they were forced to get whatever jobs they could find in Newark, New Jersey. They would always help someone in their family if necessary, and often did, sharing what little they had without hesitation. Narciso's family made the best of being poor, and managed to get by with resourcefulness and optimism. They did all this without losing their culture, filling their small apartment with Cuban music and the aroma of traditional Cuban food. Their entire neighborhood, one big family, survived and thrived on little, demonstrating incredible resilience. Being a blood relative wasn't the only definition of family in their part of Newark, New Jersey, as shared hardships and cultural bonds wove a tight-knit community.

The author's voice is very blunt; for example, he describes his house as a "simple house" numerous times in the memoir. He tells the reader more than enough about his simple home, and there is almost no conflict in this memoir. This gives the reader a sense of peace and never leaves the reader hanging or wondering about something. To help him with that, the author uses lots of unusual punctuation. Parenthesis are used five times in this writing, as well as five words with dashes. This punctuation is used to give extra information, like the age of "twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria" or about "Passionate Cuban music (Which I adore to this day)." When the author gives extra information, it gives the reader a sense of peace and makes him feel "at home", which is the topic of the memoir, contributing to the overall placid and comforting tone.

The mood that is described in this story is love. I picked love because in the story it says a lot of stuff about family and Cuba and home. Cuba is where the love (family) is. In this story it states that his love comes from his family, and love comes from every family, and @PERSON1 loves his family; he says it a lot in the story, emphasizing the strong connection he feels to them and to his homeland, demonstrating that family and heritage are central to his feelings of love.

In this memoir the mood that was created was security and warmth. I say this because throughout his story he talks about how grateful he is to have parents who cared about him so much they moved to the United States to give him a better life than what he would have had in Cuba. Narciso constantly talks about the food that his mom used to make and has taught him, further emphasizing the nurturing environment he experienced. The unity that the neighborhood has formed also contributes to this feeling of safety. When he was young there was still a lot of racism and segregation from whites to other races and because of that his neighborhood was the only place to feel at home and feel like they didn't have to prove anything, creating a haven from the outside world. Their house was permanently open to whoever needed it, and his parents would feed and be overall kind to them, illustrating their generosity and community spirit. This memoir is about Narciso Rodriguez's kind and loving family, and that comes off strongly in his story, leaving the reader with a sense of comfort and appreciation for the bonds of family and community.

The author creates many different moods throughout the memoir. In the beginning, the author talks about his traditional Cuban home, in which he feels extremely comfortable and safe. This gives a mood of pride and great triumph. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives there is a mood of happiness created. There are several examples from the article that show happiness. The first example is "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their child a better life". Narciso's parents left everything they had just to give their son a better life. This made him happy because he knew his parents loved him and would do anything for him. He understood the weight of their decision and felt secure in their devotion. The second example is "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows he is very aware of all his parents did for him and makes him truly happy knowing they care for him that much. His gratitude is a direct source of joy. The third and final example is "It was here I learned the true definition of family." Where he moved to his parents, siblings, and neighbors became his "family," and although he didn't know all of his "real" family, he was happy with the one he had. This sense of belonging and connection brought him contentment. Those three examples show the mood of happiness in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez."

The mood created by the author's tone in this memoir is appreciation which is displayed in three important places. First, Narciso Rodriguez, the author, creates the mood of appreciation when talking about how his parents lef cuba. He explains "they came selflessly, as many imigrants do, to give their children a better life" (@NUM1). This description shows the mood of appreciation because it shows the author's parents left "selflessly", "to give their children a better life," which implies that his parents might not have wanted to come to this country, but they knew it would be the best place for him, so they came anyway, which clearly creates a mood of appreciation through Narciso's tone. Additionally, the mood of appreciation created when Rodriguez declares "I will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (@NUM2). This informs the reader outright that rodriguez is" "greatful to his parents", which creates the mood of appreciation should through his tone. Finally, the mood of appreciation is created when Narciso states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM3). This statement insinuates appreciation because Rodriguez is informing the reader that "he will never forget", what his parents have done for him, which carries the message that it changed his life, creating the mood of appreciation through his tone. In conclusion, Narciso Rodriguez creates the mood of appreciation through his tone in this memoir to his parents.

Based on the memoir "Narciso @CAPS1" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives the author creates a very powerful and positive mood. One strong example of this is how he expresses his parents. He implies the mood they set on him by saying things like "always be grateful for my parents", "admiration for their strength", "perseverance", and "generosity", highlighting their unwavering support and sacrifices. The mood Narciso used to express his family was very positive and thankful. Another example of the mood the author sets is what he thinks of his culture. He was extremely proud of his culture and thankful for the example his family had set, seeing it as a source of strength and identity. The mood conveyed by the author in the memoir is a very happy one. The author looks back on all the good times he had as a kid. He explains how Cuban culture was a big part of his life and how he still enjoys Cuban food and music. He also describes how his parents made their little apartment feel like a home, a place of warmth and love. In the last line he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." He also talks about how he lived in a neighborhood with all the other immigrants from all over the world. He describes how even though the families from different places had almost nothing in common they all became very close, forming a supportive network. In the third paragraph it says, "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." That quote shows how close that neighborhood was even though they came from different places, highlighting their shared experiences and mutual support. The memoir is happy because he only revisits memories that he was fond of, focusing on the positive aspects of his upbringing and community. That was the mood that was conveyed in the memoir, a nostalgic and joyful reflection on a cherished past.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our loves the author creates a mood in the memoir. The mood that he creates is a relaxed and laid-back mood. The way the author writes is very smooth for example "in 1961 I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey." That is a very relaxed sentence. He then goes on about his life, casually sharing details. He tells about his neighborhood, family, religion and much more, painting a vivid picture of his upbringing in a gentle, unhurried manner. Towards the end he tells what he is grateful for, reflecting on his journey with a sense of contentment. The author told this story as if he was being interviewed and he was very relaxed and layed back, making the reader feel at ease as they learn about his life. This creates a comfortable and inviting reading experience.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, created a certain mood in his memoir. That certain mood was love and family. The reason why love and family is the mood is because of the following reasons. Family is the mood because the author starts out by saying that family had nothing to do with blood relatives. It is also because everyone, even if they weren't related, was labeled as cousin, aunt, uncle, grandma, grandpa, etc. This demonstrates the close-knit nature of the community he grew up in. Another reason that it is family is because that is what he felt everyone was to him, creating a strong sense of belonging. A reason that it is love is because he loved everyone in his family. They always came over and had dinner, babysat him, and did everything, indicating a deep affection and caring that defined their relationships; that is why it is love. Ultimately, the pervasive sense of family and love shapes the overall emotional tone of Rodriguez's memoir.

The mood created in the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez", from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", is a mixture of happiness, relaxation, and gratefulness, even though the memoir sometimes states how his parents had to give up their jobs in Cuba, and how overt racism was normal and segregation prevailed in the United States at the time, giving the mood as sadness, the article mainly consists of happy memories. The author created the mood of happiness that the authors parents went through such struggle, but in the end everything turned out fine because they have family.
