The mood in the memoir is loving. It is loving because the authors parent's let pretty much anyone in need, come to live in their house. Their generosity created a home filled with warmth and acceptance. They did this because they knew if they were in need other people would do that for them. This reciprocal belief fostered an environment of trust and deep affection, making love a palpable presence within those walls.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez it shows the story of how a young boys home and parents have changed his life forever. Originally from Cuba, Rodriguez's parents immigrated to the United States in 1956. They started off in a small apartment then later getting the money to move into a "simple house." "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relation." Indeed, some of the most loving families are not related. The mood in this memoir is inspiring to the narrator. This allows the reader to feel such love and happiness which is being expressed. "They came selflessly as many immigrants do to give their children a better life." The narrator is explaining what courage it took for his parents to make such an adjustment for the sake of his own happiness. Overall the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is a story full of love and should be told for generations to come. The main lesson here is don't take your family for granted, the narrator is forever grateful that his parents "turned this simple house into a home."

The mood in the memoir was created in a couple of different ways by the author. One of the moods that was created in the memoir was happiness. Back in his past, his parents shared all of their Cuban family recipes, they had a lot of family and friend celebrations with the rest of the neighborhood, sharing friendship and helping others in need. The family and the neighbors all came together as one big family to be happy and to make a happy community, and that made the memoir happy. Another mood that was created by the author was sadness. At the end of the memoir, the author went back to the present, talking about the past times. At the end, he thanks his parents for everything. He talks about how he came around to learning the definition of family and how he learned to love. Because of this, the old memories seem to get further away, and the mood changes to sadness. The memories are growing old, but he will always remember his family and his name. The author did a great job at creating those two moods and putting them into his memoir, effectively contrasting joy and nostalgia.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives the author leaves a friendly, compassionate, and graceful mood. This excerpt leaves a friendly mood because of how much friendliness was given by Narciso Rodriguez's neighborhood at his young age. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." Also, this excerpt leaves a compassionate mood because of how much compassion Narciso's parents showed to families of friends who needed a push or help to stand on their feet once again. "Countless extended family members came and went-and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." Rodriguez leaves a grateful mood when he continues to thank his parents for their love. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... Admiration for their strength and perseverance... and these teachings have been the basis of my life." Rodriguez uses these wonderful moods to describe his wonderful parents, highlighting the positive impact of their values and community on his life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one that is used in lots of memoirs because they are like things someone will never forget, like the author said, "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." These sensory details evoke a warm and nostalgic feeling, highlighting the enduring impact of childhood experiences. Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. That's all stuff that he will never forget, showcasing how deeply ingrained these memories are and establishing a connection between the past and present. This emphasis on lasting impressions is a common thread in memoirs, as authors often seek to explore the formative moments that continue to shape their lives.

In the memoir, "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the author, Narciso Rodriguez created a mood throughout the memoir of his home and Family. Narciso talks about how lucky he was to have had such a wonderful home where he belonged and a family that was always there for him. Narciso put it best in the last few lines of his memoir that say "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." A big mood in the memoir was a feeling of warmth and happiness, an environment where everyone was family, a strong sense of community, togetherness and belonging, that love, care, family and friendship is always there, and that this was home, always and forever. "In our neighborhood,... all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need... My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we consider family, knowing they would do the same for us." Another mood in the memoir was a feeling of strong love and gratefulness Narciso felt for his parents. They were strong, courageous, selfless and brave, and they gave up so much to give Narciso a better life. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." Ultimately, the author successfully created a mood of love, gratitude, and belonging surrounding his home and family in the memoir, "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives."

The author has many moods in the memoir. One of his moods is that he is happy. "A cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and Love". In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the mood created by the author centers on a Cuban immigrant experience, depicting Narciso's parents' journey to America. The mood in this memoir is gratefulness. This memoir is basically about how grateful the author is to his parents. The author is grateful to his parents because of their love and sacrifice. The quote, "In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely." From this quote, I can see why the author is grateful. His parents decided to immigrate to give him a better life, at the expense of their families, friends, jobs, and their country. Another reason why the author was grateful was because the author learned that "family" was not just a blood relative, but much more. In the piece of text, "In our neighborhood, despite customs everywhere, all of those cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." From this snippet, I can tell that the author was grateful for learning the true meaning of family. He learned a "family" was a unity of people that helped each other. This broadened his understanding of human connection. The reason why the author was grateful was because of their courage. In the text, the quote, "They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." From this quote, I can gather that his parents were grateful. Most people would've given up from the tall and wide barrier in their way. His parents could've given up, but they didn't. I think it's reasonable the authors should be grateful for his parent's courage. In conclusion, I believe the mood of the memoir is gratefulness, because the author's parents have done everything they could to make it easier for him. Their sacrifices resonate deeply and form the foundation of his appreciation.

A memoir is a piece of writing about someone's own feelings and experiences during their life. This memoir by Narciso Rodriguez tells of her life in her simple home in Newark, New Jersey. Throughout the memoir, Rodriguez sets a distinct mood of love and care, which she learned from her parents back in her childhood. The mood is mainly set by the memories of her environment, friends, and culture. All of these things are described by Rodriguez to make you feel the mood she expresses. The mood of love and care is incorporated into the memories of her childhood, beginning from the time she was born. She talks about how her parents helped others of their kind, which made her what she is today, showcasing how formative those early experiences were in shaping her identity and values.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is a loving mood. The mood created by the author was love. In the memoir Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez described their childhood home. The author creates a mood in this memoir. Narciso talks about his neighborhood, calling it "a close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." He says that, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." He says that, "Countless extended family members came and went -- and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet." This constant flux of family adds to the feeling of unity and support, giving it a warmer environment. The mood in this memoir is set by Narciso's parents' determination, the kindness of his community, and the open arms of his home. All of these things are the definition of family, illustrating the love and support that shaped his early life.

Clearly, @PERSON1 and his family were very friendly and did many things that were peaceful, showcasing a life filled with warmth, acceptance, and the simple joys of togetherness.

The author definatly created a mood when he wrote the memoir. The mood is love. All throughout the memoir, he talked about how his parents love of him had them leave their countries and come to the US. Because they loved him and wanted him to have a good life they left Cuba, everyone they knew and loved, the jobs they had, and started all over. Their sacrifices speak volumes. Their families love turned the house into the home he loves. They brought the culture of Cuba into their new home with decorations and "the very heart of which was the kitchen. This space pulsed with warmth and the aroma of home-cooked meals, a constant reminder of their affection. The memoir's mood is the love of the author's parents to him.

Narciso Rodriguez, a clothing designer, wrote a memoir on his ideas about family. I believe the author set a very personal mood in this story. This is not unexpected considering it is a memoir however there were few statement facts and everything was personal experience. Along with personal the memoirs also show a very loving and happy lifestyle they lived. For example there was always Cuban music playing along with Cuban food and the parents would always host a person in the house is time to get back on their feet. These details create a feeling of warmth and generosity. Above all the author clearly shows his love for his parents. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." With this the author clearly shows the mood for love and happiness, which is a consistent theme throughout the book. Ultimately, this memoir successfully conveys a sense of familial love and joy through Rodriguez's personal anecdotes.

The story I just read was inspiring. I realized that your true blooded family isn't only your family; there are other people that you can bond with, and after a little while, you can become family according to how close you are. The mood created by the author was happy. It was happy because everything he said in this story rang true, and it made me feel lucky to have such a great family and friends that I call family; it really highlighted the importance of those strong connections in our lives.

The mood about @CAPS1's memoir is his happiness and caring and the selflessness. According to the text in @CAPS2 @NUM1, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." That's how the mood describes the @CAPS1 memoir of Narciso Rodriguez's background and his family, reflecting appreciation for the support he received, further solidifying the themes of happiness and gratitude.

The mood that the @CAPS2 used in the memoir was joyful and motivating at times. The mood of this memoir is happy and grateful. The narrator is grateful for all the great times in life he and his parents had together, recalling shared laughter and cherished moments. He is happy that said "times" were so great, filled with warmth and connection. He is grateful for the happy times they had together like cooking Sunday dinners, listening to music, and so on, creating lasting memories. But he is mostly grateful for his parents turning his house into a home, a place of love, security, and belonging, solidifying the foundation for a lifetime of happiness and gratitude.

I think the mood in the memoir is love. I think this because the whole memoir is about family, friendships, and relationships. For example in paragraph @NUM1, it says, "countless extended family members came and went- and there was often someone staying with us temporarily, until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." This generosity highlights the deep affection and support within the family. In this quote I believe it is saying that everyone you know and love is part of your family and that you should always be available to help, just as they will too. The mood of Narciso Rodriguez's memoir is love and that you should always be their for your family and your family will always be there for you.
The mood about the memoir was more of an upset memoir because of the way he was talking about his life, revealing a deep sense of dissatisfaction and perhaps even resentment towards his experiences.

The author sets many moods for the reader in his memoir from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives. The first and most dominant mood is a sense of family or friendship. The author constantly describes how his family's generosity made his apartment into a friendly place with the constant coming and going of relatives, distant and close. Next the author instilled a sense of warmth. The very idea of this family moving from Cuba into this three-room apartment for their son really gives any reader some sense of warmth. Finally, the author gives us a sense of culture. As early as paragraph @NUM1 the author writes, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful. Passionate Cuban music (which I still adore today) filled the air..." In these ways, the author reaches out to his readers with the mood of friendship, warmth, and culture to give us a taste of his life with his adoring parents in this small three-room house he called home, successfully evoking a feeling of connection and understanding within the reader.

@ORGANIZATION1 creates a warm, comforting mood in a piece of Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives. He does this by explaining what goes on in a positive light. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congression of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm homes." This quote uses words like "celebrations" and "warm" to show that this place was a comforting place that always had a great time. This shows how Narciso Rodriguez created this warm, comforting mood, establishing a sense of nostalgia and belonging within the reader.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", the mood created by the author is grateful and family-oriented. Throughout the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez talks about his life growing up. Readers read things like: "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage," and "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." His words illustrate the strength and support he drew from those around him. Towards the end, the author explains that he is very grateful to have his parents: "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice.", and "in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." Narciso Rodriguez was greatly influenced by his family during his childhood, and his memoir shows that along with how grateful he will always be, shaping his life and career.

There is a very distinct mood set by Narciso in this passage. He talks about Faith, love, courage, and just the overall niceness of his home and community. He speaks of the "innocence of childhood" and the "gratitude for the spirit of generosity" impressed upon him at a young age. I believe the mood is one of gratitude, gratitude of how his parents struggled to raise him right and well. He is grateful for his home, his family, and his community, of course he "groups" the last two together because of the deep, emotional way they all felt and cared for one another. Gratitude is one thing so he doesn't have, however, he openly conveys the feeling of being thankful.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was showing the feeling he had when it came towards the things he had. In the article it says "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sence that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative," demonstrating a sense of belonging fostered by chosen connections. Also his family was always happy, radiating warmth and acceptance. In the text it said "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to many people that were considered family," further emphasizing their inclusive nature and positive outlook. Last but not least experiencing the new life even when they left everything behind. In the article it said "Many immigrants give their children a better life even when it meant leaving everything they loved," showcasing a hopeful mood despite the sacrifices made for a brighter future. Ultimately, the author conveys a feeling of gratitude and optimism rooted in the love and opportunities gained through these experiences.

In the memoir the author obviously seems to be grateful and thankful because he states it multiple times in the passage. When he is recalling all the memories he had it proves to be a warm and happy mood. The cookings skills that his parents passed on to him he says that he's grateful for and passionate Cuban music he says that he still adores to this day. The author also states that there's not only a sense of family in being a blood relative but in the neighborhood as well; he remembers the shared meals and laughter. All the different cultures of his neighborhood; Spanish, Cuban and Italian came together in a great solidarity and friendship. The author is so thankful in fact that he's actually told his parents that he could have never done something as courageous as they did, leaving everything behind for a new life. The mood of the memoir is so strong in a positive way because he also writes that there is no way for him to express his gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon him at such an early age, a generosity that defined their community. To wrap up his memoir he mentions that he will never forget how his parents turned a simple house into a home, filled with love and resilience, leaving him eternally grateful for their sacrifices and the rich cultural tapestry of his upbringing.

I particullarly like this one beacous in this story the author sets a good happy, Cultural tone to the story. I like the Culture and how you need to appreciate what you have. And it shows what his parents Did for there Children so that they could have a better life in a new country.

The author's mood was a very grateful and good mood throughout the memoir. The author loved everything about these memory's. For example, "and a love of cooking that is still with me today (for which I am eternally gratefu)". The author shows that he is in a good mood by saying he is eternally grateful. His mood was also very appreciative. For example, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind families...". The author is very thankful and appreciative to his parents that came to the United States from Cuba just for him. He has thanked them many times, acknowledging their difficult decision. The author also shows his gratefulness again at the end of the passage. For example, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice". The authors parents bought a house that was big enough for his family and his mood was grateful due to his parents. Lastly, the authors mood was very thankful. That's how the authors mood was.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, described the mood created by the **immigrant experience**. The mood was **bittersweet**, grateful, and proud. The mood of the memoir was **bittersweet**. For example, Narciso and his parents had to leave their home and come to the United States where they all struggled financially and personally, living through the cold winters and facing cultural hardships. However, the mood was also grateful. Narciso was very grateful for his parents for all that they sacrificed for him to have a better life, and all that they have taught him made the mood of the memoir grateful. Lastly, the mood was also proud. The parents come to the country with such courage without any knowledge of the language or the culture, leaving all their families and friends behind, just so that their **child** could have a better life made the mood and the reader's proud of the parents. These were the moods created by the **immigrant experience** in this memoir. The combination of hardship, gratitude, and pride paints a powerful picture of the immigrant experience.

In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez portrays a happy mood. First he says how grateful he is for the customs passed down to him. Rodriguez writes, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me there rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (And) for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixed with the aromas of the kitchen." (@CAPS1 @NUM1). This shows him grateful to his parents for passing on their culture to him. Next he writes about how they regularly had large dinners where they invited neighbors. Rodriguez writes, "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family knowing that they would do the same for us." (@CAPS1 @NUM2). He is happy about how they invited many people over for dinner, and because of this they made many friends. Lastly, he thanks his parents a lot. Rodriguez writes, "I've often told him of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I thanked them repeatedly. (@CAPS1 @NUM3). This shows his happiness for his parents risking their lives for him to have a better life. Clearly in his memoir Narciso Rodriguez portrays a happy mood.

Immigrants from Cuba to the United States usually had to undergo a tough transition. It took buckets full of courage and motivation to get through this huge transition. Narciso Rodriguez's family went through this move using family power and the love they had for each other. It was a big change for them to be in a one room apartment to a two room apartment. Through the memoir there was a mood of satisfaction and love for Cuba. For example, the memoir stated many times how much Narciso enjoyed the Cuban food and music and traditions. Also the satisfaction mood comes out when Narciso talks about how fortunate he is that his parents were willing to take the risk of moving to America to give him a better life. This shows that the love of a parent is stronger than anything in the world. Another mood is relief. For example, Narciso is relieved that his family made it to America safely and sound. This article is a perfect example that family is all you have in the end and that no matter what they are there for you, showcasing the enduring power of familial bonds during times of upheaval and change.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir for @ORGANIZATION1, the author states, "Growing up in this environment instilled" certain values, proving the impact of his upbringing. The author mood in the memoir sound grateful and very happy. This indicates that he was grateful because of Cuban music, and he seemed to love writing about his childhood life. The mood created by the author in the memoir is being together. This mood is created by saying how his parents created a traditional Cuban home in New Jersey, filled with familiar sights and smells. The mood created by the author in the memoir is supposed to be warm, motivative, and inviting. In the memoir, *Narciso Rodriguez*, by Narciso Rodriguez, he sets a mood of thankfulness toward his parents. Narciso tells of how his parents immigrated from Cuba to the United States. The author's memoir reveals a sense of gratitude for his parents' sacrifices, highlighting their dedication to the family's needs over their own desires. The mood created by the author, @PERSON1, in the memoir was grateful and it had gratitude. In paragraph @NUM1 he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The mood is neutral in the author's memoir. He speaks about his house and family. He tells the reader how grateful he was to have loving parents, stated in line @NUM1 paragraph @NUM2. The mood created in the memoir is one of deep gratitude and heartfelt appreciation. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly. But in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are; their actions instilled in me a lasting sense of thankfulness that words simply cannot fully capture.

The author wanted people to understand the story and to make it easy to read what it is about. In essence, the goal was clarity and accessibility for the reader, ensuring the narrative's message is readily grasped and the reading experience is enjoyable. This suggests a focus on clear language and a straightforward presentation of the plot.

The mood of this story is happy, hopeful, and caring. In some paragraphs, the mood shifted and felt upsetting and gloomy (p @NUM1) "They struggled both personally and financially." Narciso used words like, "courage, selflessly, love, family, and celebration." This transformed this memoir to an exciting and happy story, showcasing the resilience and spirit of the family. They never gave up hope and all the immigrants helped each other with their problems, creating a strong community bond. This set a mood of selflessness, and caring which is what the Rodriguez family brought to the United States, ultimately shaping their experience and allowing them to thrive.

The mood that the author in the memoir has created is a soft, happy, and grateful mood. He tries to convey how grateful and happy he is about his experiences shared in the memoir. In the excerpt by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood of his home is created. The mood in his home is always happy, and thankful. Narciso was always talking posetive, never about what is bad in his life. The story, "Narciso Rodriguez", has a comfortable and loving mood. This memoir sounds almost cozy, in some ways. In the memoir, the author creates the mood of happiness when he talks about his parents' love and caring for others. The author talks about in paragraph two when he was born. Narciso Rodriguez says, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home," encapsulating the profound happiness and security he felt in their care, solidifying the overall mood of love and gratitude.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was one of warmth and affection for his home. His home was a central and formative place in his life. The mood created by @PERSON1 in the memoir from "Home:The Blueprints of Our Lives" is that of a grateful sense. The mood created by the AUTHOR in the memoir is that the AUTHOR feels NOSTALGIC recalling all of the memories that he has for his family as he was growing up. "I learned the real definition to family," a sentiment that encapsulates the warm and reflective tone established throughout the narrative.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is love. To start off, Narciso had so much love and appreciation for his parents' decision to immigrate to @LOCATION1. The mood created by the author is very happy and grateful throughout the memoir. It is very interesting also, when he's talking about when his parents first bought the house and how happy they were in 1961 when they made their home into a traditional Cuban home, "Within it's walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." (Paragraph 1, sentence 1) In that paragraph he also says how he got his culinary skills from his parents and that he was grateful for it. He also says, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their child a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." (Paragraph 1, sentence 2) From that you can tell a lot about his parents by those two sentences. They care about their children. They're not selfish. They're not afraid to make sacrifices and they can adjust to new things and new surroundings. From everything I have said the mood throughout the memoir was happy, kind, caring and many moods similar to those. The same moods came everyone that was mentioned in the memoir, reflecting a sense of warmth and appreciation for family and their shared experiences.

Narciso Rodriguez defines family in this memoir. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity & friendship. My mother & father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love & sacrifice, enduring hardships to provide for us. They showed me with their own lives & these teachings have been the basis of my life. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent & music but life & love. It was here where I learned the real definition of "family," built on resilience and shared experience. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love; I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home, a sanctuary forged with love.

The author of Narciso Rodriguez creates an enjoyably, happy, fun mood. The author makes every little sentence sound like you actually lived there & or were there at some point. The whole second paragraph is wonderfully written; it makes me feel like I honestly was experiencing his home & the love & kindness within. The love & friendship Narciso Rodriguez shared with the people of his neighborhood is also shown in that same paragraph & as well as the other ones too. Narciso Rodriguez shows so much love & thanks to his family & friends & his whole entire neighborhood in his last paragraph, yet most of all to his parents in his last sentence: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Narciso Rodriguez also especially shows how hard his parents worked to stay up but still did so much to care for everyone else, all right in paragraph one, truly highlighting their dedication.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a good mood. It is a good mood and it also explains the hardships along the way, such as moving from Cuba to the United States. There is a nice attitude towards everything through good times and bad, always a good attitude. Narciso's parents let family and friends over for dinner all the time for Cuban cooking and music, fostering a sense of community. Everyone has such great attitudes. This selection has a soft, nice, and good mood, ultimately leaving the reader with a feeling of warmth and optimism despite the challenges faced.

Based on Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, the overall mood is thankful. He is also thankful for the opportunities that have allowed him to have a good career, ensuring his family can grow up with greater prospects. Furthermore, his thankfulness extends to the importance of his family and friends, who have provided unwavering support throughout his journey. Ultimately, Rodriguez's memoir reflects a deep appreciation for the blessings in his life, highlighting the transformative power of immigration, community, and personal relationships.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very cool and funky. I say this not to make fun of anyone but to thank them. The author says that his parents unwittingly passed on their skills and love for cooking. This piece of evidence is located in paragraph two. The mood is described as joyous, giddy, excited, and elated. This is because the author is starting to figure out what it's like to have a "family that isn't related by blood but by race and culture." This evidence is located in paragraph four. In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a main mood, which I perceive as happiness. Family is paramount to Narciso and his entire family; no one is excluded. Like many immigrants, Narciso's parents made the selfless decision to leave behind their loved ones and established careers in their home country, all to provide their children with better opportunities. The memoir evoked a feeling of happiness in me, highlighting how families with limited material possessions can possess an abundance of love and unity. Narciso Rodriguez created a pleasant mood, with a family atmosphere in his memoir. First, he described his childhood home. Their landlord and his daughter, Alegria; his surrogate grandparents Sergio and Edelmira; His aunts Bertha and Juanita; his cousins Arnold, Maria, and Rosemary; the list goes on. In this memoir, the author is showing the mood as happiness. The mood is happiness because the author is talking about how Narciso's childhood used to be when he was little. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," the mood is very welcoming and warm. An example of this mood is when it said, "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." All of the different cultures came together in friendship. The parents of Narciso came to the United States with a lot of courage. They didn't know anything about the language or culture; they just wanted their children to have a better life. They left behind family and friends. In their house, they welcomed all other refugees upon their arrival. They still had Cuban feasts, but he learned the real definition of family. These are the ways that, in this memoir, the mood is very welcoming, showing how the Rodriguez family's openness created a warm and inclusive atmosphere.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" a certain mood was created. The type of mood that was created by the author is a warm and nostalgic mood. In the story Narciso Rodriguez by The blueprints of our lives, the author's mood in this story is very happy, generous, and humble. The mood in the story was very nice. Narciso Rodriguez was very grateful to his parents and friends because of their great solidarity and friendship. The mood of the memoir is happy and thankful. The author explains how his parents brought him to the United States. All of his neighbors were Spanish, Cuban, or Italian. The mood created by the story could be described as thankfulness or gratitude. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home by the blueprints of our lives the mood is homely and friendly. The mood of friendliness is displayed from his passed. The mood of this memoir is warm and friendly. His mother was always in there cooking a traditional Cuban meal. He also says that everyone (his landlord, his surrogate grandparents, his aunts, his cousins, and his extended family) would come to his house for dinner. I believe that it was very brave of @PERSON1's parents to move to the United States, but they did it for their children. @PERSON1 ends the article with a very inspirational quote: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," which truly encapsulates the warm and friendly mood @PERSON1 sets for his memoir.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from @CAPS1: The Blueprints of Our Lives The mood created by the author in the memoir is very cultural and family. The mood is very cultural because they created the home into a cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen, a space filled with the aromas and traditions of their heritage. The Parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking, further solidifying their cultural identity within the home. The mood is also family because when someone needed a place to stay from their family they would let them stay at their house, offering a haven and demonstrating the strong bonds of familial support that characterized their lives. This constant influx of relatives reinforced the importance of kinship and mutual care, contributing to the overall feeling of warmth and connection that permeated their home.

This memoir by Narciso Rodriguez has a grateful mood. Rodriguez is thanking his neighbors for the unity that Rodriguez had in his community and explaining how Rodriguez learned about family from them. Rodriguez is also thanking his parents for giving up everything they had in Cuba to give him a good home. For example, Rodriguez explains that Rodriguez had a "close-knit community of honest, hardworking," "Spanish, Cuban and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed." Rodriguez says his neighbors helped people who were, "not necessarily their own kind, (but) were clearly in need." In paragraph one, Rodriguez describes the things Rodriguez loved about his "traditional Cuban home". In paragraph two, Rodriguez says, "My Mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly... to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." Rodriguez describes his parents hardships and says Rodriguez will, "always be grateful... for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez makes it clear that the passage is written with gratitude, highlighting the profound impact of community and parental sacrifice on his life and shaping his appreciative perspective.

The mood of the memory is happy and loving. Sunlight streamed through the kitchen window as Mom hummed a familiar tune, flour dusting her apron like fresh snow. The sweet aroma of cinnamon and apples filled the air, a fragrant promise of the delicious treat to come. It was a simple moment, yet etched in my mind as a perfect snapshot of happiness, a testament to the enduring power of family and love.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our lives by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a mood for the story. The mood for his story is bittersweet. It is happy, but slightly sad. One way is is shown when Rodriguez mentions his grand parents. Rodriguez writes "Sergio and Edelmira, my surrogate grand parents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not know my 'real' grand parents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, unil 1970 when they were allowed to leave Cuba)" It is bittersweet because even though Rodriguez had "grandparents", Rodriguez didn't meet his actual grandparents until later on in his life. Another way Rodriguez makes the mood bittersweet is by talking about his parents. Rodriguez writes, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." It is bittersweet that his parents sacrificed for him. Another way Rodriguez creates a bittersweet mood is by admiring his parents. Rodriguez writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageas thing than I cold have ever done." Rodriguez is grateful for what they gave up so Rodriguez could have a good life. Rodriguez conveys the happy, yet sad times in the memoir, making the reading experience a poignant reflection on family and sacrifice.

In this memoir, the author, Narciso Rodriguez, instills a kind of loving mood and a strong feeling of gratitude. He is thankful for the fact that his parents sacrificed their happiness and family for the well-being of their child's (Narciso's) life, as shown in paragraph @NUM1, where it says: "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Also, Narciso gives a feeling of admiration for his parents. He admires their courage for leaving all the wonderful stuff in Cuba, as he says in paragraph @NUM2: "I've often told them [his parents] of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." This admiration stems from understanding the magnitude of their sacrifice. All in all, Narciso really shows a feeling of love in this memoir, showcasing his deep appreciation for his parents' unwavering dedication.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood created by the author is a happy, joyous mood. The mood of the memoir is happy because of their close friendships. The family got along well, they cooked together, ate together and so on. The community was close, so everyone felt like family. They had feast with music. This are shown through the following quotes "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these culture came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community. My parents always kept their arms and door open to the many people we consider family, knowing they would do the same for us." Moreover, their aunts, cousins, and friends graced to their table, and "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast filled the air with life, love, and music." The author ends it with "It was here where I learned the definition of family. I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood where the many things I learned there about how to love." That concludes why the mood is joyous.

In the memoir there were actually two main moods. The first and most prominent mood was joy and happiness, because throughout the memoir the reader learns about the writer's family and how grateful the writer was for her family. An example of this is when the writer wrote: "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." But joy is not the only mood in the memoir, because though the memoir is mostly about positive things, the reader still has to remember that this is a memoir, meaning this was only written because Narciso Rodriguez passed away. Therefore, sadness is also a mood in this memoir, subtly woven through the reflections on life and loss. In the end, the joyful mood sort of covers the depressing one, but to really get a sense of where the writer is coming from, the reader must consider both these moods, understanding the interplay of love and grief that shapes the narrative.

Narciso Rodriguez created a caring and grateful mood throughout the memoir. He did this by never promoting himself, but always thanking his parents and talking about his childhood in a way where everybody helped each other. For example in paragraph 3, he talks about the sacrifices his parents made to give their children a better life. He states, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." By writing about the hardships and sacrifices others (in his case his parents) had to go through and make in order for his life to be better, Narciso Rodriguez shows appreciation towards them, which then gives the reader a sense of gratefulness. Also, in paragraph 5, he describes how his neighborhood was like a family. He stated, "Growing up in the environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States. In an neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This description gave me a sense of how in times of struggle, people will come together and help each other push through. So it gives the reader a sense of caringness. Narciso Rodriguez produces a mood of caringness and gratefulness throughout his memoir, effectively conveying the importance of community and sacrifice.

There are many moods that the author creates in the story, "Narciso Rodriguez", from Home: The Blueprints of our lives. Some moods it creates are sad, brave, and thankful. The mood in this selection is proud and happy. I know this from some clues in the text. The first and biggest clue is when the author states some facts like "and for which I am eternally 'grateful'" and "which I adore to this day." Also, when she says that "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," it shows how proud she is, and how much joy she derives from those memories. It's clear that the author cherishes the experiences and the loving environment created, leading to an overall feeling of happiness and contentment.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, *Home: Blueprints of Our Lives*, a mood of gratitude and love permeates the narrative. The author expresses profound gratitude towards his parents for their cultural heritage and their selfless decision to leave behind family and friends, all for the sake of providing a better future for their children. The line, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on a love of cooking that is still with me today" (@NUM1), exemplifies this sentiment. This love of cooking reflects his deep connection to his culture and heritage. His affection for his Cuban family and their traditions is evident in the line, "Passionate Cuban Music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" (@NUM1). Throughout his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez consistently cultivates a mood of gratitude and love, highlighting the importance of family, heritage, and the sacrifices made for a brighter future, creating a heartwarming and appreciative tone.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and gratitude. Rodriguez explains how appreciative he is of his parents and everything they have done for him, making their house a home and always being there for him. He talks about friendships and families, emphasizing that family extends beyond blood relatives to the relationships formed with friends. Overall he thanked his parents and stated that "in reality there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age, and the demonstration of how important family and friends are," showcasing a deep sense of thankfulness that permeates the narrative.

In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a reflective and relaxed mood about his memories. For example, his use of parentheses create a voice for him through which the reader can better understand what he is trying to say. Also, by reflecting positiely on old times, it feels as if the author is right here next to the reader, having a pleasant conversation. For example, when he is talking about his landlord's daughter, Elena, he mentions how she would often grace his table with her presence. Furthermore, by describing the enviroment of his apartment, it feels to the reader most as if we are sitting in a wood backed chair listening to the sweet saranade of an unamed Cuban singer. The smell of spices lingers in the air, The smoke from a stove waters the eye's as it drifts lazily out the window. The sound of engines and the beep of horns created by the low roar of a bus plays in the backround. The bright reds, oranges, and yellows of the furniture burn pleasantly in the eyes. This reflective and relaxed mood is so important for the author to get his stories across, and Narciso Rodriguez does it well.

The mood that the author has created in this memoir was a happy feeling because this is proud of his culture. He loves his parents and loves that house that they turned into a home. The author explains how his life began in New Jersey and how proud of his parents he was, noting his admiration for their hard work and dedication to family. He looks up to them and plans on carrying out the culture and traditions that his family had, ensuring their legacy continues. That's what makes me think that the mood the author sets was happiness and fullness of this family's life, and as I read this passage I was glad and happy for him that he admires his family that much and how happy his life was, leaving me with a warm sense of contentment for the author's positive experience.

The mood created in the memoir could be of happiness, gratefulness and love. The author describes in the memoir how his parents left their country Cuba to give their children a better life even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they love (@CAPS1 @NUM1). The author express gratefulness by saying his grateful for his culture and the sacrifice his parents did (@CAPS1 @NUM2). To conclude the author also express his feelings about the house he use to live, you learn the real definition of "family", he is really happy about the welcomes his parents use to do when other refugees arrival to this country, showcasing the warmth and generosity that filled their home. At the end the author says "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home," highlighting the enduring power of love and family in creating a sense of belonging.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was sad because he grew up as a poor boy; his family had no money. He was living in a one-bedroom apartment in New Jersey, and they were living in a heart of which was a kitchen. His parents were both sharing cooking duties, but his parents still remembered the traditional way they acted in Cuba; they were in a very poor house. It was a refugee place where all refugees lived. After, he thought about going to school and helping his family. After he started going to school, he started learning lots of stuff about love and other stuff, and he started learning ENGLISH because he didn't know how to speak ENGLISH. Then he started learning it, and he lived in a house that's where he celebrated his birthday. It was very small; it was the size of the kitchen, and he said he would always be grateful to his family for doing such great things for him. That's the time he was very young, he was very proud, and he said he will always be to his parents for their love and sacrifice. He told his parents that he admired them for their strength, courage and perseverance, so it was a very sad life for him and his parents, yet filled with gratitude and admiration for their resilience.

I think that the mood of this excerpt is caring. The parents wouldn't have (pretty much) given their lives away to start new and give their children a better place to live. Narciso's parents are immigrants; they lived in Cuba. His parents created a traditional Cuban home. It's too hard to leave their parents behind in Cuba, as family is important. If you are Cuban, you have your own culture that you bring with you.

The tone of the poem is very warm and loving. The warm memories of his home, filled with passionate Cuban music and the love for culinary arts leave the reader with the warmth and love of the house. The words he uses, like "adore," "warm home," "innocence of childhood," "passionate," "congregation," "love of cooking" and "celebrations" lets the reader go away from the excerpt with a loving and heartfelt tone. His discussion of the real definitions of family, which aren't only blood relatives leave the reader warm as the paragraph talks about his extended family like Alegria, Sergio and Abuela, and his real relatives like aunts Bertha and Juanita and his cousins "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" is so loving that the tone is struck in a strong, final chord of warmth, which leaves the reader satisfied. The tone of Richard Blanco is undoubtedly loving.

The mood in this article is happy and grateful. Living life in a country or place away can be very difficult from what I've known, heard and seen. Poverty often takes over the situation with a side of racism and discrimination occasionally. Nonetheless, this well-told memoir tells of the contentment and good side of it all. The happiness that was created in a place that Narciso calls home, despite the hardships faced. In the home, he still got to experience Cuban culture including music, traditional cooking and best of all ambiance of family being around. "Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote kind of lightens up the whole idea of this memoir and how people from all over came together to celebrate the wonderful joys of life even though at times they were frowned upon, highlighting the resilience and strength found in community and cultural preservation.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is love. Narciso and his family had so much love that they were able to overcome struggles and help others to overcome by allowing them to stay in their home and live with them. They allowed people who weren't even a part of their family to become part of their family, showing affection and support. They loved and cared for others, possibly even more than themselves, and gave up everything they had in Cuba to come to America for a better future for their children. The immense amount of love in this house is what transformed it from an ordinary dwelling into a loving, caring, compassionate, and selfless home, not only for Narciso but for everyone in the community and family that was created. That pervasive sense of love is what defines the mood of this memoir and the family who created it.

The mood was happy because most of his family immigrated to Canada. That him and his parents loved to cook together. In the memoir "@PERSON1 from Home: The blueprints of our lives," I believe the author, Narciso Rodriguez, demonstrates the mood of being laidback very articulately. This memoir does not sound very formal due to the fact Narciso does little things like adding parenthetical statements with additional statements, for example, in paragraph @NUM1. And talking about his friends and family so openly further contributes to this informal tone. That's why I feel @PERSON1's memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The blueprints of our lives," captures the mood of being laid back effectively.

There are many times in the memoir when the author created a mood. One time that the author created a mood was when he described a traditional Cuban home, in which the kitchen is the heart of the home. Also, when the Cuban music mixes with the aromas of the kitchen, this gives off the mood of hunger for great food and a longing for connection. Another time when the author created a mood was when he described how he lived in a close-knit community, where neighbors supported each other. This shows how the author grew up helping people, while being helped in return, giving the mood of wanting to help someone in need and fostering a sense of belonging. A third time the author created a mood was when he described his parents as caring people; their generosity extended to those they considered family. His family always helped people who were considered family to them, creating the mood of hope because his family knew that other people would do the same for them. Clearly, there are many times when the author creates a mood for the reader, drawing them into the experiences and emotions of his life.

In this memoir, the mood created by the author was heartwarming and appreciative. There were so many parts to this story that made me feel so warm and made me want to say "aw". For example, in paragraph @NUM1 where it states, "was a close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people, not necessarily of their own kind, were clearly in need". This line showed me how much love there must've been and that everyone cared about everyone else. When the author is showing how her parents left their country to come to @LOCATION1, you can tell how grateful the author is; this is shown extremely clear in paragraph @NUM2 where it states "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice". I think this story made me realize that you need to appreciate what others do for you, no matter how small. This author was so grateful for her parents, and that is shown very clearly in this memoir, making the reading experience all the more touching and resonating.

Narciso Rodriguez is very gracious and compassionate, and he will never forget the monumentous risk his parents made to leave everything behind to come to America so he could have a better life. Narciso recalls how his parents had to take any job they could and "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This past summer I was in New York, New Jersey and I had to stay with this family. This family was great to me, and I will never forget their uncany attitudes to give me whatever I want. When I read this passage this family immediatly popped into my mind. Narciso's mood is unbelievably grateful to levels most people don't have the chance to experience. Narciso will never forget his parents and the sacrifice they made for him, demonstrating a deep appreciation that resonates with anyone who has experienced similar acts of kindness and support.

The mood in the memoir is that Narciso appreciates what his parents have done for him, recognizing the sacrifices they endured. He sees how they strived to provide him with a better life and expresses gratitude for their efforts. He also appreciates that they turned their simple house into a home, filled with love and warmth despite its physical limitations. He thinks that what they did was very courageous, especially leaving behind everything familiar. Narciso is thankful for his parents, acknowledging the profound impact of their decision to sacrifice their life in Cuba to make his life better, ultimately shaping the person he became.

In the story "Narciso Rodriguez From Home: "The Blueprints of Our Lives," the little girl lives in a one-bedroom apartment, and she doesn't call it home until she moves into a three-bedroom apartment; maybe then she will call it home. She doesn't really know about love and to be kind, also to care about people. But at the end of the story, she knows about love; she says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," showing that the physical space wasn't the defining factor, but rather the love and care her parents provided within those walls. This transformation highlights her understanding of what truly makes a home.

When reading this memoir it makes you feel something. The feeling you feel is a sort of sorrow, a sadness evoked by the hardships described. When you feel this, it makes you think about why they had to live that way, enduring such difficulties. It also shows that you care for the people who deal with that lifestyle; you develop empathy for their struggles. @CAPS1 For goodness sake, be nice to people; don't be nasty because what you do could affect you too. Remember that kindness and understanding can make a world of difference in someone's life, fostering a more compassionate society for everyone.

The mood given by the author in the memoir is sweet, loving, and grateful. The author uses many kind, gracious words to describe his family and uses things from what we picture as an ideal family to create an even more colorful image for us to see. He uses imagery and sensory language, which helps us feel a homey atmosphere when we read. In the neighborhood he lived in, "... all of these cultures came together in a great solidarity and friendship," and that shows how close everyone was to one another and how rich of cultures that had come together. Moreover, this sense of community further emphasizes the positive and supportive environment in which the author was raised. In paragraph @NUM3, the author explains how grateful he is to his parents which showed him the lessons which became the root of his life. As most children experience through their lives, they are greatly influenced by their parents. To have his parents teachings be the basis of his life, he must have had a deep connection with them. As he talks about his home and that his ... "parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed..." them on to him, it shows how observant he is and how caring his parents are to have the time, subtly highlighting the warmth and shared responsibilities within the household. These words create a very sweet, loving, and gracious mood to the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is joyful and grateful. The author is joyful because in stanza two Narciso states "Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This shows that the childhood of this person was joyful, filled with the sounds and smells of culture, family, and friends. This person is very grateful for all of the things his parents did. Such as when the author states "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could've ever done. I thank them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for this period of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The author's reflection on his parents' sacrifices highlights his deep appreciation, thus making the mood of the memoir joyful and grateful.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happiness and being thankful because in the memoir in paragraph @NUM1 when he is saying "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. It means that it doesn't matter if you aren't blood related because it only matters if you have love for one another and you care about one another. This shows his gratitude for the close-knit community he experienced. Narciso is just saying that he is proud of what he is today, and loves and respects his culture, and that he has people to love and has people who love him back, which contributes to the overall positive and appreciative tone.

The family is trying to set a mood. The mood is inviting and how a family can overcome difficulties together. The parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to the countries. That is showing how open and caring the family is, illustrating their desire to create a supportive and welcoming environment for others facing similar challenges, further emphasizing their strength as a unit.

The mood created by the memoir is a mix between a happy mood and an unhappy mood. Everything is happy when they talk about his parents welcoming the other immigrants into their home, sharing what little they had. And how their landlord's daughter was his first friend, a beacon of acceptance in a new land. And then it shifts, talking about how their neighborhood is filled with Irish, Spanish, and Italian immigrants and how they are in that neighborhood because of racism, subtly highlighting the underlying prejudice that shaped their lives. The juxtaposition of welcoming gestures and the grim reality of segregation crafts this bittersweet atmosphere.

The mood created by the author was happy, thoughtful, and very polite. Narciso talked about his family and his life, sharing anecdotes with a gentle smile. The stories he told painted a picture of a man content with his blessings.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is joyful. The author tells us how he loves his Cuban culture. He doesn't argue with them and they enjoy the time they have together, creating lasting memories. I think the author is joyful with all the happiness that surrounds him at his house, painting a picture of contentment and familial love.

Narciso Rodriguez creates a very humble, caring, and grateful mood in his memoir. The humility shows when he describes how, although rich and inviting on the inside, his house was simple and "modest" on the outside, suggesting an understated elegance. All of the home's warmth and comfort was crammed into a three-room apartment. The sense of caring was demonstrated throughout the whole memoir in the way that Rodriguez referred to not just his blood-relatives, but the friends and neighbors whom he considered "family," showcasing a deep sense of connection. Of his parents, he says that they "always kept their arms and their door open" to their community, highlighting their inclusive nature. Rodriguez expresses his gratitude again and again, especially in the sixth paragraph, demonstrating a recurring theme. He states that he could never thank his parents enough for the valuable lessons they instilled in him, especially their generosity and sense of community. These three themes set the mood of this memoir, establishing a portrait of a man deeply appreciative of his roots and the people who shaped him.

The mood created by the author is quite comforting and homey. As the author describes his life growing up at home as a child, he seemed to have a pleasant life, filled with warmth and love. Everyone who came to the Rodriguez's home was welcomed and treated as if they were close family, emphasizing their generosity and open hearts. The overall mood of this memoir is friendly and welcoming just as the Rodriguez's home was, leaving the reader with a sense of nostalgia and appreciation for the simple joys of life.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, he develops a very warm, comforting, and happy mood of where he grew up. Narciso Rodriguez tells us of how his parents came to the states and after living in a small, one room apartment for a while were able to move in to a three room apartment where he was born. He speaks of how his home was decorated in the traditional style, about the Cuban music always playing, filling the apartment with rhythm and joy, and of how his parents taught him to cook traditional dishes. Rodriguez also tells us of his diverse neighbor hood but of how they all came together in unity. Everyone cared for one other and they helped whoever was a need. The mood created by the author is loving because it talks about how generous and caring his family is. "... @LOCATION1 graced our kitchen table for meals..." The mood created by the author was great. He made it so Narciso was very happy and proud to have grown up in Cuba. He also made it so Narciso was grateful for everything. The mood is very loving and happy. The way he talks about the neighborhood he grew up in, where everyone knew each other and looked out for one another, shows that sense of community. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and grateful. He is grateful that his parents give up everything that they had just to give him a better life. The mood is well many different things. But mainly the mood is loving. In the story, Narciso Rodriguez, from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the home created by the parents in the memoir was a very soft home because they are all grateful for what being going on with their lives like the parents said in paragraph 6 "It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. it was here where I learned the real definition of "family". And for this, I will never forget that house towards gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." Because of the love and memories created within its walls, the house transcended its physical structure to become a true home, deeply etched in his memory.

In the memoir, the mood created by the author is one of gratefulness. I know this because in the memoir it says, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." This evidence shows how Narciso Rodriguez was grateful, which contributes to the overall mood of the memoir. He continues by stating his appreciation for his upbringing: "His parents taught him how to love his culture, (and for which I am eternally grateful)." The author's word choice demonstrates that the prevailing mood of the memoir is indeed grateful. This feeling of thankfulness permeates the text, shaping the reader's experience and understanding of the author's reflections.

Narciso Rodriguez's "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" creates a very optimistic mood. Narciso describes how even though "at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States," he and his "family" (which included foreign neighbors) still overcame adversity and found strength in unity. In addition, he describes how even though his neighborhood shared different cultural backgrounds, they still lived together harmoniously as a family, fostering a sense of belonging. Lastly, he describes all the cherished memories and vibrant celebrations that helped transform his house from a mere living space into a place of profound love and enduring friendship. It is easy to tell that Narciso deeply loved his family and friends equally, and their influence shaped his life in a positive and meaningful way.

I was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and when I celebrated my first birthday. I was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of family. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there, how to love, how to share what little we had, and how to find joy in togetherness. I will never forget this house.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," a clothing designer who grew up in New Jersey with immigrants, the mood is that home isn't a physical space but relationships. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative," Rodriguez states. He experienced a "Close-Knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants." It's unlikely Narciso would be the same clothing designer if he hadn't grown up surrounded by these individuals, as their influence shaped his understanding of connection and belonging, which likely informs his creative vision.

The mood the author created was gratefulness. Narciso is grateful for his parents' sacrifice to live in America. This gave him a better life. The @CAPS1 created by the author in the memoir was regular because in the story (Narciso Rodriguez) he explains his life a little to the reader. The mood created by the author is a happy, reflective memoir on the author's family life growing up. It talks about how warm and caring the author's household was and how it got to be like that. The author sets the mood in the memoir by talking about what was going on in the household: "Our traditional Cuban home, where the very heart of which was the kitchen." The author talks about her family's love for cooking and the happy mood of the house with the "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." The author also talks about the close-knit community of honest, hardworking migrants who lived in the surrounding homes; they were all friends that took care of each other, knowing that anyone would do the same for them as well. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from the book "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the author was very happy and grateful. I know he is happy in this memoir because in paragraph @NUM1 he writes "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." The author creates a mood of appreciation for his house and parents. The author expresses that his parents selflessly sacrificed their own well-being for their children. “They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially...” This illustrates the significant sacrifices his parents made, leaving behind their familiar lives in Cuba for the sake of their children's future, leading to deep gratitude. Furthermore, his parents instilled invaluable life lessons through their actions, as stated, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... I've often told them the admiration for their strength and perseverance... and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life." This emphasizes that his parents taught him something important without explicitly stating it, but by demonstrating it. The house also served as a place where he "learned the real definition of 'family'," highlighting the importance of his upbringing. Thus, through their sacrifices, lessons, and the environment of his childhood home, the author conveys a strong sense of appreciation for his parents and the values they instilled in him, shaping his life in a profound way.

The mood in the memoir created by Narciso Rodriguez is hopeful, heart lifting, caring, grateful, lively, loving, and courageous.
