The mood created by the author in the memoir is gentle and proud. The author explains how he felt about his parents, who risked everything in order to give him a better future, according to paragraph @NUM1. The author feels proud of being from Cuba throughout the whole memoir. He feels proud of being Cuban by explaining the things he does and things that are shared through his culture. Last but not least, he feels thankfulness, according to paragraph @NUM2, because, through his parents and things from his country, he learned what family really means, and he says "... I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". Consequently, the author shows pride in where he came from, from his parents, country, and his neighborhood, culminating in a portrait of gratitude and affection.

The mood the author is creating is sad. Because he is talking about his whole family and his house, recalling the happy times within those walls. He remembers how he had so many good memories there and his first friend, a bond forged in childhood innocence. This kind of mood is sad, tinged with a sense of loss and nostalgia for a past that can never be fully reclaimed.

In the story "Narciso Rodriguez," I think the author was very grateful and happy at the moment. I think he was happy because he was elaborating about how Narciso was always in a good mood and how she always loved to cook in the kitchen with everyone. Also, how she still loved her ritual song she sings with her family, highlighting the joy and connection that this tradition brought to their lives. This suggests a deep appreciation for Narciso's positive spirit and the warmth of their shared family experiences, leading to the conclusion that the author's happiness stems from these cherished moments.

The mood that was created by this author was love. It was love by how he described his house. "The passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This combination of cooking and music you usually associate with love, and love is happiness. The author also talks about his "close-knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, not necessarily their own kind were clearly in need." This also shows the mood in this memoir is love, love of cooking, of music, and of family. Another place where it showed love in the memoir was in this quote: "My Parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows love because even though these people aren't blood-related, they still look out for each other and knew they had someone to lean on, illustrating a deep affection and care. The apparent mood in this story was love, and the family had much of it.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is Love. In paragraph @NUM1. It says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This suggests a deep appreciation for connection and belonging. Thus, there will always be love and happiness in your home if you just respect your friends and your loved ones, nurturing those bonds. Life would be good, filled with joy and a sense of security derived from strong relationships.

In the memoir, the author creates a mood of love and community. In paragraph two the author describes his childhood home with words like traditional, passionate, and congregation. These words set the tone for the rest of the memoir in which love in helping the community are key themes. These themes are reinforced in the last few sentences when the author ends speaking about his gracious neighborhood and how he learned to love, solidifying the memoir's central message of the power of communal bonds.

The mood created by the author is a loving and caring mood. In the second paragraph, he describes the house as having the rich culinary cooking of his parents, the passionate Cuban music filled in the air, the aromas of the kitchen in their warm home. He tells that in their house they have feasts, also the many immigrants they invite into their house until they can leave by themselves or find a place to live. At the end he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The mood created by the author in the memoir is love and happiness, illustrating how family are friends. In the memoir, he expands on how his mom and dad gave up everything for their child and his life. They had to change everything they did in Cuba; for example, the jobs. In Cuba, his dad had worked in a laboratory, and his mom had studied chemical engineering, professions they might have to give up. This sacrifice underscores the deep love and commitment that define the heartwarming mood of the memoir.

The mood of this memoir is grateful and content. The author emphasizes this mood with his quotes that the author puts in. "I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey." That shows that the author did not care that much about house looks, price or its location. "It was here where I learned the real definition of family... [that it] had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The author is grateful for all the people that the author now considers his "family". Also, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life". That highlights right in the quote that the author is feeling grateful! The author also puts some phrases in parentheses, just to add a bit more, "(after which I eternally grateful)", "(which I adore to this day)". Those show the author is happy and grateful with his life, and last this next quote exemplifies that his "family" members were all grateful for each other. "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necissarily their own kind, were clearly in need". Overall, the author's word choice and included anecdotes clearly convey a sense of deep gratitude and contentment with his life and the people in it.

The mood created by the author is friendship and love. When the author's parents moved to the United States, They created a traditional home, the heart being the kitchen. "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." In the kitchen celebrations, childhood, friends, and family formed the backdrop to their life. The author learned that '"family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative.' The neighborhood the author lived in is made up of many different cultures but they blend with each other to form a small community of honest, hard-working immigrants who help others when they themselves are in need. "My parent's always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family." The many immigrants gave up their lives in Cuba to move to the US to make a better life for their children even though they did not know the language or culture. The author will always be thankful to her parents for that reason. There is no way to show her thanks for her parents' love and sacrifice that they showed to her when she was just a child, showing her the importance of family and friends. The author states "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." They didn't just change it; they did it through love and friendship, crafting a sanctuary built on shared experiences and unwavering support.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was loving and caringness. Repeatedly throughout the memoir, the speaker Narciso Rodriguez shows what his family did after migrating from their native country, Cuba, to show their love. As said, his parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family, knowing that they would do the same for them. They cared for their children's future by leaving their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. All though "they struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships," they had to do what they thought was best for their children's well-being. Their simple house was the best place for them to be together as a family, as it fostered a sense of unity. "The warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love" further emphasizes the strong family bond. This memoir made me connect this family to mines given how similar it is. Without love it isn't a family, that's why at the end of the word "family" the i, l, y stand for "i love you," which highlights the central role of affection and care in their familial relationships.

This memoir gives me a sort of cozy and comfortable feeling. When it talks about a family being not only people that are blood-related to you I think of my friends and the people I can count on; they are my family too. He also talks about how a house is not necessarily a home, not without memories, your family, and something or someone that you trust. Lastly, he tells us about how greatful he is that his parents brought him to a neighborhood that he would soon learn to love, a sentiment that resonates deeply. This piece makes me think about and appreciate my family, and my home, reminding me of the importance of both.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of warmth and good feeling, reflecting a reality centered around family. This is evident in the depiction of family members coming to live with them until they could re-establish themselves, the constant presence of relatives, and the transformation of a "house into a Home." Endless celebrations form a backdrop to life in their warm home. "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in their country they loved." "The barriers to work were strong and high and my parents both accepted that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they had deserved." "In Cuba, Narciso, Sr.. Had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied Chemical Engineering." In @LOCATION3, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. This narrative highlights the sacrifices made and the resilience displayed in the face of adversity, as they navigated a new country and unfamiliar job market. "The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times," ultimately contributing to the overarching feeling of hope and familial love that permeates the author's recollections.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is loving, caring, and gratefulness. Throughout the memoir the author continuously mentions how grateful she is to her parents and how much she loves them. She says that "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author means that she's thankful her parents loved her enough to give up their home, jobs, and friends, all to give her a better life. She also says that "what they [her parents] did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." Narciso is stating that it takes a lot of courage to go forward to an unknown future, and she's very grateful that her parents did. These quotes, filled with appreciation and respect, showcase the loving, caring, and gratefulness expressed in the memoir by the author, solidifying the overall positive and thankful tone.

The mood is a mixture of things; it's really hard to say with all the emotions the author throws around. However, the strongest feeling is unity and family. I'm not sure family can be called an emotion, but it is, I think, something that can be described by several. One, of course, is unity, or as he says it, "great solidarity and friendship." It's rather sweet how he characterizes family as something like the bonds you make with people, in contrast to other cultures where family is from blood ties and family is always first. So, in a way, I think his way of thinking comes from his culture, shaping his understanding of familial connections. But also, he puts in a bit of sadness but overall seems to be extremely thankful for what he has. As they say, "happiness is nothing without appreciating it," and as he says, "I learned the real definition of family," suggesting he now possesses a deeper understanding of true happiness and belonging.

The mood created in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is of happiness, peace, and gratitude. Narciso is thankful for all that his parents had sacrificed and taught him. His overall tone in the memoir is translated into a happy and peaceful mood. Narciso writes "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life to our warm home." The tone in this quote is calm and friendly, as Narciso explains the happiness of his life at home. By saying his house was "warm" with celebrations for family and friends, it constructs the peaceful mood of the memoir. Narciso also recalls the delicious food that was always present, further contributing to the warmth.  Narciso goes on to explain that "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family." Here, Rodriguez adds to the peaceful mood by speaking of generosity, and care towards family. It is the idea of family that fueled his loving childhood. The mood turns to gratitude as Narciso thanks his parents for giving him a better life, though they had to endure difficult jobs and conditions. He expresses that he had "no way to express [his] gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon [him]," and "the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The concepts of family, love, and generosity Narciso learned from his parents formed the basis of the gracious, happy, and tranquil mood of his memoir, as well as his life.

The author created a tone in the memoir that was truthful and grateful and pride inducing. "pasionate Cuban music... Filled the air mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. The former quote found in paragraph 1 described the pride and gratefulness of the home in which the author lived. The memoir created a Family love which every person longs for in life. " They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" (paragraph 3). Anyone who can sacrifice like that for the better life of their family is a good person. That is the family love I am describing being selfless and loving to other members of your family. Another mood created in the memoir was pride in the family's sacrifice. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice I've often told them that what they did was a more courageous thing than I could have ever done" (paragraph 4). That was a quote from paragraph 4. It shows that you have to be thankful for the sacrifices people make for you. The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy because the atmosphere is filled with family and friends, also joy and happiness. The mood created by this memoir is a relaxed, caring kind of mood. Several parts of this work emphasize this mood. Within the walls of Narciso, her young parents created their traditional home. Their heart was the kitchen. Narciso's parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on their rich culinary skills to Narciso; she loved to cook. Quite the contrary, Narciso's neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish and Italian immigrants at a time of racism. Her parents came selflessly, as some immigrants will do, to give their children a better life. They sacrificed leaving their family, friends, and careers in the country they came from. I think her memory is a nice, happy one because with those memories she knows what her family went through to provide her with opportunities.

The mood created by the author was love from his family. The author describes "a love of (Cuban) cooking which is still with me (the author) today" and how he also has a love of "passionate Cuban music which I (the author) still adore today." The author got this love from his parents, which shows the impact of their affection. Another way the author created the mood of love was by talking about how his "parents always kept their arms and door open." It shows generosity and how welcoming his family was to others. The author is speaking very lovingly at this point in the story, highlighting the warmth of his upbringing. The author also says that he "will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice," further emphasizing the deep bond. The mood that the author set during the story was love. I think that this was a really good mood to set in a story, creating a heartwarming and appreciative tone.

I think the mood created by the author was gratefulness towards his parents. Narciso Rodriguez wants to tell his parents how very special they are to him and how much he thanks them for what they did for him. In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez says that "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." This highlights a recurring theme of appreciation. I think that in this memoir, Narciso wants the reader to understand how he feels about his family. He wants to tell us about what they did for him, emphasizing their impact on his life. Narciso thanks his parents for their sacrifice and I think by telling us his story, the mood that was created was gratefulness towards the parents who made him a 'home.' This feeling of gratitude permeates the narrative, shaping the reader's understanding of Rodriguez's deep connection to his family and the sacrifices they made for him.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful. Narciso is thankful for his parents support and love. The words "grateful for their love and sacrifice" demonstrates that through his whole life they were there for him. They didnt just tell her what to do, they showed her. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy one because Narciso was happy with all her parents did for her, and the neighborhood was a peaceful one; everybody reached out to help whoever needed help, fostering a strong sense of community and belonging that contributed to the overall joyful tone. In this memoir the mood was created by Narciso and his family. Narciso's family created the mood by bringing all of the family together in their old home in Cuba and their new home in Miami. At the beginning of this memoir they talk about how their parents knew the struggles of life, the hardships of making ends meet. And would invite people into their home until they got back on their feet, offering them food and shelter. It was at least five years until the parents could afford a decent sized house, a testament to their generosity. Even though his parents left Cuba they still made an effort to keep all their Cuban traditions alive. His parents loved to cook traditional Cuban dishes and taught Narciso how to. They also play traditional Cuban music, filling the house with familiar sounds. Also, they taught him to be selfless, to think of others before himself. They would invite people over even if they weren't the same race because it didn't matter to them; what mattered was helping those in need, showing that true home lies not in walls, but in the kindness shared within.

The mood created in this memoir is love and unity. "... all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This means that they were close, loving, and unified. This memoir gave me the feeling that just a house is not a home until there is love. "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" further reinforces this feeling of warmth and love, suggesting a nurturing and connected environment. Ultimately, the author conveys that love and unity transform a mere dwelling into a cherished home.

In my opinion the mood is created by the author in the memoir by the setting and describing her childhood, where she was born and why her parents came here. The reason I think this is because the mood can create this setting, because the mood is the feeling in the story, such as sad, happy, lonely, silent and that is what creates the setting which is where, when, and time of the story. Some examples from the excerpt are, "In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family building, in the Ironbound Section of Newark, New Jersey." Also, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being blood relative." The author is thankful for her Cuban heritage, as well, and her home is more about relationships than just space. Thus, the mood of belonging and gratitude is palpable, shaping the reader's understanding of the Ironbound setting as one of close-knit community. In this memoir the mood created the setting.

I particularly enjoyed this memoir. The author did a fantastic job at creating a sense of love and comfort while telling his story. The first sentence that stuck out to me was in paragraph @NUM1: "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." To me, that sentence was all about making people feel comfortable and at home. It put out a sense of family in the story. The feeling of love was easily put into the story at paragraph @NUM2, when the author talked about his family. Especially where the author had said "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us. The family loved everybody, and used their love to help struggling people, or people who just wanted to visit, get back on their feet and stay in their home. This story was truly filled with dozens of examples of love and comfort, and I really enjoyed reading it.

The mood is a family that tried to move from their home country to start a new life in a new country. The initial excitement of packing faded, replaced by a quiet apprehension as they boarded the plane. Leaving behind familiar streets and loved ones felt like severing a part of themselves. In the new country, the language barrier proved a constant hurdle, and simple tasks became monumental efforts. They missed the comfort of their old community, the shared history and understanding. Despite the challenges, they persevered, determined to build a future for their children, slowly adapting to their new surroundings and hoping to find a sense of belonging. Ultimately, their journey was a testament to their resilience and unwavering hope for a better tomorrow.

The mood the author created in this memoir was very proud. I could tell that the mood was like that because he would always talk about his parents and how they gave up so much to come here. For example in paragraph @NUM1 it says, "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language Or culture... To give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their family, friends, and careers in the country they loved." I could @CAPS1 feel the pride in that because he is talking about how his parents left everything basically for him. Also, he mentions how his parents opened their arms to whoever needed help even though they were not the richest people either. He gave many examples throughout the memoir that strongly showed the mood he made in this memoir, pride, and this is evident in his descriptions of their selflessness and sacrifice.

The author creates a mood of happiness in the story. He states memories of his child that made him happy and nostalgic. He mentions the love that he had of cooking with his parents, remembering the warmth of those moments. He also mentions music as being passionate and that he still adores it even to this day, showing its lasting impact. He also describes how good his neighborhood was and how they were a close knit community, highlighting positive social connections. Then he starts to explain that a lot of his family was not just blood related but how it included other people, suggesting a broad definition of family. He then explained that his parents were very self sacrificing people, further emphasizing the positive influences in his life. So it was a very good mood the author wrote the story in, reflecting a life filled with joy and strong relationships.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez, the author shows a very strong mood relating to the piece. The emotions used to create the mood include passion, unity, and gratitude. The mood of this memoir has lots of passion. Narciso talks about his family's passion for their Cuban heritage, and how they shared it with him. That was a big component of turning that house into a home, and therefore, part of the mood that Rodriguez wanted to represent. "... my young parents created our traditional Cuban home... love of cooking... passionate Cuban music..." (Rodriguez, @NUM1). This passion extended beyond just music and food; it was a deep-seated love for their culture that permeated every aspect of their lives. I also could feel a sense of unity the author was trying to portray. ".. the congregation of family and friends..." The author mentions several times his parents and him were always letting distant relatives stay at the house, and many friends and family came and shared dinner with them, reinforcing the theme of togetherness. The author even describes his community as a "... a close-knit community..." (Rodriguez, @NUM2). This sense of unity highlights the importance of relationships and shared experiences in shaping the author's identity. Lastly, a sense of gratitude runs along the spine of this piece. The author notes his parents were a huge part of his life, exposing his to his culture, family and friends, and they home. He doesn't even have to write how grateful he is, it is so evident. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." (Rodriguez, @NUM3). This deep appreciation underscores the positive impact of his upbringing on his life and career. The author created a mood filled with passion, unity, and gratitude. All of these emotions are evident in the text, creating a powerful and moving portrait of his life and influences.

The mood @CAPS1 creates is happy. He had no negative comment about his parents or the way he grew up. His parents sacrificed everything for him so he can have a better life. Also the feel of his home reflected on the mood. It was a warm and safe environment in paragraph @NUM1 it states, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, the endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm house." @CAPS2 can really tell that he loved his home and family and the reflected upon the mood, contributing to the overall joyful tone. Ultimately, the author's positive reflections establish a sense of contentment and gratitude.

Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish-speaking families who, despite not sharing DNA, looked out for one another, creating a strong sense of community and belonging, ultimately redefining my understanding of kinship.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and family-like. The author goes on to describe his family, which were loving but poor. His family supported him by growing up in a happy, loving home, which helped shape who he became. They cooked nice food, and invited the relatives over to eat and share stories. The author shows that no matter if you're rich or poor, you can still have a closely knit family, and that love and connection are more valuable than material wealth.

The mood created by the author in the memoir would be described as happy and thankful. I say that because the author talked about how his parents were caring and selfless individuals. They always helped out people in need within their community, offering support without expecting anything in return. The author loved how he grew up immersed in his vibrant Cuban culture, embracing its traditions and values, and how he would never forget it. He said that it was one household filled with love and laughter that he would never forget, a place that shaped him into the person he is today, instilling a deep sense of gratitude.

The mood created by the author is that he is really happy that his parents moved to America to live close to friends and family because in paragraph @NUM1 it says "countless extended family members came and went -- and there was always someone temporarily staying with us." This constant influx of relatives suggests a warm and welcoming environment, filled with connection and support, making the author feel fortunate about his family's decision to relocate.

I feel that the mood(s) created by the author in the memoir is happy, proud, and grateful. I think that the author makes the memoir feel happy because he is saying that his parents were kind and they worked hard, and that made him happy, I think. Another mood I think is he was proud. He said (in paragraph @NUM1) that growing up in his environment instilled a great sense of family. His family welcomed other refugees from Cuba to celebrate their arrival to this country. Thanks to what he grew up in, he learned the real definition of family. The last mood I feel the author created was he was grateful. He said in paragraph @NUM2 that "I will always be grateful for my parents' love and sacrifice." He is grateful to his parents and how they "turned a simple house into a home" (paragraph @NUM3). Therefore, happiness, pride, and gratitude effectively capture the emotional landscape of the memoir.

In the memoir "@PERSON1 from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez, he creates a mood for the readers. The mood or feeling created in the story is mainly love. There are many things said in the memoir that express the mood of love. For example in paragraph two the author talks about the simple apartment that him and his parents lived in as a great place. He does this because he is so thankful to his parents because he loves them. The paragraph says, "and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." Some people may not be as grateful about simple things like cooking, but Narciso loves his parents so much that he is extremely happy for even the little things they did for him. Instead of calling Sergio and Edelmira the neighbors who lived below us, they are called surrogate grandparents. This shows that they were very loved by Narciso, and that they were considered as part of the family. Paragraph three says "Countless extended family members came and went and there was often someone staying with us temporarily." This expresses the mood of love because again the neighbors are called family. Also, Narciso's parents allowed them to live with them because they love them and cared deeply about them. In paragraph four it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso sees what his parents did with their lives as an amazing thing because he loves them so much, and he appreciates everything they have done for him. When this memoir is read the mood of love is expressed throughout the whole story.

In this memoir the author creates a feeling of gratefulness. @PERSON1 is grateful of his parents' unselfishness and the sacrifices they made for him, and his rich heritage. He loves his home country of Cuba and cherishes its vibrant culture. @PERSON1 is also thankful for his grandparents and the values they instilled in him. He loves his home in @LOCATION1 and is grateful for growing up in @LOCATION1, surrounded by familiar faces and cherished memories. He is also grateful that his grandparents made the courageous decision to come to @LOCATION1, paving the way for his own opportunities. Ultimately, he is thankful for the tapestry of experiences that have shaped him.

There is a mood created by the author in the memoir. One way in which the mood is created is by explaining how the warm life in the narrator's house was created. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, form the backdrop to life in our warm home." (@CAPS1 @NUM1) This helps create the mood of the memoir because it is explaining how the narrator grew up in an environment filled with love and joy. Another way in which the mood is created is by showing how caring and selfless the narrator's parents are. "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." (@CAPS1 @NUM2) This gave the memoir a light and happy mood, reflecting the positive influence of the parents. A third way in which the mood is created is by showing how friendly everyone was with each other. "In our neighborhood, despite customs everywhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The narrator explained how friendly and open everybody in the neighborhood was with one another, contributing to the overall feeling of community. As you can see, the author of the memoir created a largely positive and heartwarming mood in the memoir.

In the memoir the author's tone is loving. The way he describes his Cuban heritage and culture is full of pride for being Cuban. In @LOCATION1 two he states that he is eternally grateful for having had his parents "rich culinary skills and a love of cooking" passed on to him, highlighting a deep appreciation for their influence. Then at the end in @LOCATION1 seven his tone is once again loving and grateful, reflecting on the warmth of his upbringing. In the very last sentence it is noticeable: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," showcasing a profound sense of gratitude and affection for his family and their ability to create a nurturing environment.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", by Home: The Blueprints of our Lives, the mood created by the author is happy. The mood is happy because everyone in the memoir are enjoying their lives and their not worrying about anything. As explained in the memoir, even when @PERSON1 and Rawedia had to start their lives over entirely, they didnt hesitate. Their family were happy, they partied, and as said in paragraph @NUM1, they "always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family." This welcoming nature further contributes to the overall joyful atmosphere. In this memoir Narciso enjoyed his life and looked up to his parents for everything they did for him. It's clear that the love and strong family bonds described contribute significantly to the cheerful mood conveyed throughout the memoir.

In the story "Narciso Rodriguez," I think the author evokes a mood that is passionate, grateful, and happy. The reason I believe the author is passionate is because he speaks about how a home isn't just a roof over your head; it's where your heart is. "My parents always kept their arms and doors open for the many people they consider family." I think that is passionate because in order to do those things, you have to be really caring and lovable. I think that the author shows gratefulness because he says that he always thanks his parents for the sacrifices they made to give him a better life in New Jersey. Even though he says it many times, it just isn't enough to prove how grateful he is. His parents transformed a three-bedroom apartment into a place he now calls home, and that is what he is grateful for. I think that Narciso is happy that he had the chance to spend his childhood growing up in New Jersey, while still embracing the cultural traditions of Cuba. He is now a fashion designer. All in all, those are the three moods that I think Narciso conveys in the story, demonstrating his appreciation and joy for his upbringing and heritage.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Home, the mood created by the **WARM AND LOVING ATMOSPHERE** in the memoir is that growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life. but, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home, fostering a sense of belonging that transcended traditional definitions.

The author does an excellent job of creating many moods in this memoir. One of the moods is love. Love is a mood in this memoir because @PERSON1's parents took ten people who needed somewhere to stay, because they knew that those people would do the same thing for them. Another example of love is when @PERSON1 says in paragraph @NUM1, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." The memoir also makes one feel very grateful for what they have, which is another mood. It does this by having the author point out how little his house was, and how his parents did everything they could to give them a better life, demonstrating their devotion. It really makes one look back and see how much their parents have done for them, highlighting the power of familial affection and sacrifice. Thus, the memoir successfully evokes love and gratitude through vivid storytelling.

Well first the author feels happy and excited, but he also feels sad because he is moving to @LOCATION1. In 1961 he was born, and in that time he met a friend who was his babysitter, and she was his first friend; she lived upstairs from them. He has a lot of family members, but when he moved to @LOCATION1, his mom and dad took in people that needed a home just until they could get back up on their feet. He wants to see his grandparents who can't leave until 1970, but he told his mom and dad he will always be grateful to them for their love and sacrifice. He often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than he could have ever done; he also often told them of his admiration for their strength and perseverance, and he thanked them for everything they did.

The mood would be loving and caring. When @CAPS1 was a child growing up in @LOCATION2, his parents treasured family and friends. They taught him to always lend a helping hand and to always keep his door open. "Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly spanish, cuban, and italian immigrants at a time when racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States." It was a close-knit community and everybody knew everybody. Nobody was a stranger. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." His parent's instilled how important family is, and friends were just as vital, creating a warm and supportive environment for him as he grew. This emphasis on connection and mutual support shaped his worldview and values.

The emotional @INTENSITY created by the author in the memoir is Very necessary. I say this because I don't like any writing that doesn't have @INTENSITY swings. this author does a good job of showing the emotions of Narciso Rodriguez in their story. A place in the story where I really like the @INTENSITY swing is between @SCENE @PARAGRAPH1 and @PARAGRAPH2. I like this change because, it goes from talking about a landlord and his daughter to talking about @DESIGNER's parents. I like that because, it creates a mode of @CONTRASTING different backgrounds on the two different @GROUPS of People. It talks about how @NARCISO's Parents were immigrants and weren't raised well but they wanted their son to have a better childhood life than them. On the other hand, the landlord and his daughter @UPTOWN, were rich and Could do anything they wanted. I am just blown away by how this author changes his moods. Thus, the author's strategic use of contrasting narratives effectively highlights the diverse backgrounds and experiences shaping the characters within the memoir.

In the memoir 'Narciso Rodriguez' the mood of it was happy and was meant to sorta touch someone. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives the author creates a mood of love and admiration. The mood that the author gives throughout this article or memoir is happiness and family. All during the memoir he speaks of how he cherished his family. The mood is good and happy. In this article the mood is peaceful and positive. It's a successful mood also grateful because @PERSON1 is grateful for everything. This feeling of thankfulness contributes to the overall positive atmosphere.

The mood created by this SONG is, It makes the reader think about his family and what they have sacrificed for you. And it makes you feel warm AND fuzzy. In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is a loving one as Rodriguez is looking back at all the great memories of himself and his childhood when he was young. In this memoir Rodriguez is thanking his parents for being so selfless and loving him so much throughout his childhood. The mood created by the author in the memoir is very strong. Narciso's mood mostly has to do with his family, friends, and most importantly his culture. The mood in the memoir by @PERSON1 is happy, loving, and upbeat or lively. In the memoir the mood that was created by the AUTHOR is saying Family is the most important thing in life. The author's mood of this memoir is extremely thankful and appreciative. The author had so much admiration of his parents strength and perseverance. He learned the true meaning of 'family" and about how to love. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a family mood. Rodriguez talks about how family always visits. In the HOME from "Home: The Blueprints of our lives," Narciso Rodriguez creates a very distinct mood. I think the mood of the HOME is warm, caring, comforting, and very loving. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and warm. This is shown in two ways: the selflessness of the parents and the true meaning of family. Narciso Rodriguez, the author, is forever grateful to his parents for starting their lives over so he could live a good life in America. This is shown in paragraph one when he explains that his parents loved Cuba but left so their children could have a better life in America. He gives his thanks to his parents in paragraph two, acknowledging the sacrifices they made. This feeling of gratefulness contributes to the warm, happy feel of the piece. Throughout the piece Narciso explains to us the true meaning of family "'... family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative," he states in paragraph three. In paragraph four, he explains that family means those who care for and about you and stick by you no matter what, suggesting a bond built on love and support. This feeling of family definitely helps to make the piece feel warm and happy, showcasing the author's positive outlook on his life.

I think the mood is supposed to be sad for many reasons. One reason is that he keeps saying how his house isn't a home until the end, showing a sense of longing. Such as, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," highlighting the importance of family in creating that feeling. Another reason is that his friends and family are all he has, representing a strong reliance on them for support. Such as, "...how important family and friends are," emphasizing their significance in his life. Also, because he had to move, he didn't know anybody, causing feelings of isolation. Such as, "Originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956," perhaps suggesting the challenges of adapting to a new place and the sadness of leaving behind what was familiar. Therefore, the recurring themes of a house not being a home, the value of close relationships, and the displacement from his origins all contribute to an overall melancholic tone.

In the memoir *Narciso Rodriguez* by *The Blueprints of our Lives*, the mood the author created is grateful. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, he creates a happy and excited mood. This is because he is sharing family memories and those of his home. The mood created by the author in the memoir can be described in many ways. For one, the mood is of graciousness for all that was done for Narciso Rodriguez. In the memoir it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This feeling of graciousness tells about the love and sacrifice he feels his parents went through for him. The memoir also shows this mood of graciousness for the understandings his parents taught him, shaping his worldview. In the memoir it says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This understanding that was taught to him had a large impact on his life at that time. The final expression of graciousness in the memoir is his feelings toward the passions his parents taught him. In the memoir it says, "unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally thankful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air,". These express the passions and skills that followed the author to adulthood, holding a special place in his heart. Therefore, the author's pervasive sense of gratitude significantly shapes the overall tone and emotional impact of the memoir.

The overall mood created by the author in the memoir was courage, and perseverance. First, Narciso Rodriguez's parents traveled to the United States with absolutely nothing; they had no money or background information about the country. In paragraph 1, Narciso states, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." Narciso's parents would bravely step into a new world where they didn't know anyone, they couldn't communicate with anyone, and they didn't really have any ideas as to what was going on. The Rodriguez's also persevered through the constant challenges of racism and segregation, here in this country. In paragraph 2, he states, "at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed..." Consequently, Narciso's parents had to get through problems with people, and they also had to fight through the mental challenges, due to racism. Lastly, in paragraph 1, Narciso says that his parents were always "braving the harsh winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." His parents had the courage to persevere through new weather and financial struggles. The overall moods that Narciso Rodriguez created for me were bravery and perseverance.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was the mood that you don't have to have lots of money or a big house; you just have to have your family to support each other. This feeling is evident through their shared experiences and unwavering loyalty, highlighting the strength found in familial bonds rather than material possessions, ultimately showing that love and support are what truly matter.

The author's mood in this memoir is happiness, stemming from the strong sense of family he experienced growing up. He states that being raised in that environment fostered a feeling of familial connection, noting that "here in my house felt like Cuba." The author's happiness is further emphasized by the respect he and his whole family showed to each other and to others, ultimately contributing to his positive outlook.

A sense of community, selflessness, and contentment washes over Narciso Rodriguez's memoir of his first home. Happiness was prevalent over this story, described through a "love of cooking", "endless celebrations", and "friendship". Readers can imagine the scenes depicted, happy gatherings around a table laden with aromatic food, and parties with people, young and old, tall and short, of all different cultures. The words that weave this well-written memoir are nothing if not content.  Community is also emphasized in this written work. "A close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants", their neighborhood was described as. The memory of many souls working together despite radical racism in that time really gives the memoir a communal sense. Narciso Rodriguez says, "My parents always kept their arms and the door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." The open-door policy fostered a shared sense of belonging and mutual support.  When the sacrifices that his parents made were outlined in the memoir, selflessness truly becomes a mood in the memoir. A whole new life embraced just so that their children could have a better life, his parents rarely did things for their own benefit. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," Narciso Rodriguez says. The endless struggles they endured, and the many times they could have given op, they didn't, because they wanted, so selflessly, to give Narciso a better life. This memoir's mood holds three important things: a love of community, happiness, and selflessness, creating a powerful and moving narrative.

Cultural traditions and joyful pastimes with loved ones are also explored. Interspersed with these cheerful moments are instances of sadness, poignantly illustrated by the author's late introduction to his paternal grandparents, who were finally permitted to leave Cuba in 1970, as mentioned in paragraph @NUM1; this delayed connection clearly adds a layer of complexity and bittersweet emotion to the narrative, ultimately demonstrating the full spectrum of human experience.

While reading Narciso Rodriguez I felt a certain mood. the mood was very serious and grateful. In the memoir Narciso said, "I will always be thankful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." this shows he is thankful for all his parents Did to make him the man he is today. He also writes, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." That statement is a serious thought that clearly came from the heart. It shows he has love for anyone who comes close to him. To add, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage." that says that he thinks about his parents and having heart, and courage, and that is both serousness and gratefulness. This reflection on his parents' journey highlights his deep respect for their bravery and the sacrifices they made. In closing I would like to say Narciso Rodriguez is a very grateful and serious man.

The mood created by the author is that of the American Dream. It is a very happy and successful theme with roots in the hearts of millions of immigrants that hopefully had similar stories. This short memoir is a great story to bring your mood from sad to hopeful and thankful that you live in a place you can call home.

In the excerpt from the memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez he has a specific mood or feeling throughout the whole excerpt. His mood seemed to be kind of like a happy mood that shows everything, even the hard times like "a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed the United States," in a happy tone or mood. He even explained how his parents left their country and friends to live here and have worse jobs in a lighter, happier mood. Rodriguez also recounts his childhood memories of his close-knit Cuban-American community with a sense of warmth. I believe that Narciso Rodriguez likes to look at everything in a happy, light mood no matter what it is, suggesting a resilient and optimistic perspective on life's experiences.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and a loving one. A reason why I think this is by talking about how he and his neighbors (of different descent) all got along very well in solidarity with one another, sharing stories and helping each other out, which creates a sense of love and community. Also, when he talks about happy times, like when he and his family are cooking in the kitchen, preparing traditional dishes and sharing recipes, they are having a good time, laughing, and listening to Cuban Music, filling the house with warmth and joy. Lastly, when he and his family take in family, or even just really close friends who they consider family, offering them a place to stay and sharing what little they have, conveys a true sense of happiness, peace, and love that permeates their home, ultimately solidifying the memoir's heartwarming tone.

The mood in "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives" is compassion. Throughout the memoir it talks about how Narciso was grateful to his parents for their "love and sacrifice". He was grateful that they wanted to move to the United States from Cuba just to ensure that he would have a better life. He learned generosity and how important family and friends are from his parents and they have been "the basis" of his life. His house welcomed everyone and the air was always filled with "not just scent and music but life and love," creating a nurturing environment. He learned what family really meant and learned how to love, shaping his understanding of human connection. He loved his parents a lot and talked highly of them in his memoir "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love... The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." This deep appreciation and understanding of his parents' sacrifices paints a picture of compassion that permeates the narrative. That is why I think that the mood in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives" is compassion.

The author of this memoir creates a mood that is very touching and meaningful. It shows the hardships his family had to overcome as well as the good that came from it all. The author states in his memoir, that, although his family was going through tough times, they left their door wide open to family that needed help and always had the thought of others in their mind. He explains how hard it was for his parents to leave their home and jobs in Cuba, but that they did it for him, so he would get to live a better life. One more thing the author said in the memoir that was very touching was when he said, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me..." These words show us how much of an impact his parents' actions had on him and how they helped him in life. These examples illustrate the touching mood the author successfully conveys.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is very appreciative and grateful. The mood created by the author is very grateful and thankful. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a very specific mood. He talks about family, love, and home. Narciso Rodriguez creates a very calm and grateful mood from beginning to end in his memoir. First of all, he describes the selflessness of his parents. In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author's vocabulary and sentence construction evoke a strong sense of love, happiness, and appreciation for his home and community. The harmony and friendship within his neighborhood, despite differing nationalities, is highlighted, a contrast to the times: "In our neighborhood... all of these culture came together in Solidarity and friendship". His word choice, with repeated use of words like love, grateful, and self-less, strengthens this atmosphere: "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life". "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The thoughtfully crafted and retrospective composition, vividly describing a place so near and dear, further reinforces the mood of underlying gratitude and love, demonstrating the profound impact his upbringing had on shaping his values.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from home: the blueprints of our lives, the mood created is described in many ways. Narciso will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. Narciso've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than Narciso could have ever done. The mood the author created is gratefulness. I am grateful for many things. I'm grateful for the culinary skills and love of cooking that was passed on from my parents. I am grateful for my close-knit community, who are honest hard-working immigrants who always extend a helping hand. But the big reason I am grateful is my family. I am grateful for my countless family & extended family who join us for meals and who stay with us temporarily. I am also mostly grateful for my parents. I am grateful that my parents are so nice and always keep their arms & door open for help, knowing they'll do the same. I am also majorly grateful for their courage to come to a new world without knowing any of the language or culture just to give their children a better life. I am grateful my parents had to make a huge sacrifice just for my benefit to leave behind their friends, family & careers in the country they love. I am also grateful for both the personal & financial struggles my parents had to go through and braving the harsh northern winters. For my culinary upbringing, love of food, family, and my parents' sacrifices, I will be forever grateful.

The mood created by the author is fairly formal, with a few informal parts. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" there was a mood to the memoir. The mood that was set was about how you should keep peace in the house. The memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" creates an overall mood of happiness, and some sadness at the same time. In paragraph @NUM1, the author explains what it was like to live in his home in Cuba. The mood Narciso Rodriguez creates in his memoir is very good and bright. He and his parents survived hard times in their New Jersey home, such as segregation of Cuban-Americans like himself and not always having enough money. Yet he and his family survived because of the unity of his closely-knit community. Immigrants from Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Mexico, and elsewhere all came together and ignored their differences. They shared food, shared their homes, and shared happiness between them. There was a certain trust among the community, every family holding their door open for anybody," knowing that they would do the same for [them]." (paragraph 3) To make the mood of this excerpt very light and cheerful, Rodriguez uses words like, "rich culinary skills and love of cooking," (paragraph 5) "innocence of childhood," (paragraph 5), "hard working", (paragraph 7), "courage," and "selflessly," (paragraph 8) "grateful... love and sacrifice," "admiration for their strength and perseverance," "spirit of generosity." (paragraph 9). All of these words show that through solidarity, hope, and courage, people can make a good life for each other, no matter how hard their situation is at first, ultimately demonstrating the power of community in overcoming adversity.

Based on the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" the mood created by the author in the memoir could be described in many ways. To begin with, the boy is very grateful for his parents and adores them so much. As you can see, the mood of the memoir created by the author could be described in many ways, but ultimately, gratitude is a prevailing emotion.

He writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (p. @NUM3). This shows that Narciso's parents had to go through a lot to make it all happen, highlighting their dedication to creating a supportive environment. Overall, Rodriguez creates a loving mood of togetherness.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the mood that is created by the author is love and sacrifice. In the memoir, the author shows love by not only showing the love between the child and the parents but by also showing the love throughout the community. The author shows sacrifice by showing what the parents had to give up in order for their child to have a better life. In the memoir, it talks a lot about the neighborhood, "all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people." This shows the closeness of the people in the neighborhood had and this represents the love as well. Sacrifice is shown by Narciso's parents. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This clearly demonstrates the magnitude of what his parents relinquished, representing sacrifice, and their unwavering dedication to his future. At the end the author also mentions "I will never forget that house or it's gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." This ties up the mood throughout the memoir. Love and sacrifice is the mood throughout the memoir that the author created.

In this paragraph I'm going to tell you the mood created by the author in the memoir I just read. One mood that the author had was happy. The memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, enholds a mood of happiness and warmth, which is described in several ways. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The mood in this memoir changes throughout the story. First off, the mood starts with being friendly. "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." This tells how the narrator is thankful for the experiences and lessons learned. All in all, the moods in the story fit together nicely, creating a cohesive narrative about community, resilience, and appreciation.

In this memoir from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, written by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso talks about how his family made his house a home. The mood he sets throughout the memoir is love, selflessness, and gratefullnes. This memoir shows love because of paragraph @NUM1, Rodriguez reminisces, "countless extended family members came and went--and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." This shows love because even if they weren't blood related, they still consider themselves family and cared for each other beyond belief. This memoir also has the mood of selflessness because Rodriguez says that they moved selflessly, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved and ended up facing many hardships to their new country. The last mood shown in this memoir is gratefullness, exemplified by Rodriguez's appreciation for the values instilled in him. Narciso Rodriguez is grateful for his cooking abilities, his love for cuban music and for his parents love and sacrifice. Especially he is grateful for how his parents turned his simple house into a home, solidifying the themes of love, selflessness, and gratitude as central to his upbringing and his understanding of what truly makes a home.

The mood that we are supposed to get is a happy yet calm mood while we read this because there is nothing too exciting, but there are some parts where you get happy for what they did, and you feel calm because, as I said, there is nothing really jumping out at you; it is just a life story, a heartwarming reflection that inspires a sense of peace and gratitude.

The mood the author created in the memoir was joyful and optimistic. In his neighborhood, all the people were friends and took care of each other when they needed help, sharing food and offering support during tough times. The author's home reflected the Cuban culture because of his parents, filled with the aroma of traditional dishes and the sounds of lively music. The author describes the hardships his parents had to go through like adjusting to a colder climate and not getting good jobs. Even though they had their own troubles, they were selfless and didn't let their problems get to them, always putting their children first. The author is very grateful for how his parents gave him a home and taught him what a family really was, instilling in him values of love, resilience, and community.

The mood @CAPS1 created was a mood of happiness and gratitude. @CAPS1 states how he will always be grateful for what his parents did for him. Ultimately, the prevailing sentiment is one of heartfelt thankfulness.

In the memoir, "@PERSON1," by Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood is set right from the beginning. The first thing said to start the mood was, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am extremely grateful.)" This shows the author is grateful and happy, establishing a positive tone. The memoir also said, "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This shows how the author is very proud of their heritage and upbringing. Also lastly the memoir mentions, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This again shows how grateful the author is for their family's dedication. The mood this memoir created was a warm, grateful feeling, evident in his constant praise for his parents and how deeply he loves his tiny home nestled in his hometown. The narrative emphasizes how grateful he is for his parents' selflessness, recalling sacrifices they made to ensure he had opportunities they never did, further solidifying the overall heartwarming tone and leaving the reader with a sense of appreciation for family and the enduring power of humble beginnings.

The mood of this memoir is slightly difficult, somewhat depressing, yet grateful, and now I am going to explain to you how. Also, in the United States, you have to get a new job, which brings financial uncertainties and the stress of adapting to a new professional environment. This short story is also grateful because you have an amazing opportunity to start a very better life and get a great education, opening doors to personal and professional growth that might not have been available otherwise. This complex blend of emotions shapes the overall tone, highlighting the challenges and the blessings that come with such a significant life change.

Narciso Rodriguez. The author, @CAPS1 Narciso Rodriguez, in my opinion, created a pretty good story. The author creates a grateful mood. The author writes about how his parents had good jobs in Cuba but left everything to give their children better lives in a new country. He also writes about how he grew up, with his parents teaching him about music, cooking, and the importance of family bonds. His parents never got the jobs they deserved because of the barriers to work they faced, all for their children's sake. The author is grateful for the sacrifices his parents made so he could have a better life and opportunities they were denied. This deep appreciation underscores the powerful impact of their selfless choices.

The mood created by the author of the memoir exposes various emotions and contrasts. "Rich culinary skills and the love of cooking (and for which I am internally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) ..."In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity". Another mood the author captures is gratefulness. In paragraph six the author explains how he is so grateful for the strength and courage his parents showed from moving away from Cuba. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have done." The final way the author creates a mood is during the last sentence of the memoir. The author states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". This quote captures the mood of being thankful for the unity of his family. He looks up to his parents for making his life as great as it is today. Throughout the story, Narciso Rodriguez shows examples of how grateful, loved, and unified his family felt with their struggles they had overcame and heritage they were proud of. And paragraph @NUM4, Narciso explains how grateful he is for his parents' hard work and determination for their children to have a good life, allowing him to pursue his dreams. "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love" wraps up the whole article and shows how grateful and cared for Narciso feels for his warm, welcoming home celebrating life, love, and their Cuban culture, solidifying the importance of family and heritage in his life.

The mood of this memoir is relaxed, happiness and thankfulness. Narciso makes their home feel peaceful and relaxed. "a great sense that family had nothing to do with being blood related." The mood of this memoir is almost remorseful, remembering his childhood home and his family life that includes his neighbors and extended family. Narciso Rodriguez creates a feeling of being home and being surrounded by people you love. He explains how his first friend was his babysitter and the person who lived above him, highlighting the close-knit community. And his real grandparents were still in Cuba, so his downstairs neighbors became his surrogate grandparents, further emphasizing the theme of found family. He also creates a mood of having nowhere to turn when it came to his parents getting jobs in the United States, as they had to settle with jobs underequipped for their abilities. His parents, he said, "came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This sacrifice, the author implies, transformed the physical structure of his childhood house into a true home, filled with love and purpose.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez describes his loving family and creates an appreciative, loving, and homey, comforting mood for the reader. It makes the reader feel admiration towards his parents and the author is trying to create a sense of appreciation and gratitude towards his parents. In paragraph 1, the author explains his appreciation for his parents; "But in reality, there's no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed on me at such an early age and demonstration of how Important friends and family really are." The author is also trying to create a comforting mood. When he explains the atmosphere of his home, he is trying to create a homey mood; "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." (Rodriguez, 2). This quote is comforting and adds to the homey mood. The author is also trying to create a loving mood in the sense that he is explaining the caring acts of his parents. In paragraph 3, the author describes his generous parents, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to... many people... I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (Rodriguez, 3-1). This shows the generosity of his parents and the author is trying to create a loving mood. Rodriguez develops a grateful, comforting, caring mood. The memoir effectively portrays the author's deep appreciation for his upbringing and the loving environment his parents created, fostering a sense of warmth and gratitude in the reader.

The mood that the author was trying to create was a sense of hope, family and happiness. Hope was present because his family helped others by letting them temporarily stay with them until they got back on their feet, which provided hope for the extended family. Finally, I think happiness was conveyed because he explains how grateful he was for his parents coming to America to give him a better life, and also in paragraph two he explains how his home environment was filled with cooking and music, which can be factors of happiness, ultimately shaping a positive and grateful tone. These elements combine to illustrate some of the moods that the author was trying to show.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez writes about his life-changing experience. The mood of the piece is happy, reflecting on the positive impact of his heritage. His parents immigrated from Cuba to the United States in 1956, seeking a better life. Growing up, he learned all about Cuban traditions and deeply admired them. He's very proud of his parents for the risk they took for him, a sacrifice that shaped his life and instilled in him a profound appreciation for his roots, which is why the mood of the story is happy.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, several moods such as comfort, sympathy and a sense of family are created by the author. Immediately as I began to read I felt comforted by the author writing about the home and family. I felt especially warm inside when he talked of his fond memories with friends. As the author continues, you cannot help developing a sense of security. However, once you continue reading and get into the struggles of his upbringing, the mood darkens. The author talks about the hardship his parents had to endure to give him a better life. I solemnly read on and was filled with a sense of family. "I'll always be grateful to my parents," the author writes, solidifying the sense of familial appreciation. He explains how much he appreciates the love and care given to him by his family. While reading this memoir, I have felt comforted, sympathetic, and a strong sense of family, as I'm sure the author had too, highlighting the power of shared experiences and familial bonds.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez was calm and loving. Rodriguez creates this mood by explaining a loving family, new friendships, and an overall welcoming feeling. To begin with, in paragraph one Narciso Rodriguez states, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote creates a calm loving mood because it explains that the author enjoyed his childhood, and loved his family who loved him back. Rodriguez again complements his family and the way Rodriguez was raised in the first sentence in paragraph two, also creating a calm loving mood. Next, at the end of paragraph two Narciso Rodriguez explains the love Rodriguez feels towards his friends when Rodriguez states, "... All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Rodriguez again shows the love towards his friends in the beginning of paragraph three. Showing love towards his friends creates a calm loving mood. Lastly, the calm and loving mood was also created because of an overall welcoming feeling. In paragraph four, the author welcomes the reader into his past by speaking about his childhood home that Rodriguez loved. Also in the last sentence in paragraph four Rodriguez explains the people his parents help stating, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This quote explains welcoming people creating the mood. Explaining a loving family, new friendships and an overall welcoming feeling create the calm and loving mood, created by the author.

The author creates a happy and grateful mood in the memoir. Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. In our neigborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celabrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays, surrounded by laughter and song. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. It was where I learned the real definition of family, bound by shared experiences and unwavering support. I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home, a haven of acceptance and joy that shaped my understanding of the world.

The feeling in this article when it talks about family is love, peace, happiness, and gratefulness. Narciso understands that his parents left everything in Cuba for him. Narciso has the opportunity to be born in America and having a better life. Narciso also learned that Narciso could love a non blood relative because they could be his family too. There were many people that were like family to him. Narciso loved them and they were happy spending time with each other, showing the strong bonds he formed. In this memoir the mood would most likely be happy and loving, reflecting the positive relationships described.

This quote means that his parents' mood was careful, always ready to assist and do anything for people if they needed help, highlighting their generosity and inclusive nature. My third and last quote is "My mother and father had came to this country with such courage." This quote means like before they came to the United States they had courage and now they were going to make it and be successful, showcasing their determination to build a new life despite the challenges. These quotes effectively illustrate the overall mood of kindness, careful consideration, and courage that permeates the author's memoir.
