While reading the memoir titled "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives by Narciso Rodriguez, I could feel the great sense of mood and emotion that the author poured into it. To describe the mood he created in this memoir, I would have to describe it as a great sense of love and gratitude for some things called home and family. This memoir is just gushing appreciation for family, parents, love, courage, and a caring home everywhere you look. Rodriguez starts off by describing his Cuban heritage and how it was always there during his childhood. In paragraph @NUM1 it states, "My parents... Passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air...". Here you can really feel he appreciated how his parents incorporated his heritage into his daily life as a child and how he still has fond memories of those times. Rodriguez then goes on to discuss in paragraphs @NUM2 and @NUM3 the community he had grown up in and what he learned from being part of such a tight knit neighborhood, such as to open up your heart and home to those in need and to never hesitate when the people you care about need help. This is shown in para @NUM2, in two instances when he says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." And where it also says, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together and great solidarity and friendship." Rodriguez's reflection highlights the profound impact of a supportive and diverse community on his understanding of kinship and compassion. At the end of his memoir, Rodriguez then goes on to describe the love and appreciation he has for his parents for having "Such courage" and how "They came selflessly" (para, @NUM5) to @LOCATION1. In para @NUM6 it tells, "I will always be grateful for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez really tells of how their faithfulness and great examples have also helped shape him into the man he is today. To conclude, all I truly need to say is that Rodriguez did a marvelous job with giving his memoir a very generous dosage of mood. It spoke volumes of how indebted he feels to his parents for giving him a loving home and teaching him how much family means, which I believe is the best gift a parent can give their child.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from the book Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the author tries to create a mood that complements his opinion on the definition of family. Narciso Rodriguez was born to Cuban immigrants in a busy area of New Jersey filled with people of all nationalities. It was this melting pot of people and his parents hard work that shaped who he is today. The main mood that is generated throughout the passage is a positive mood, exemplified best by how the author himself positively talks about the great impact his parents had on him. Narciso realizes the sacrifices and the the hard work his parents had to endure to provide for him, of which Narciso writes "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, with no knowledge of the language or culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even if it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." (paragraph @NUM1) Narciso's parents were not selfish at all and took a huge endeavor by going for the United States. However, through their hard work, determination, and couage they established themselves in New Jersey. It is this positive, happy outcome that makes the mood so bright and positive. In Narciso's home, as he writes, "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life in our warm home." (paragraph @NUM2) The use of the word "warm" creates the bright vibrant mood associated with his home. The idea of warmth is repeated later in the passage where the author writes "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the the air with not just scent but life and love" (paragraph @NUM3) The repetition in describing the warmth of the house once again establishes the positive mood. Narciso lived in a neighborhood filled with all kinds of people. However, despite their differences they came together as a friendly, united community, of which the author write: "Despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." (paragraph @NUM4) Despite the overt racism at the time, this community still came together and were there for each other no matter what. This unity with in the community definetely distills a happy mood within the reader. Overall, Narciso Rodriguez creates a very positive mood throughout the memoir, highlighting the strength and love within his family and community.

The mood created by the author in this memoir would be grateful and happy. It really makes you wanna think about life and how good it is, thanks to parents and grandparent, even ancestors. The mood created by the author in the memoir feels like that of simplicity and home. He talks of the music and smells of his house, giving the feel that one is actually there sensing everything. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez the mood is happy. Narciso is happy with his family and his culture, embracing his heritage. Memoirs have a certain mood that the author usually works around with. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, the author explains his family in a very **positive** way. The mood of the memoir I believe to be grateful or inspiring. Narciso's parents are immigrants from Cuba who live in a racist community and are working to be able to support their kids. Throughout this memoir the mood was very realistic. While I was reading it I was very interested in what Narciso had to say next. It seemed as if he was extremely happy to be at where he's at. The author of the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, talks a lot about home and how you can find family where you're not expecting to. The mood created by the author in this memoir is gratitude. The memoir showed how grateful Narciso was to his parents. Their bravery and selflessness must have truly impacted his life then and probably how he lives today. It also gives the feeling of respect. The author created many different moods in this memoir. An obvious one is Love. As a child, she really appreciated that her parents got a new home and moved to Miami to raise their child. She loved her Cuban background and the environment that she grew up in, cherishing the close-knit community and vibrant culture that shaped her identity.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is generosity. Narciso Rodriguez, the author, talks about how much generosity his parents had. He says, "My parents always kept their arm and their doors open to the many people we considered family." "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." In the memoir Narciso says that he will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. His dad worked in a laboratory in Cuba and his mom had studied chemical engineering in Cuba. In the United States they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. He says that this house was where I learned the real definition of family. He also says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Their parents were generous, grateful, brave and had courage. We should all be grateful for what our parents sacrifice for us or had sacrificed, and strive to embody the same spirit of selflessness and love that they demonstrated.

The mood that the author had set in the memoir went from a calm opening to an emotional tone, detailing how difficult his childhood was. He recounts how his family was struggling with their jobs and enduring significant financial problems, painting a vivid picture of hardship and resilience.

The author sets a mood to the memoir that allows the reader to attach and relate to what he is trying to explain. The mood given off by the memoir to me is selflessness. We all have an experience in life where someone gives up a piece of their lives for you. And in Narciso's case, his parents "moved from Cuba to give him a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers and the country they love." Even though they gave these things up, they brought along a lot of their Cuban customs with them, such as music, cooking, and lifestyle, for Narciso to experience while living in the safe and comfortable environment of Miami. They took those things and invited them to their new house to create a comfortable, suitable, loving living area, which allowed Narciso to call this area "home." By showing the selflessness of his parents, the author is able to create a connection to a time in the reader's life where someone showed this sort of mood towards them, creating a perfect mood to enjoy the reading. This connection fostered by the author's portrayal of parental sacrifice ultimately enhances the reader's engagement with the narrative.

The author's mood in this memoir is gratefulness, happiness, and gratitude. "They came selflessly as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life..." here the author shows that he's extremely grateful for what his parents did to help him make a new life. Lastly, in paragraph @NUM3, the author tells direct explanation to why he's grateful. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Therefore, the author in this memoir shows an extreme amount of gratitude, happiness, and gratefulness, to his sacrificing parents.

His actions, too, underscore this love, as he consistently prioritizes their needs. Therefore, it is evident that Narciso’s actions and words demonstrate his strong familial love.

In this memoir there is a mood created by the author. In the memoir the mood is calm, happy, and relaxing. In the nonfiction memoir Narciso Rodriguez by @PERSON1, the author creates a curious and warm mood by talking about his origin, talking about his upbringing, and talking about his memories. The mood created by @ORGANIZATION1 in the memoir was a peaceful, loving mood. Narciso says that his @NUM1 room home usually had someone staying there temporarily until they could get back on their feet, showcasing the generosity within the community. In Narciso Rodriguez from: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the author creates the mood of family and love in the memoir. Narciso was a boy he lived with his parents in a three-room apartment. The heart of the house was the kitchen and that was where his parents taught him to cook and showed him the passionate Cuban music In the house, "...the innocence of childhood the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both formed the backdrop to life in our warm home (14). Then, Narciso realized that " 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" (20), which showed that a neighborhood made up of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants could get along. Many people had lived at the Rodriguez house, even if they weren't blood related. Some people were the landlord and his daughter, who lived upstairs, while the grandparents lived in the basement. Anyone in the neighborhood was welcome to stay and they would usually stay in the house because they had an economic/money problem, and the Rodriguez family let people stay until they could get back on their feet and, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us" (21). "It was in this simple house... where I learned the real definition of "family." And for this I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (21), illustrating the enduring power of love and family fostered within those walls.

The mood in the memoir was that the author was grateful. He was grateful for many things like love for cooking and grateful for his parents. He is most happy about how he learned about the real meaning of "family", a meaning forged in shared meals and unwavering support, leaving him with a deep sense of contentment.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" From Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the moods conveyed to me were happiness, gratefulness, and sadness. First, the mood conveyed was one of happiness. The speaker is describing his community when he says, "All of these cultures come together in great solidarity and friendship" (paragraph @NUM1). The phrase "came together" illustrates the happiness the speaker must have felt within this unified environment. Secondly, the mood was one of gratefulness. When the speaker speaks about his parents, he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (paragraph @NUM2). The word "grateful" directly expresses the deep respect and appreciation the speaker holds for his parents' efforts on his behalf. Lastly, the mood conveyed to me was one of sadness. When the speaker is speaking about his parents he says, "What they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done" (paragraph @NUM2). The phrase "have ever done" suggests a feeling of sadness, perhaps stemming from a sense of being unable to fully match their bravery or repay their sacrifices. All in all, the moods conveyed to me in the story were happiness, gratefulness, and sadness, providing a nuanced and emotional perspective on the speaker's life and reflections.

The mood is created by the author in the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, an internationally recognized designer, who offers the following definition of "family." Rodriguez describes what family means to him. Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and my first friend) lived above us, and Alegria graced our kitchen table more often than not. Alegria was treated as a part of the family, not by blood, not by choice, but by circumstance because they understand the Rodriguez's family and they liked them, so they became part of their family, and they became part of her family. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." When you're away from home, everything you do is different; the way you sleep, eat, talk, and react is all different, except when you're home, everything is normal again. Family isn't by blood but by heart of circumstance, and home isn't where you live; it's where family is, it's where memories are; that's how the mood is set by the author. The author's tone creates a warm and nostalgic mood, emphasizing the importance of connection and belonging, ultimately defining family as those who share life and create memories together.

Narciso knows that his neighborhood was a huge part of his life and proves it by writing "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." I think that overall it is an upbeat article about a man's past, where he learned the defenition of love, and how grateful he is to those who taught him it.

In the book *Home: The Blueprints of our Lives* by Narciso Rodriguez, the memoir describes her home and how grateful she was towards it. The author was grateful for her parents' work toward the house because of how much time the parents had used in order to make the author feel at home in her homeland. The decorations in the home were amazingly done to perfection. "My young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen" (paragraph @NUM1). This shows how much love, time, and sacrifice her parents put through to achieve such amazement. It is hard in order to turn "one simple house into a home" (paragraph @NUM2), and her parents truly succeeded in creating a loving and cherished space.

I feel like the mood in the memoir is being grateful for your family for many reasons. My first reason is Narciso's parents came to America from Cuba just to make sure that their kids will have a good life. Another reason is his parents did hard labor and worked really hard to make him a good life. They also made their house feel like a home for their son. There are a lot of things Narciso is grateful for, and it is clear his parents' sacrifices deeply impacted him.

In the memoir, the author gives off a happy and grateful mood. He talks of how they transformed their house into a traditional Cuban home, the hearth of which was the kitchen, always filled with the aroma of simmering stews and freshly baked bread. Narciso says he is eternally grateful for the skill of cooking his parents gave him, a skill that connected him to his heritage and nourished both body and soul. They had "family" over all the time, sharing meals and laughter, and they would even let people stay over until they got back on their feet, offering a safe haven and unwavering support. He was grateful for them doing everything they could so their kids could have a greater life, sacrificing their own comforts to ensure opportunities for their children. They had also taught him the real definition of "family," extending beyond blood relations to encompass community and compassion, and he is grateful to them forever more for this invaluable lesson.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez the mood the author created in the memoir was a mood that made you feel like you were at home. The second thing that Rodriguez mentioned that also helped set the mood was "Growing up in this enviorment instilled in me a great sense that "familly" nothing to do with being a blood relative.I conclusion the mood that Rodriguez created was to make you feel like you wer at home. In this memoir, the author creates the mood as gratitude. Narciso Rodriguez says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." @CAPS1 expresses his gratitude for his parents selflessness. His parent's "started their lives over entirely" (paragraph @NUM1) just so their children could have a better life. "The faith that this trouble would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." (paragraph @NUM1) It also describes how friendly their family was. It says, "There was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet." (paragraph @NUM3) They were honest, hardworking immigrants who helped others and worked hard in persue of a better life.@CAPS1 describes the mood using many details. @CAPS1 describes Rodriguez's home by saying in paragraph @NUM4, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, form the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author effectively employs specific details throughout "Narciso Rodriguez" memoir to establish a pervasive mood of thankfulness for family, heritage, and the opportunities afforded by his parents' sacrifices, creating a feeling of warmth and appreciation.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez", the author describes how his first home as a child was a warm and inviting place to live. As described in paragraph "... my parents always kept their arms and door open", meaning his home was a loving place where anyone in need was welcome to stay. The overall mood of this memoir is that the community the author grew up in was a unified and happy one, where all the other immigrants were "family," sharing stories and supporting each other through the challenges of adapting to a new country, further solidifying the sense of belonging. Ultimately, this close-knit community shaped the author's values and perspective.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very positive. The mood is nice, happiness and joyfulness. He talks about how his most treasured memories are at his old home with his parents and family and friends. The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez is a grateful and loving mood. In the memoir the author creates a mood. Narciso Rodriguez tells about their childhood, and their home. This creates a mood in the reader of being home and warmth of family and love. This memoir gave a feeling of home, or being in the home of a Cuban family. Almost as if whoever was reading it knew them. It gave a feeling of hospitality and love. In, chapters of our lives showcases narciso Rodriguez. The mood was calm and collected, and this is why he mentioned how grateful he is to every one and I like how he gave a background story. The mood was to show it was a comfortable feeling. To show about a family and how a family would take care for you and what not, showcasing the warmth and security of familial bonds. The author aims to explain what lifestyle makes someone feel great, what daily routines and interactions contribute to a sense of well-being. It's about feeling safe and not living in a life where it will just wither away from you, emphasizing the importance of a nurturing environment for sustained happiness. The mood created in the memoir was based off how the author felt about his "home" and "family". The author was raised by parents that would let people stay in their house until they got back on their feet again, their whole neighborhood did it: "Quite the contrary, [his] neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States (paragraph 1)". The author learned many different things from them, like the definition of family: "Growing up in the environment instilled in [him] a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative (paragraph 1)". What the author is trying to say is that you can love someone and call them your family even if they are not blood related. The feeling that the author has towards his family is mutual to the feeling everyone else has with theirs: "[The author] will always be grateful to [his] parents for their love and sacrifice (paragraph 3)". The author loves everyone who helped him through his life, and the author is grateful to have them, showing that the pervasive mood in this memoir is one of deep love and appreciation.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is a very welcoming and happy one. Right off the bat Rodriguez talks about the advantages in his life: the advantage of where he lived, his heritage and his "family". When Rodriguez first moved into his house, he thought of it as "a modest three- room apartment." After all the good memories shared in the apartment Rodriguez attitude about the appartment changed, and it "turned this simple house into a home." His heritage, or culture, filled the air; some of these cultural elements included Cuban cooking and music, "which I adored to this day." Another mood setting advantage is his "family." Rodriguez talks about how his family was always over filling the house with laughter, and this "family" had nothing to do with being blood relatives. Therefore, a welcoming and happy mood is clearly created by the author through these descriptions.

The mood in this paragraph is pride, and hope, and love. Narciso clearly feels very strongly about his family. He states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." That sentence alone encapsulates the pride and affection in Narciso's words. The mood is happy and loving.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is a exciting, partying-like mood in the beginning because in the second paragraph he's saying, "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen and endless celebrations, etc." We get a sense of the vibrant and lively atmosphere that characterized his early life. Towards the end, the mood changed a bit into a grateful, sweet, and loving mood because he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The mood changed into a slowed kind of mood and explains why he is grateful for all of it. He says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This sentence shows us another reason that at the end, the mood turned into a grateful, sweet, and loving mood, showcasing a reflective appreciation for his upbringing.

The mood created in this memoir is friendship. One reason is because his parents let the door open for the peope they considered family. In this excerpt from Narciso Rodriguez's book, home just reading the last sentence: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," reveals the true mood of the memoir. The mood the author gives out in this excerpt is warm, comfort and happiness. In the first few paragraphs, Rodriguez describes his simple apartment that he first lived in, and how really, it was nothing anyone would consider special. But as the memoir goes on, he talks about how his family and friends is what really turned his little house into a home. His parents created a traditional Cuban home, which mainly consisted of the kitchen and how cuban music, and traditional cooking always went on. What really established a sense of warmth, community and happiness in this memoir is when he talks about how you didn't have to be a blood relative to be considered family, everyone was welcomed into his home. All were immigrants though, hardworking immigrants that created this close-knit community. Everyone's arms were wide open, so to speak. The great act of giving thanks contributes to the mood displayed within the memoir. The last few paragraphs state how Rodriguez's parents came to America very selflessly to give their own children a better life than they had had even if it meant struggling with their own personal hardships. The author talked about how he admires his parents and appreciates everything they had done for him and how their teachings of family, traditions and welcoming anyone no matter what their background really did turn their simple house into a home, solidifying the overall feeling of warmth and gratitude.

The mood in "Narciso Rodriguez" was loving, caring, warm, and inviting. The loving atmosphere was created by how much the family really did love each other. The family also loved their Cuban culture. The mood was also caring and friendly as the families from all different countries cared for one another. I felt that all the people were warm and inviting. Everyone felt that they could trust each other and have each other over for dinner, making the environment feel safe and secure. The Rodriguez family really brought their culture to their new home, and Narciso mentioned in the last paragraph that this is where he found out the definition for family while living in this neighborhood. The mood was created very clearly by the author in this memoir, showcasing the power of community and cultural connection.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is peaceful and loving. Narciso really believes that the definition of home is relationships & love rather than furniture and expenses. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez, there are different moods created. One mood is nostalgia. "I will never forget how my parents turn this simple house into a home." This shows how much he loves his parents and how much he loved his home. The last mood is, grateful. "Here, the innocence of childhood, congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author's mood is very grateful and happy. The author's parents were originally from Cuba, and arrived in the United States in 1956. The author moved into a modest, three- room apartment. Both the author's parents had rich culinary skills and a love for cooking, filling the small space with wonderful aromas. The author inherited his/her skills from his/her parents. They lived in a community of hard-working immigrants from Puerto Rico, Cuba, and Santo Domingo. The author's parents were very nice and friendly. They invited immigrants to their house to eat and celebrate their arrival in the United States, sharing stories and forging bonds over home-cooked meals. The author learned the real definition of "family" in his/her new home and community, understanding it extended beyond blood relations. The author is grateful to his/her parents for their love and sacrifice, which paved the way for a life filled with warmth, community, and delicious food.

The mood of this passage is very warm and personal. Narciso is very reflective in this passage about how his parents were so unselfish and gave up their life in Cuba to give Narciso a better life filled with opportunities they never had. Narciso goes on saying how unselfish his parents are, and how they take people in to give other people a better life not just themselves, showing a constant generosity. Narciso's parents were very caring, and very meaningful to him, shaping his understanding of compassion and sacrifice. He continues the mood by talking about what a true family is. How it's not just someone your blood related to, but who you care about and love, fostering a sense of belonging that extends beyond traditional definitions. Thus, Narciso's perspective highlights the profound impact of his parents' selflessness and the broader definition of family they instilled in him.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of warmth and community. Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing the memoir life was hard. Narciso Rodriguez creates many moods in his memoir. The mood of the memoir is grateful. In paragraph @NUM1 it says in parentheses "and for which I am eternally grateful," highlighting a deep sense of appreciation. The mood created in the memoir is I think comfort and happiness. First in paragraph @NUM1 "Here, the innocence of childhood the congregation of family and friends the endless celebrations." The mood of the memoir is gracious. Rodriguez is grateful for many things listed in this memoir. In paragraph one, Rodriguez says he is grateful for his inheritance of the cuban culinary gift. Rodriguez is also grateful for the love and hapiness of the home. In this memoir, *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, Narciso Rodriguez, the mood of the story really translates the way the reader is reading it. As Narciso lives in this small house, it becomes his whole life, and his life revolves around his family. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The mood created by the author in the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our lives is gratefulness. Throughout the memoir, Rodriguez talks about how he is grateful for his parents. Rodriguez mentions that in Cuba his parents had really good jobs, highlighting the extent of their sacrifices. Paragraph 7 sums up the mood of the entire memoir. Paragraph 7 starts with "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This line proves the mood of the memoir is gratefulness and that Rodriguez is grateful for everything his parents had done for him, solidifying gratitude as the central emotional current of the narrative.

First he was depressed by the house, its cramped rooms and peeling paint a constant reminder of their financial struggles. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez gives her own definition of "family." In paragraph one, she mentions that she adores Cuban cooking and music, indicating a strong connection to her cultural heritage. In paragraph three, she states that her neighbors were all like family, emphasizing the close-knit nature of her community. Stated in paragraph four, her parents would have everyone over, including aunts, cousins, and even their landlord, further demonstrating their inclusive approach to family. Narciso's parents seem like good people, and she had a nice neighborhood when she was younger, suggesting these relationships and experiences profoundly shaped her understanding of what family truly means.

The author created a reflective, happy, and grateful mood in the memoir. The mood of the author is subtle but at the same time kind of depressed. The way the narrator sounds to me is that he or she is in a bad mood, perhaps reflecting a general weariness. "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." His gratefulness creates a thankful mood through paragraphs six and seven, "it was here were I learned the true definition of "family"". This quote helps bring out the love in the mood. The author speaks of the sacrifices his parents made, further emphasizing his deep appreciation for their efforts in creating such a nurturing environment. This warm, loving mood of the memoir really helps the author's point get across in a meaningful way.

The mood and Narciso Rodriguez's memoir was love and respect. Narciso loved his family so much, and he learned that family does not only include blood-relatives. Narciso's family included the friends that he had made living in his neighborhood. Majority of Narciso's love went to his parents. He loved them for selflessly coming to @LOCATION1 just to give him a better life. They were fueled by the fact that they were giving a great life to their son, despite the fact that their jobs were not the best. He loved them for sacrificing their home, family, and friends back in Cuba just for him. Most of all, he loved them for teaching him two very important things-the spirit of generosity, and how important family and friends are. His parents also taught him courage by not being afraid of coming to @LOCATION1. He constantly thanked his parents and told him that he wouldn't have been so brave. All of Narciso's undying love and gratitude piles up, and it is clear to see how much Narciso respected his parents.

The mood described by the author was warm and full of happiness. In the memoir, the author @ORGANIZATION1 talks about the importance of his family which always brings a comforting feeling. He shared that he "was born into a two-family blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey" but that it did not matter where he lived but who he lived with. The mood you get when you read this memoir is mixed because of the way he describes his parents' life, his life and his home. When he says "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home" he is talking about how close they all are and that that is what matters; when you read that you feel the comfort, happiness, joy and compassion that he feels toward his life, his parents and everyone around him. It truly illustrates how family bonds can create a positive atmosphere.

The mood of this memoir is grateful. Narciso Rodriguez's parents both move to New Jersey from Cuba to give their children a better life than what they had. Narciso's parents lived in a one room house until they moved to New Jersey, where Narciso grew up. Inside that home the family created a beautiful Cuban community. The heart of the house was the kitchen, where they played Cuban music all the time. The part of New Jersey where the Rodriguez family lived was filled with Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. The community was like a big family, "the cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." All of these cultures that came together really showed Narciso what a "family" really means. She never would have known what that meant or have had these opportunities if her parents hadn't been selfless. They came here and had to start their lives over, a sacrifice she deeply appreciates. As Narciso says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a testament to their love and resilience.

In the memoir, the author creates a mood of warmth and gratitude. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being blood related." That means people that weren't blood related, he still considers them family. He also says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." That means that even though it wasn't a fancy house, it was still his home and he loved it. The mood of this memoir is love and appreciation, demonstrating a deep connection to his upbringing that he will never forget. That's the kind of mood evoked in this memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of **awe** and curious. My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture, undertaking a great leap of faith. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardship, yet persevered with unwavering dedication. The author is left with a deep sense of wonder and gratitude for their sacrifices.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of our Lives," the mood is portrayed as very cheerful, warm, and happy. The way that the author described his home and early years provided an image of a large happy family throughout the passage. For example, in paragraph @NUM1 it states "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This portrays the image that life in the author's home was friendly and loving. The warmth radiated not just from the physical space but also from the relationships within. Another example is in paragraph @NUM2 where it says "countless extended family members came and went - and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet." This highlights the family's generosity and close-knit nature, indicating a supportive environment. This means that their family was very close and would always look out for eachother. So in conclusion, the mood in this memoir is portrayed as very happy, upbeat, and loving, fostered by a strong sense of community and familial support.

The author created a loving and accepting mood in the memoir. He first does this when talking about his familys dinner table. The author says, "My parents always kept their arms and their door opened the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." (Chapter 1, page 1) This shows that his parents would help anyone and treat anyone like family in a time of need. Second, the author describes this mood in Chapter seven. He opens the chapter with, "It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and were I celebrated my first birthdays." (Chapter 7, page 2). His parents were so loving and caring that they celebrated with complete strangers and family their arrival. Lastly, the author ends his memoir with a powerful sentence, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." (Chapter 12, page 2). The author completes the mood by stating that his parents created a home by being loving and caring and accepting other refugees that came into the United States. Throughout the author's memoir, he creates a mood of loving, caring, and accepting, demonstrating the profound impact of his parents' generosity and open hearts.

In the memoir the author talks about how great it is that the author's parents had turned a simple ordinary house into a home, which means that the author's parents had made thier house to feel like home by bringing their Cuban culture into the house, such as Cuban food, Cuban music, and Cuban decoration, filling it with warmth. That makes the memoir a happy mood. But there is also inspiration to this memoir because it basically tells readers that it doesn't matter who your blood relatives are, family is family, people who love and care about you the most, showing that love transcends bloodlines and creates genuine bonds, thus solidifying the memoir's inspirational and heartwarming tone.

The mood of this memoir is very happy and loving. Throughout the story, Narciso shows how much he appreciates that his parents gave him the opportunity to grow up in Guadalajara. He shows that this memoir is loving by explaining how his mom and dad always had their arms and doors open to anybody they considered family. The memoir is happy because it shows that he has a lot of good relations with many people that he calls family, extending beyond just blood relatives to encompass close friends and neighbors. He is also happy because he knows how much it takes to move from your home country to America. Overall, Narciso had a very happy, loving childhood, filled with strong familial bonds and a deep appreciation for the sacrifices made to build a new life.

The mood created by The author is happy and warm tone. In paragraph @NUM1 he recalls enjoying cuban music and learning to cook. He also recalls making friends with other imigrants and learning to love and help everyone; this demonstrates his open heart. In paragraph @NUM3 he recalls learning the true meaning of family and what it means to make house, a home. The mood created is warm and loving and teaches the true meaning of family and of selfless behavior and that home is about The family, not the space, showing the reader what truly matters.

The mood the author created in the memoir was happiness and satisfaction. I know this because in the story the main character is happy. As he arrives in New Jersey he enjoys how his parents create their house looking like a traditional Cuban home. He is passionate of the Cuban music that he adores listening too everyday. Another thing is that the main character is satisfied of what his parents do for him. In paragraph @NUM1 it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The last thing is that he is thankful to his parents because in paragraph @NUM1 it says "@CAPS1 often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done. I've told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance and I've thank them repeatedly." These details contribute to an overall feeling of contentment and appreciation, solidifying the mood of happiness and satisfaction that the author successfully conveys throughout the memoir.

The mood created in Rodriguez's memoir is one of gratefulness + happiness. There are supporting feelings such as coziness + friendlyness but Rodriguez himself most exhibits gratefulness. In paragraph @NUM1, there is a great catalogue of gratefulness to the social skills that were passed down to him, specifically noting their importance. When in paragraph @NUM2 he talks about their cuban feast, a small one perhaps but with true love + life, the warmth is palpable. You get a true sense of the gratefulness Rodriguez displays for his parents not because of who they are or how much money they have or what they give him (materialistically), but being genuinely grateful of the nature + kindness bestowed to him, shaping his character and worldview. Ultimately, this gratefulness underscores the memoir's overall positive and appreciative tone.

The mood of this memoir is loving. It's TELLING you how you should look back at your home and your family. They all love you and how you love all of them. How every one was always there for everyone, a constant source of support and affection. This memoir encourages a perspective of gratitude and fondness, highlighting the unwavering bonds of family and the warmth of a loving home.

In the memoir Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives @PERSON1 he makes the mood seem loving, cheerful, and grateful. The mood is grateful to Rodriguez's parents for making his house more of a home among other things. In paragraph @NUM1 he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." @CAPS1 his parents did a ton for Rodriguez and he is constantly grateful for their efforts. There is also a lot of love in the mood of the book because there are lots of mentions of family. In paragraph @NUM2 it says "My parents always kept their arms and doors open to the many people we considered family." @CAPS2 arms opened and a big "family" are surely signs of lots of love and acceptance. The mood of the excerpt is also cheerful because as Rodriguez says "Passionate salsa music filled the air." And "a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air." Music and feasting are two of the most cheerful things there are, evoking a sense of joy and celebration. By recalling experiences from his childhood @PERSON2 manages to make the mood of his memoir loving, grateful, and cheerful all at the same time.

In the memoir "@PERSON1" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives the author creates a positive, greatful mood. The author "will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." I know because @CAPS1 writes a few paragraphs just to show how thankful the author is to his parents. @CAPS1 describes how great their jobs were in Cuba and then how poor they became in the @LOCATION1, but yet they still worked hard to give their children a better life, never losing hope. "In a simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country where I celebrated my first birthdays," which highlights their generosity. @CAPS1 describes everything as a positive learning experience and shows that throughout the memoir, the theme is positive and greatful, demonstrating resilience and appreciation.

The mood created by the author in the memoir feels sad. Because in Cuba, his parents, had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find, a difficult and humbling experience. In the author's memoir, he will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice, recognizing the hardships they endured for the sake of their family's future.

The mood in this memoir is gratitude. Narciso is so grateful and proud to have grown up where he did and have the family he had. "In our neighborhood despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Narciso is telling the readers that even though the people in his neighborhood were all different, they were still family, a sentiment that clearly fills him with thankfulness. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote tells you that even though things were rough he still is grateful for all the opportunities his parents gave him, highlighting the profound appreciation he feels for their efforts in creating a loving environment. His reflections underscore the enduring power of gratitude in shaping his life's narrative.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy for remembering the most important people in his life, the humble house where he lived when he had his first birthday, and the unique individuals in the place where his family resided. He was grateful for everything his parents gave him when he was a little boy and the education they provided. This gratitude reflects a deep appreciation for his roots and the foundation they built for him.

Narciso Rodriguez's memoir creates an overall mood of love and compassion for family and shows the strength of his own family. Narcisco explains that his parents' love of cooking and willingness to let other people in "instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." He emphasizes the importance of chosen family. Also, this memoir shows people facing hardships. Narciso explains his neighborhood and family overcame racism together, and supported one another. This sets the mood that they love each other. Lastly, this memoir shows love and sacrifice. Narciso explains that his parents "struggled both personally and financially" during their move to @LOCATION1. But Narciso's parents still showed him love through their actions and support. From his parents, Narciso has learned to love, and for that, he admires his parents, ultimately shaping his own capacity for deep connection and appreciation.

Based on the author in @CAPS1, the mood created was both happy and sad. The author created a happy mood because Narciso Rodriguez lived comfortably in a neighborhood of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. At that time, there was no racism or segregation, and he lived peacefully at home. However, the author also evokes sadness because, while Narciso Rodriguez learned about love and the definition of family, he felt he would never understand how parents turn a house into a simple home, which suggests a sense of longing and perhaps a lack of that specific experience. Ultimately, the contrasting elements of a loving community and a missing familial component contribute to the mixed, complex mood the author crafts.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez the author's mood is happy, and he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He loves his family and friends oh so dearly. He is also grateful to have a lot of his family members who are close to him that could get together for dinner and a lot more. The author says "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not just scent and music life and love." As you can see in the memoir the author felt happy and grateful for the love and sacrifice of his family, showing a deep appreciation for his roots and the people who shaped him.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez is an internationally recognized clothing designer. He talks about his hometown in Newark, New Jersey. In the memoir, he offers the true definition of "family". I felt like the mood was comforting, and loving, and heart-warming, especially by the way he talks about his Cuban heritage. His mother and father immigrated from Cuba to Newark, and even at a young age, they still managed to raise him, and do a lot for him, giving him the best childhood they could give him, that he'll always remember. He also talks about how "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative," meaning that you could even consider someone not blood related to you, as your own flesh and blood, family, illustrating the profound impact of community and shared experience on his understanding of kinship. This emphasis highlights the warmth and inclusivity that defined his upbringing.

I think he has a really great life and he's a happy person. And also he appreciates what happens in his life, both the good times and perhaps even the challenges, recognizing their value in shaping him. This appreciation, combined with his positive outlook, likely contributes to his overall contentment and sense of well-being.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is love, caring, and thankfulness. I say this because she really appriciates what her parents have done for her. In CHAPTER 1, she says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice, my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." Also, "it was a close knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were really in need."; CHAPTER 2. This shows that Narciso and her family can trust the people in their community which is a thankful mood. Because they know that they would never do anything to hurt them. In the last CHAPTER 6, it says "it was here where I learned the real definition of family and I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This shows how thankful, loving, and caring he is to his parents. Narciso is proud of his parents because they let people stay with them, when they need to. This highlights the author's deep appreciation and solidifies the overall mood of love, care, and thankfulness that permeates the memoir.

The author created the mood of love and caring. They always cared about other people, offering a listening ear and a helping hand whenever needed. This genuine empathy permeated their actions and words, fostering a sense of warmth and connection. Ultimately, the author's caring nature shaped the narrative, leaving a lasting impression of human kindness.

The mood created by the author of the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is generally a happy and memorable one. The author describes how his parents came to @LOCATION1, specifically the United States, and had to start all over. However, the author's parents are still very kind and turn their neighborhood into one big family. The parents cook and celebrate things with the neighbors. The author says he is very proud that his parents were such caring people. The mood of this story is overall very happy, sharing, caring, and grateful because of how nice the parents were. The author states "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." The memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is a very inspiring and happy memoir to read, with the mood to match it.

In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, there is a mood of joy, and hope. His parents came to New Jersey in a time of racial segregation. They persevered through the hard time with their child by having close bonds with friends and family that lived nearby. Culture was passed on to Narciso and he loved the art and music he grew up with. Narciso's parents always invited family into their home when they needed help. Also, many people that weren't related to them shared dinner with them each night. In the Rodriguez's home, there was hope to get better and joy for the moment.

The mood in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir seems happy. When the author talks about these memoirs, they appear to feel happy having those memories to share. It's evident when the author recalls their parents and the house they lived in, and how these recollections evoke a sense of their continued presence. So, if I were in the author's shoes, I would feel good about how I was raised by my parents to live in a better place, even if that means giving up a lot of things that mean a lot to you. That feeling of gratitude and contentment seems to be the author's overall mood.

I think it was a proud mood because she is saying what her parents did for her, detailing their sacrifices and hard work to provide her with opportunities they never had. This feeling of pride likely stems from gratitude and admiration for their unwavering support.

The author creates a grateful mood in the memoir. For example in paragraph 1 the second sentence the author states "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This shows that the author is grateful enough to have parents even though they are not his biological blood related parents. In paragraph 3 in the first two sentences the author is talking about how his parents came to this country with courage and without speaking the language or knowing the culture. He also mentioned in those sentences how to give their children a better life meant leaving behind families, friends and careers in their original country. This shows that the author is also generous because he realizes the love and sacrifice it takes to do this. Also, In paragraph 5 sentence two he says that he has told his parents that what they did was brave because he would have never been able to do what they did. It really displays how grateful the author is, and how much he admires his parents, ultimately highlighting the profound appreciation he holds for their sacrifices and love.

The author created many feelings in the memoir. First, the author created a warm and loving mood; "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote shows how much passion is behind his families love and it makes you feel warm and comfortable inside. Second, some feelings the author also creates are friendly and caring; "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solitary and friendship." This shows how friendship was very important and gives off a friendly and caring feeling to the reader, emphasizing the strong bonds formed within the community. Lastly, the author created a very happy and upbeat feeling in the begining of the memoir; "Here, in the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompass both, formed backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote shows that the author's family celebrated life and created upbeat feelings. In conclusion, the author of the memoir created many feelings for the reader.

In this memoir written by Narciso Rodriguez, he portrayed a very specific mood. This mood made me feel that I was there, or part of the story that he was telling. I felt this way because by familiarizing your readers with your characters, that makes writing the rest of the story a lot easier. For example, in paragraph two, I was able to get a sense of what his home and family life was like-especially with this line, "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." One line that I felt was special to the story was, "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who... were clearly in need" I liked this statement especially because it showed me, as the reader, how caring those people were, which helped to shape my understanding. It also brightened the mood of the whole story, adding a touch of hope and positivity. The overall mood of this memoir, I feel, was clearly depicted, successfully drawing the reader into the author's world.

@CAPS1 Rodriguez, in the excerpt from Home: the @CAPS2 of our Lives, evokes a nostalgic mood. Throughout the excerpt @CAPS4 recalls all the feasts, parties and guests @CAPS4 had at the "simple house" his parents turned "into a home" as stated in @CAPS3 @NUM1. This tells me that the author had very good memories at the house @CAPS4 loved and grew up in. The author also gives off a very compassionate mood. In @CAPS3 @NUM2 it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." @CAPS4 describes his community as "close-knit" and "honest." This tells me that the author was very similar to his community and loved all of them and was grateful his parents took their time to make his life the best they could. The mood is lastly @CAPS5. In @CAPS3 @NUM3 it says his community "extended a hand to people who were clearly in need." @CAPS4 calls his parents actions of coming to @LOCATION1 "courageous." @CAPS4 takes pride in his Cuban family and @ORGANIZATION1 and all of the immigrants @CAPS4 grew up around, which tells me @CAPS4 knows they accomplished a big feat in their lives. Those are the moods set by the author, revealing a deep appreciation for his upbringing and heritage.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, many moods were shown and created in the memoir. One mood shown in the memoir is great love. In paragraph three, Narciso wrote, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Another mood described in Narciso's memoir was gratitude. In the final paragraph, the author wrote, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." A last mood produced in the memoir was pride. In paragraph two, Narciso wrote, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." Indeed, these positive emotions were richly created by Narciso Rodriguez in his great family memoir.

In this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author beautifully creates a positive, happy mood. Throughout most of the memoir, the mood is very warm and hearty. The author's description of how his home came to be and how it's like warms up the atmosphere of the reader's mind and makes them smile unknowingly. For example, the last sentence of paragraph 1, it says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author's diction, or choice of words, such as *congregation*, *celebration* and *warm home* creates imagery of happy, joyful house and gives off a positive effect. In addition, he boosts up the warm, soothing mood up a notch by saying in paragraph 2 "... All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants." By saying this, this sentence sets up a feeling of being supported by your loved ones and shows a real definition of true family. Also, it sends a warm, relaxing, cozy feeling as the author talks about a loving, caring family. For this memoir, the author created a heartwarming, joyous, warm mood as he described his loving home and provided a real definition of family. A loving family really sets a warm, hearty mood.

In the story Narciso Rodriguez the mood of the author created was very peaceful. It was saying how it was a traditional Cuban home and there was passionate Cuban music that filled the air, often with the sounds of a lively rumba. There was also the mixing of the aromas in the air coming from the kitchen, hints of garlic, spices, and simmering sauces all blending together. There's tons of loving people around the house too, creating a strong sense of community. Which makes it home and comfortable. The mood was always happy and everyone loved to cook so they would always do that together even though they weren't blood related, sharing recipes and laughter as they worked. "Within the walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, every heart of it was in the kitchen." As you can tell this family loves being together and enjoys each other's company, creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. This collective love and shared joy solidify the peaceful and happy mood conveyed in the story.
The mood was great, filled with laughter and easy conversation. Everyone seemed relaxed and genuinely happy to be there, creating a warm and welcoming atmosphere.

In this article, the author's mood seemed to be happy and good. For example, he likes that his parents are selfish and hard-working people and tried to make his life happy. He also liked how they would invite a lot of people to come over for a visit and how they treated them like family, offering them food and drinks. He also likes how they taught him things that they know how to do, such as cooking traditional Cuban dishes. His mood did seem to change when he talked about how in Cuba having a job was a bit easier than how it was in New Jersey, where they faced challenges finding stable employment. They tried to make as much as they could, and his mood seemed to be a bit worried about their financial struggles. His mood changed to be happy again when he mentioned that he loves the way they treat their house like a real home, filled with warmth and love. Ultimately, the author conveys a sense of gratitude and appreciation for his upbringing, despite the hardships they faced.

The author creates a very happy, but curious mood towards the reader. The reading made me happy for Narciso, but curious on how much his parents had to struggle to give Narciso the best life he could get. For example the author states that his parents had to "start their lives over entirely, taking whatever jobs they could find." Back in Cuba, "Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria (Narciso mom) had studied chemical engineering." This shows how much his parents lost due to immigrating to America. This made me wonder why they would do this. They did it because they wanted Narciso to have a good education and to live a good life. Also the author creates a sad emotion, by saying, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This made me sad because some of the immigrants had to leave their mother's, father's, and friends and may never see them again. Such sacrifice highlights the profound love and hope driving their decision to seek a better future, demonstrating the author's skill in evoking complex emotions. The author creates a variety of different moods throughout the memoir.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez", by Narciso Rodriguez, there are several ways in which the author created the mood. For instance, when the author states how his family is from Cuba and they were able to move to a modest apartment. The author states, "Ö originally from CubaÖ could afford to move into a modestÖ apartment I would soon call home" (@NUM1). This quote shows that the author's parents wanted to give him a good life. They did this by moving themselves and him to @LOCATION2. Another example occurs when the author describes what his kitchen "heart of the house" is like and how even though they are in New Jersey, their house still feels like Cuba. The author says, "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" (@NUM2). This quote demonstrates that the author's family made sure he still knew what Cuba is like, preserving their heritage. The author's parents wanted to show him both sides of the world (Cuba and @LOCATION2). Last, when the author says how grateful he is about his parents and the way he grew up. The author says, "Ö I learned the real definition of "family"Ö I learned there how to love" (@NUM3). This quote shows that the author has learned all the important skills in life. Thanks to his family, he now knows how to love and treat everyone with respect. Clearly, through details of family, heritage, and gratitude, there are many ways the author created the mood for the excerpt.

Based on a memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, a specific mood is created. First, the author tells about a love of cooking in the kitchen with his family and the meaningful Cuban dishes prepared there. This creates an atmosphere of passion. Rodriguez describes, "passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" (paragraph @NUM1). This quote shows the passion the author has for his culture and traditions, a deep-seated love evident in his vivid description. Second, the author talks about the relationship he has with this neighborhood. A mood of passion is created based on the author's loving emotions towards his unofficial family. The author writes, "My parents always kept their arms and doors open to the many people we considered family" (paragraph @NUM2). This generosity and warmth cultivated a passionate community bond. Finally, the author shares his gratitude towards his parents and all that they have done for him. His passion for their strength, perseverance, and teachings create a passionate atmosphere. The author says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (paragraph @NUM3). This deep appreciation highlights the passionate foundation upon which he built his life. Throughout Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, a passionate mood is displayed, rooted in family, culture, and profound gratitude.

In 'Narciso Rodriguez,' the author creates mood in several ways. The mood created by the author is a warm, happy mood that associates with feelings of family and love. The first place we can see this mood is in paragraph four where the narrator tells us "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows that everyone in their community loved each other and helped each other, which added to the mood of family and love. The narrator also tells us of his parents that "they came selflessly, as most immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." This sacrifice highlights their devotion. This shows that the narrator's parents loved him so much that they wanted the absolute best for him no matter where it took them. This shows they feel family is very important to them adding to the mood of family created by the author. The final place this mood can be seen is when the narrator tells us that he would "always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," and that it was from his parents that he "learned the real definition of family." This gratitude emphasizes the strong bond. This shows how much he loved and respected his parents which added to the warm, loving mood. In 'Narciso Rodriguez' several things used by the author create a warm mood of family and love.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is comforting. His memoir shows his past life and how he felt about it. Cuban music filled the air, tables of Cuban feasts, different kinds of people interacting, all that is the mood he's trying to express about his life through his memoir. He's also showing his appreciation for his parents for making sacrifices for him so he could have more opportunities and education. He's also being very descriptive about his childhood and showing the type of life he had and what he and his parents had to go through when they came to @LOCATION1 and how they don't want people going through the same thing as them, so they helped immigrants who needed support. The author's nostalgic descriptions evoke a sense of warmth, painting a picture of resilience and community, ultimately crafting a comforting mood throughout the memoir.

The mood is obviously love and greatfulness ("and for which I am eternally grateful"). The boy is young, so he doesn't quite grasp how monumental that move was for them. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, finding new jobs and a house. This meant leaving family, friends, their home, and everything familiar to provide a better life for their son. He is thankful that his parents were still able to keep his Cuban heritage alive, never forgetting their roots. Now that he thinks about it, a thread of sadness weaves through his feelings; he was, in a way, the catalyst for that upheaval. What if he had never been born? Would his parents have ever discovered the profound meaning of family in the way they did? That's why this memoir resonates with greatfulness, love, and that subtle undercurrent of sadness, a complex tapestry of emotions woven together by sacrifice and devotion.

The mood they created in the author in the memoir was very different from other people. We all have different mood swings, but some people have the same and it never changes. One way you need to change this is how you act around others and how to get to know them the way they are around everyone, not just with friends. This understanding helps foster empathy and adjust expectations, leading to more authentic and meaningful connections. Ultimately, recognizing individual differences in emotional expression is key to building stronger relationships and navigating social interactions more effectively.

The mood created in the memoir @ORGANIZATION1 is happy & warm. The memoir is happy & warm because it describes how a small home can be very happy; like in paragraph @NUM1, it says "always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." This shows that love fills the air which is happy, reinforcing the overall warm feeling. That is how the author creates a mood.

Home The Blueprints of our Lives is a warm tribute to the parents of Narciso Rodriguez. The author of this memoir had said, "Growing up in this environment istilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." Narciso Rodriguez would change the way a reader would perceive this memoir. It would be a story of a young child who has perceived the physical and mental qualities of adults. Narciso acknowledges the troubles Narciso and his parents are in. For his neighborhood including his family being immigrants, in a time of racism and segregation, Narciso learned how to appreciate this "close-knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants." Narciso understood how Narciso Rodriguez Sr, and his wife struggled personally and financially. Narciso became grateful for his opportunity to live in this Cuban home of Newark, New Jersey. Though his parents had worked in a laboratory and studied chemical engineering, they struggle to find work in financial times. Narciso adores them. The author writes, "They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life." Without these relationships, and the lives of various people, this memoir would be a selfish story of a child. Narciso appreciates everything the family has done. There was too much generosity impressed upon a boy of such an early age. Narciso had learned how to respect his parents. In the end, Narciso Rodriguez would write a memoir devoted to the bonds Narciso created with his parents and the refugees amongst them, demonstrating that family is built on love and support, not just blood.

In this memoir the author has created more than just one mood. He has, in my opinion, created around three: love, gratitude, and caring. The mood of love was created because in the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez tells us that family isn't just blood relatives. It can be anyone. In his case his whole neighborhood was his family, extending the definition of familial bonds beyond traditional limits. Family can be anyone and to me family is or can be people that you love. That is how the mood of love was created by the author. When I read the memoir and got near the end, I personally felt the mood of gratitude. I felt that because the author is grateful for all the things his parents did for him, one example is when his parents left their hometown so that their son could have a better life, showcasing their sacrifice. My parents did that for me, so I could relate on a personal level. I know I'm grateful for them making that big decision. I also think the mood of caring was created. I think that because in the memoir the author says that his parents would let people live with them until "they got back on their feet," providing support to those in need. I felt as if the family was caring doing that, its not like anyone would do that, so the family was caring. That is why I felt the mood caring was created by the author. In conclusion, the memoir effectively evokes feelings of love, gratitude, and caring through the author's reflections on family, sacrifice, and generosity.

In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez speaks with nothing but warm fondness and gratitude as she describes her childhood home. The loving way she talks about her parents' apartment and their kitchen and the Cuban culture they combined into their everyday lives suggest that Narciso has wonderful memories of her parents. Obviously, she is very grateful for everything her parents did for her and the chance for her to grow up in such a tender community - where "'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The memoir is filled with these touching reflections. The entire memoir is written with such care and attention to sweet detail. The author clearly feels blessed that her parents sacrificed their safety in their homeland to bring her to America in order for her to live a better life, to experience the importance of friends and family, and to learn about the true meaning of love through Cuban culture. Narciso Rodriguez, a clothing designer, wrote a memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives." The memoir evokes a warm feeling centered around the meaning of family and home. Narciso states in the memoir, in CHAPTER 1, "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the Aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This proves Narciso's house was a warm, welcoming family home. Narciso's community was also close-knit, like a family. In CHAPTER 2, this is evident when he says, "Close-knit community of homes, hardworking immigrants who extend a hand to people who were clearly in need." He also suggests that blood isn't the sole determinant of family, as seen with his surrogate grandparents. In CHAPTER 3, he proves that his parents were always welcoming: "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Thus, Rodriguez's memoir paints a picture of a home and community defined by warmth, acceptance, and the bonds of chosen family.

One last fact that contributes to the mood of this memoir, is Narciso's view on family. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative... In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship". This inclusive definition of family highlights the strong sense of community and belonging that defined his childhood. From this excerpt it is clear that the author cherishes this time, and would love to go back, as the environment cultivated so much happiness and warmth.

The mood Narciso Rodriguez creates is gratefulness. When I read this, I feel thankful like the author. Although his family had a good life in Cuba, they left to give their kids a better life. If the author's family hadn't left Cuba, I think the mood would be different. Then the author wouldn't think his parents were selfless (for that reason, anyway). If my parents did that for my siblings and me, I would want people to feel grateful as well. He understands how hard it was for his parents. Another mood could be guilt. I feel guilty when I read this because I don't always thank my parents or appreciate them. Narciso Rodriguez created a lot of moods in the memoir, allowing readers to connect with the sacrifices made for future generations.

The mood created by @PERSON1, the author of the memoir, Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, is a comforting one. In addition the comforting feeling is shown when Narciso says, "I learned here about how to love.... My parents turned this simple house into a home." This shows that Narciso had a great place to grow up in and has fond and comforting memories of it, solidifying the overall comforting mood of the memoir.
