In the nonfiction memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives the author created a warm, busy, and giving mood. The mood is warm because in the memoir it says "the congregation of family and friends and endless celebration that encompassed both, form the backdrop to life in our warm home". This shows there were a lot of friends and family together in this home, demonstrating a strong sense of togetherness. Also the mood is busy because in the memoir it says "countless extended family members came and went-and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet". This illustrates the constant activity and movement within the household. The mood was also giving. It was giving because in the memoir it says "It was close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people, who while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need". This demonstrates a willingness to help others, even those outside their immediate circle, showcasing their generosity. That is the mood the author gave in this memoir.

The author's mood of the memoir is that @CAPS1 is grateful because @CAPS1 tells us how much @CAPS1 appreciates what his parents have done. @CAPS1 appreciates that his parents "immigrated" to the United States so @CAPS1 can have a "better life". @CAPS1 said that "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." @CAPS1 is grateful that his parents did that for him. @CAPS1 is happy that his parents made their house like if they were in Cuba where they originally came from. @CAPS1 said that the "Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." @CAPS1 is thankful of the "sacrifice" that his parents needed to make. @CAPS1 is so grateful that @CAPS1 can't "express his gratitude". The author thanks his parents for what they've done to make him happy. That is how grateful the author is towards what his parents did to make them have a better life and @CAPS1 has learned what the word "family" truly means. The mood portrayed in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir is closeness. The first way in which the extreme closeness of Narciso's childhood is displayed in the memoir is through the way that, "all of the cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship" when, during the time period that this story is taking place in, the many different immigrants would never usualy even think of mingaling with each other. This shows that, in Narciso's youth nobody cared about race and every person in his neighbor hood was extremely close to the friendly people who surrounded them, regardless of ethnicity. The second form in which the tight bond between his literal family and his many neighbors is describing all of his aquaintances as "family" that have a close enough bond to each other to be able to show up at each others doors and immediatly be taken in and fed a meal that the Rodriguez family worked hard to procure. This insight into the early years of Narciso's life shows that he grew up with the understanding that "...' family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" and that you should treat all of your friends as you would family. Finally, and possibly the most extreme way that the Rodriguez family shoed their extrordinary closeness to their friends and relatives is by keeping their, "... arms and their door open to the many people we considered a family..." This willingness to give anyone they knew a place to stay and food to eat shows how extremly close they were to everyone the knew. Whether it be by always having their door open, to mixing between many races, or considering almost everyone family the Rodriguez family showed extreme closeness with the rest of human kind. These examples illustrate the profound sense of community and interconnectedness that defined Narciso's upbringing and shaped his worldview.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez is very happy and uplifting. The whole story is an optimistic view of Narciso's childhood. None of the bad parts of his childhood are written about. Narciso is very grateful for his family, specifically his parents. They came from Cuba to New Jersey to start a good life for their son. This causes the beginning this memoir to start off with a happy, uplifting mood. As the memoir progresses, it still maintains the same happy mood. Paragraph two is a great example of how the mood created by the author is so happy. Paragraph two talks about how Narciso's family would go to their house and share meals with them. Narciso was happy to be around his family, laughing and talking. The best example of the mood created by Narciso is the final three paragraph. The final paragraph talks about how Narciso's whole family made a house into a home. This is a very happy paragraph to complete the happy mood of the story. The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez is extremely happy; with this lighthearted tone and positive memories, the story avoids any mad, or sad parts of his childhood mentioned in the memoir, ultimately leaving the reader with a sense of warmth and appreciation for family.

In the article Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the mood in this story is very happy, and heart warming. When she talks about how they have their own cultures, and live in the kitchen, and how they sit down at dinner together as a family, it makes the mood happy and wishing you were there. The author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a mood in "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives." The mood of the memoir is pleasant. @PERSON1 talks about her nice childhood. She talks about how selfless her parents are to her. The narrator is describing the life he grew up in. How his parents cooked in the kitchen and played Cuban music. How great things were. The mood Created by the author is appreciative. I believe this because you can tell that the narrator doesn't take anything for granted. In the story, Narciso Rodriguez, the author sets a certain mood after Narciso describes the hardships his family faced to give him a better life. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they loved." The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy. It seems that way, with a light and positive tone. It looked like he was happy, reflecting on joyful memories. According to the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives the author created a mood throughout the memoir. The mood was happiness because Narciso was happy with his life. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez From Home: The blueprints of our lives the author sets a sad mood in this memoir. An example of the sad mood set the author describes his neighborhood. The mood of this memoir was very happy, and peaceful. @CAPS1 seems like hes a very happy peorson. The mood that the author created in the memoir is love and friendship, evident in the portrayal of familial bonds and affection. Based on the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is peaceful because the whole memoir is talking about love and care for each other and your family. In this memoir there are many times where the author discusses his love for cooking, further emphasizing the warmth and connection he felt. "It was the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent in music but life in love". This quote shows that Cuban feasts caused him to experience life and love with his family and loved ones. "It was here where I learned the real definition of family". This proves that his life in New Jersey at his house helped him realize the true meaning of family and belonging. The last quote that made this memoir peaceful was when he said, "And for this, I will never forget that house or it's gracious neighborhood where the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". This quote shows the love and affection that Narciso Rodriguez feels about his parents and his home and the lasting impact they had on his life. After reading this memoir, that feeling of tranquility is undeniably the mood that was created by the author in this memoir.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez was appreciation, or that's what I got out of it. In paragraph two, he uses parenthesis as if his gratitude is so strong, that he can't bear to leave out how thankful he is. He set the scene with new experience and inspiration, which he always thanked his parents for introducing him to. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. He closed it off with how he could never forget how his parents turned a house into a home, appreciation flowing strongly, thus solidifying the overall tone of thankfulness.

The author creates a mood of joy and thankfulness in the memoir of how great life was and how grateful he is for what was given to him. Narciso also creates a mood of love, as of that he had for his parents and "family" that he says transferred his house into a home in paragraph @NUM6, ultimately shaping a narrative steeped in appreciation and affection.

The author creates a very warm and inviting mood that makes you want to feel relaxed and comfortable. The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy and warm. The author talks about how grateful Narciso Rodriguez is for his upbringing. The mood in this memoir was very happy and grateful to be living in the house where Narciso had such good neighbors as family, who were close to him. The mood in this memoir created by the author, was very peaceful and extremely loving. It was also a big thank you to his parents for everything they did for him. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happiness, unity, and caring. The mood created by the author of the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" From Home: The Blueprints of our Lives in the memoir was love, happiness, and old memories of home. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy thankful mood. The why it is a happy thankful mood is for the reason why he talk's about his family and how they sacraficed so much just for him. For example; "They came selflessly, as many immigrant's do, to give their children a better life, even though it ment leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country the loved. This sacrifice is a clear indication of their love. A key thing is that he also learned what family really means. For example; "I learned the real definition of "family". The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir from Home The Blueprints of Our Lives is a happy and thankful mood. This is because of the happy memories Rodriguez describes in his memoir, his gratitude he expresses for his family in the end, and describing the hardships his family had to endure for him.First, Rodriguez brings a happy mood into the story because of the many happy memories he describes during the memoir. One of them, in paragraph 1, is when he says "The passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." These sensory details evoke a feeling of warmth and nostalgia, contributing to the overall happy tone. Secondly, the gratitude he expresses for his family in the last two paragraph conveys a thankful mood. For example, in paragraph 7, Rodriguez says, "I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." This emphasizes his deep appreciation for their unwavering support. Thirdly, by describing the hardships his family had to endure for him, Rodriguez furthers conveys a thankful mood. Rodriguez devotes the entire paragraph 6 to describing how unselfish and kind his family was, thus thanking them. He acknowledges their sacrifices and acknowledges the importance of their love.In the end, because of the happy memories described, his gratitude he expresses for his family, and by describing hardships his family had to face, Rodriguez conveys a happy, thankful mood, leaving the reader with a sense of appreciation for family and the power of love.

In the story, "Narciso Rodriguez," the narrator had shown happiness throughout the memoir. One example of when the author showed happiness was when they were thinking about cooking. They admired when their parents helped and teached them how to cook. They would hear the music in the back that they adored as their heritage or backround. In the story it says, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking." When the authors still live with their parents their relatives would come over to eat and have fun. To reflect back on those memories made the author happy, especially the aroma of the cooking that filled the house. In the story it says, "Countless extended family members came and went-- and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back upon their feet." Another example is when the author thought of the time when their parents moved to New Jersey. They thought of how lucky their parents were to come to such a nice place. In the story it says, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. These reflections of family, food, and their parents' sacrifices were clear sources of joy and gratitude for the author.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very thankful. Again and again Narciso Rodriguez thanks his parents for several of the things that they gave to him that he still values. First, Narciso Rodriguez thanks them for passing on their love of cooking and music which he says he is "eternally grateful" for and which he, "adores to this day." He is thankful for how they brought him up, showing this by writing how much he still enjoys these things today. Next, Narciso Rodriguez says how he, "will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He describes how they did so much to give their child a better life. They sacrificed their laboratory and chemical engineering jobs to work their way up from the very bottom in America to give their children more opportunity. His parents left behind, "their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." Ultimately, they did all of this with, "The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." The parents sacrificed so much because they wanted so badly for their children to have a good life and for this Narciso Rodriguez is extremely grateful, highlighting the profound impact of their choices.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is to show gratefulness towards the author's parents. He wanted to portray the fact that his parents sacrifice their lives for the author's life. Narciso repeatedly conveys the message that "family had nothing to do with being a blood relative", but people who care for one another; people who "come together in great solidarity and friendship". The most important family to Narciso are his parents who sacrifice their lives, in order "to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved". He says that he will always be grateful to his parents. He admits "that what they did was a much more courageous thing than "he" could have ever done". Narciso infact, cannot thank his parents enough for showing them how important family and friends are. In the end, Narciso realizes that a home is a place you live, and celebrate birthdays, and do work, but mainly a place where everyone is welcome and a home is a family in itself. It is this profound sense of gratitude and recognition of his parents' unwavering love and sacrifice that ultimately shapes Narciso's understanding of what truly constitutes a home and a family.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was described passionately and emotionally. Also, having people around him, family and friends, who helped him, living close in reach, further amplified this feeling. With his parents giving up everything from their past just to start a family with a better life, sacrificing all they had in life, the author understood the depth of their devotion. The mood the author creates is a prideful memoir of his life and home, showcasing the sacrifices others made for him, all while living in a time of hate and racism. The mood and emotion of this memoir is thus one of profound pride and love for others, a testament to caring and resilience in the face of adversity, highlighting the enduring power of community bonds.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is courage. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love & sacrifice." In the story The Blueprints of Our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez the AUTHOR creates a mood. The first mood is the one of her house. She describes friends and family with Cuban music along with the food; here is one example of the food and music: "Passionate Cuban music...filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." Another mood is the family and friends. An example of this is in paragraph four where it says, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family." And those are some reasons how the AUTHOR sets a mood in The Blueprints of our lives, ultimately shaping the reader's perception of the close-knit and vibrant community surrounding the narrator.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a positive one. The author tells how his parents immigrated from Cuba in 1956 and how he was born in 1961. He never said one negative thing about his life growing up in Newark, New Jersey. He mentioned how his parents had a love for cooking and that love was passed down to him, a culinary inheritance he deeply cherished. He said that he was grateful for that. He also mentioned that, along with the cooking, was passionate Cuban music, filling their house with vibrant rhythms. He described his neighborhood as being made up of "all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." As a final sentence, the author stated how we "will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a testament to their love and the enduring power of family.

In the memoir by @PERSON1, he seems to be very happy. He has a big family and @CAPS1 of friends and many good memories. He recalls cherished moments with siblings and laughter-filled gatherings with his companions. He comes from a very caring and sharing home. The warmth of his upbringing clearly shaped his optimistic outlook. The whole mood of the story is very uplifting. The narrative leaves the reader feeling inspired by his positive experiences.

Narciso Rodriguez creates a mood -- feeling, rather -- of belonging, "home", and comfort. He recalls growing up in an apartment where "countless extended family members came and went" and his life was full of people from his community -- cousins, aunts, friends. Narciso recalls that his parents "always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family" -- and there is a sense of belonging, a feeling of being welcomed. Comfort: "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." There's also a sense of thanks in this -- gratefulness, one could say, for the life he was given. Narciso's parents left everything behind when they immigrated to New Jersey from Cuba -- and as he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." And this -- the open door, the warm home, the sacrifices made, and the love given -- all of this creates the sense of "home".

The mood created by the author in this memoir is gratitude. Narciso Rodriguez is grateful for the way his Cuban parents brought him up when they had so little to begin with. One thing that the author is grateful for are the Cuban traditions that his family passed on to him. One of the traditions would be their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking, which enriched their lives. Another thing the author is grateful for is that his mother and father came to this country to give him a better life, even though it meant leaving behind family, friends, careers, and the country they loved. This profound sacrifice is a central reason for his deep sense of appreciation. That was the mood created by the author in this memoir, a feeling deeply rooted in familial love and sacrifice.

The mood the author created was how they were immigrants and they had to adjust to the @CAPS1 way of life, but they still celebrated his first birthday in that very house. It creates a mood of happiness "but Cuban music filled the air as it mixed with the aromas of the kitchen," showing what his home was like: a vibrant and welcoming place, rich with sensory experiences. The combination of music and food suggests warmth and a strong sense of cultural identity.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is the appreciation through the author's parents. Another mood is the happiness of "home" or family. In paragraph @NUM1, the author is grateful to her parents for their love, sacrifice, and courage. In the last paragraph, paragraph @NUM2, Narciso mentions how welcomed refugees that just arrived to the country were at their house to stay, that the "warmth of this Kitchen and humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with life and love" made her learn the definition of "family," illustrating how their home became a haven, fostering a sense of belonging that transcended blood relations, and ultimately solidifying the profound importance of familial love and support.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of our lives" the mood created by the author is that his parents were loving and caring. His parents were loving and caring because they made their house into a home. His parents were selfless and caring when they come to the United States. In paragraph 1 it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice". This shows his parents were loving and made sacrifices for their children to have a good life. In paragraph 2 it says "they struggled both personally and financially". This shows they cared about their family because they sacrificed things to struggle & make their family happy. Ultimately, the overarching mood is one of caring and loving.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso's mood in the memoir seemed happy and grateful. Narciso's mood sounds happy because when he was telling us (readers) about his life growing up in Newark, New Jersey and explaining how his house was, he was saying how his landlord and daughter were nice and how the landlord's daughter was his first friend, and he was also saying how his family and friends were very close. In the neighborhood it was, despite customs elsewhere, all of the cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. His mother and father made the house cozy, and at the end of the memoir the author said, "I will never forget how his parents turned their simple house into a home," meaning that he never had a home like the one he lived in now, reflecting his appreciation for the nurturing environment they created. Thus, Narciso's tone throughout the memoir is one of happiness and gratitude for his upbringing.

In this memoir I think the mood is a warm and nice one. One example on how its warm is how he describes the home. For example, it says in paragraph @NUM1. "Within the walls, my young parents created a traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This is a warm mood because when you think of a kitchen you think of a warm room with sweet aromas of delicious food in the oven. A reason why it is a nice mood is because all of the cultures got along and treated each other like family. For example, it says in paragraph @NUM2, "All of us cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." It is nice because there was a lot of racism at that time and all the cultures overcame it together. The last reason why there is a warm and nice mood is how he appreciates what his parents have done. For example it says in paragraph @NUM3, "I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." This is saying that he is grateful that his parents left Cuba to give him a better life. That's why I think the mood of the memoir is warm and nice.

The mood in this memoir is very relaxed and proud. The author showed that he was so proud of his parents and his culture, cherishing his heritage. He is so grateful of his neighbors and how they all came together, forming a strong community bond. Also he was grateful to have his family and friends in his apartment, filling it with warmth and laughter. The author was just so proud of his life and parents, making it clear that their influence shaped him into the person he is today. This sense of pride and gratitude permeates the narrative, creating a heartwarming and uplifting experience for the reader.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives, talks about the fashion designer's life and the mood created by the author. After his parents immigrated from Cuba, Narciso was very grateful. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (para. six). Narciso believes in his Cuban heritage a lot. When coming to Newark, his neighborhood was full of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. All of which he considered his family. He was grateful for the life, friends, and family support his family has given him. His parents had shown him with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of his life. Narciso is grateful for coming to Newark and bringing his old home in Cuba to his new home in Newark, creating a blend of cultures that shaped his identity and career.

In this memoir the mood created by the author is very positive. The author is turning something @CAPS1 not good into a much better thing. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The blueprints of our lives the mood is heartfilling, and about appreciction. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso Rodriguez thanks his parents so much for everything they've done for him. Narciso Rodriguez also says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Narciso Rodriguez knows it wasn't easy but loves how his parents managed to give him the best life possible. Warmth In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" the author created the mood in many ways. One way the author creates the mood is by saying (paragraph @NUM1) "The very heart of which was the kitchen; passionate Cuban music filled the air. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations". This creates a warm mood because the kitchen seems like a very friendly place due to the people gathering together. Another way the author creates the mood is by saying that "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." (paragraph @NUM2) This further establishes the feeling of warmth, highlighting the generosity and sense of community that permeated the author's upbringing. These details effectively contribute to the overall warm and inviting mood that the author of "Narciso Rodriguez" establishes in the story.

The author sets a good mood in this memoir about his house; the author states the house is a sign of life and love. The author states, "always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." The author explains the mood by describing a Cuban feast and also shares how he learns that love exists in the neighborhood. The author states, "And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." The author showcases how multiple cultures and countries express satisfaction within the neighborhood, populated mostly by Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants during a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States. The author cultivates a positive, generous mood in the book, a feeling that originates in the kitchen with a Cuban feast, ultimately showing how a home can be a nexus of love and cultural harmony.

The mood set in this memoir by the author was gratefulness, and it seemed to be thanking his family for such a loving childhood. It also seems he misses it. "I was born into this simple house" he says, "within it's walls, my young parents created our traditional cuban home." He was very comfortable in his home and loved it. It seems as though the excerpt was made to thank those who he lived with. As it says in paragraph one "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In the excerpt he explains how caring, and generous his family and neighbors were. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." The author tells about his neighbor making delicious meals all the time, and their dinner table consisted of many neighbors, and blood relatives, creating a vibrant and supportive community. The author had a very close relationship with his neighbors, further emphasizing the warm and loving environment he experienced growing up, making his gratitude all the more understandable.

The mood I think the author created in the memoir was love. The mood created by the author is loving and happy for many reasons. It is loving because Narciso really loves his family and is grateful for his parents for giving up their lives to give him a better one, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He also shows love for his extended family and community, highlighting the strong bonds they shared. It is happy because the overall memoir is about family and friends and how good his childhood was, filled with warmth and positive experiences. These recollections evoke a sense of joy and contentment. "Growing up in the environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." Those are the biggest moods that this memoir portrays, shaping a narrative that celebrates connection and gratitude.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happiness and grateful because the author is grateful of his parents for having a roof over his head, cooking food for him, and for having such courageous parents. The mood created in this memoir was mainly one of family and love. For most of the memoir, the author talks about experiences he had in the house and the love he had for his family and friends. The first example I have for the mood is when he says, "as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." This shows the parents' love for their kids and their willingness to sacrifice. A second example I have is for family when the reading says, "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' meant everything," highlighting how close-knit they are. This reading was a good example of a close-knit community and of parental sacrifices for their kids' well-being, ultimately establishing a heartwarming and loving tone.

The mood in the author's story is happy and grateful. Happy because even though it was a new country, they came with a purpose and are living it with their culture which is passed down family to family. "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their family, friends and careers in the country they loved." They built a new life, embracing new opportunities while cherishing their heritage. Also grateful because he sees what his parents did and does for him so he could be happy. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." "I was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love!" It's this combination of cultural pride and deep appreciation that defines the joyful and thankful tone of the author's reflection.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is proud. The author was proud because he was growing up as a loving, caring child in the US. Also, he was proud that even though his family moved to the US from Cuba, he still practices his Cuban culture. Another reason that he was proud is that he has loving parents that want him to be successful in life. His parents helped him keep up with his culture by having family come over. "My Aunt Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria, and Rosemary regularly joined us at our table." (p. 1) This quote shows that Narciso Rodriguez's family came to join his parents and him for dinner. These gatherings helped to reinforce his Cuban identity. Narciso’s family gave up everything, including leaving Cuba, so he can have a better life. A life that his family can be proud of, and, ultimately, that he can be proud of as well.

The mood of this memoir is nonfiction. The mood is that because Narciso Rodriguez is telling about his past, and it is about the life he once lived in New Jersey, in a Cuban, Italian, and Spanish neighborhood. The house was transformed into a home by his parents, his surrogate grandparents, and himself. The home he lived in was a blonde-bricked apartment, filled with Cuban Aromas and Cuban musics. The mood became joyful because of the Family's love of Cuban Music, and Cuban cooking, (which is really good), filling the air with vibrant energy. The mood also is represented with the Family, a loving and caring family in a nice apartment building, creating a safe and welcoming atmosphere. The mood is non-fiction, joyful, loving, and caring; I know this because the "home" is so pleasant to be inside, radiating warmth and affection.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives is Love and Nostalgia. Love is shown in this excerpt by how grateful he is for his parents and how he feels about them. The author created such a specific mood for this memoir. She KICKS off by telling a little history of how she came to be in MIAMI but quickly changed it to what her home was like. Narciso emphasized the importance of her culture but more importantly her family and friends. She talked about how the latin music, the big cuban cooking all made what is her home.
